Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY ) Rating Increased to Buy at ValuEngine
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Rating Increased to Buy at ValuEngine
American Banking and Market News
June 6, 2017 Tuesday
Copyright 2017 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 601 words
Body
Ryanair Holdings plc logoRyanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) was upgraded by equities researchers at            
ValuEngine from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report issued on Tuesday. 
A number of other equities research analysts have also issued reports on the company. Zacks Investment 
Research raised Ryanair Holdings plc from a "sell" rating to a "buy" rating and set a $109.00 price target on the 
stock in a research report on Saturday, May 6th. Deutsche Bank AG raised Ryanair Holdings plc from a "hold" 
rating to a "buy" rating in a research report on Monday, February 13th. Kepler Capital Markets lowered Ryanair 
Holdings plc from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research report on Friday, February 10th. Finally, Citigroup 
Inc lowered Ryanair Holdings plc from a "buy" rating to a "neutral" rating in a research report on Wednesday, May 
31st. One equities research analyst  has rated the stock with a sell rating, five have issued  a hold rating and eight 
have issued  a buy rating to the company. Ryanair Holdings plc currently has an average rating of "Buy" and a 
consensus price target of $99.50. 
Analyst Recommendations for Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY)
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ RYAAY) traded down 0.01% during trading on Tuesday, reaching $108.79. The 
company's stock had a trading volume of 139,356 shares. The stock has a market capitalization of $26.58 billion, a 
PE ratio of 18.71 and a beta of 0.72. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 1-year low of $66.09 and a 1-year high of $109.09. 
The stock has a 50 day moving average price of $97.74 and a 200 day moving average price of $86.90.   
Several hedge funds and other institutional investors have recently added to or reduced their stakes in the stock. 
First Allied Advisory Services Inc. acquired a new position in  Ryanair Holdings plc during the fourth quarter worth 
approximately $557,000.  Allianz Asset Management AG increased its position in  Ryanair Holdings plc by 59.9% in 
the fourth quarter. Allianz Asset Management AG now owns 836,774 shares of the transportation company's stock 
worth $69,670,000 after buying an additional 313,416 shares during the last quarter.  Bayesian Capital 
Management LP acquired a new position in  Ryanair Holdings plc during the fourth quarter worth approximately 
$315,000.  Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC increased its position in  Ryanair Holdings plc by 4.1% in the fourth 
quarter. Thompson Siegel & Walmsley LLC now owns 648,898 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$54,027,000 after buying an additional 25,700 shares during the last quarter.  Finally, Thornburg Investment 
Management Inc. increased its position in  Ryanair Holdings plc by 1.4% in the fourth quarter. Thornburg 
Investment Management Inc. now owns 1,219,465 shares of the transportation company's stock worth 
$101,533,000 after buying an additional 17,212 shares during the last quarter. Institutional investors and hedge 
funds own  42.80% of the company's stock.  
Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY ) Rating Increased to Buy at ValuEngine
Ryanair Holdings plc Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an 
ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-
related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.
To view ValuEngine's full report, visit ValuEngine's official website.

Ryanair Reports 11% Increase in May Traffic
MT Newswires Live Briefs
June 6, 2017 Tuesday 6:05 AM EST

Length: 41 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY), a Dublin-based budget carrier, reported Tuesday an 11% increase in passenger traffic 
to 11.8 million customes for May.
The load factor for the month gained 1 percentage point to 95%.

Ryanair May traffic up
Ryanair May traffic up
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
June 6, 2017 Tuesday 12:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2017 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS; Food
Length: 100 words
Highlight: Ryanair Ltd. has announced that its traffic has increased to 11.8 million in May 2017, an increase of 
11%, compared to 10.6 million customers in May 2016.
Body
Ryanair&#39;s Kenny Jacobs said:"Ryanair&#39;s May traffic grew by 11% to 11.8m customers, while our load 
factor jumped 1% point to 95%, on the back of lower fares and the continuing success of our "Always Getting 
Better" customer experience program."Customers can look forward to even lower fares when they make advance 
bookings for summer and winter 2017, so there&#39;s never been a better time to book a low fare flight on Ryanair 
and we urge all customers who wish to book their holidays to do so now on the Ryanair.com website or mobile app, 
where they can avail of the lowest fares in Europe."
Load-Date: June 19, 2017
End of Document

Airline updates and election lead London markets; LONDON REPORT
Airline updates and election lead London markets; LONDON REPORT
City A.M.
June 5, 2017 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 15
Length: 175 words
Body
THIS WEEK the markets will be dominated by Thursdays General Election. While it is widely expected that the 
Conservative party will win with a sound majority, the value of sterling has been sensitive to a couple of recent polls 
that have suggested otherwise.
Today, meanwhile, Hungarian lowcost airline Wizz Air will release a trading update.
Electrical online retailer AO World will put out full-year results tomorrow, though the day will be dominated by a slew 
of trading updates from the airline industry.
Easyjet, British Airways owner IAG and Ryanair will all publish trading updates. IAG has had a turbulent couple of 
weeks following a power shortage that disrupted its flights for several days.
DX Group and St Modwen Properties will also release trading updates on Wednesday, while Auto Trader Group 
and financial derivatives dealer CMC Markets will publish fullyear figures.
Pub owner and brewer Fuller, Smith & Turner will release full-year results on Friday.

Oh really, O'Leary? Ryanair CEO's paper profit from shares rockets
Oh really, O'Leary? Ryanair CEO's paper profit from shares rockets
City A.M.
June 5, 2017 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 13
Length: 105 words
Byline: SHRUTI TRIPATHI CHOPRA
Body
RYANAIR boss Michael O'Leary is sitting on a potential (EURO)50m (£44m) paper profit following the airline's 
shares soaring last week.
In 2014, O'Leary received options on 5m Ryanair shares which can be exercised at (EURO)8.35 a share in 2019 if 
he hits "exceptional performance targets". This means the airline boss can earn over (EURO)41m.
The no-frills airline's shares hit (EURO)18.68 last week following the company reporting a pre-tax profit of almost 
(EURO)1.32bn for last year.
Ryanair's shares closed at (EURO)18.20 last week.
This puts a paper value of O'Leary's share profit at (EURO)91m, (EURO)50m above the exercise price.
Graphic
 
In 2014, Michael O'Leary received options on 5m Ryanair shares

Stock Repurchase Plan Initiated by Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Board
Stock Repurchase Plan Initiated by Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Board
American Banking and Market News
June 4, 2017 Sunday
Copyright 2017 American Banking and Market News All Rights Reserved
Length: 392 words
Body
Ryanair Holdings plc logo Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) declared that its Board of Directors has initiated 
a share buyback plan, which authorizes the company to buyback    shares on Tuesday, May 30th, EventVestor 
reports. This buyback authorization authorizes the transportation company to repurchase up to 2.3% of its shares 
through open market purchases. Shares buyback plans are typically an indication that the company's board 
believes its shares are undervalued.  
A number of brokerages have issued reports on RYAAY. Citigroup Inc cut Ryanair Holdings plc from a "buy" rating 
to a "neutral" rating in a report on Wednesday. ValuEngine cut Ryanair Holdings plc from a "buy" rating to a "hold" 
rating in a report on Wednesday, May 24th.            Zacks Investment Research raised Ryanair Holdings plc from a 
"sell" rating to a "hold" rating in a report on Friday, February 10th. Deutsche Bank AG raised Ryanair Holdings plc 
from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on Monday, February 13th. Finally, Kepler Capital Markets cut 
Ryanair Holdings plc from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a report on Friday, February 10th. One analyst  has 
rated the stock with a sell rating, six have given a hold rating and seven have issued  a buy rating to the company. 
The company presently has an average rating of "Hold" and an average target price of $99.50. 
Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) traded up 0.47% during mid-day trading on Friday, hitting $108.90. The 
stock had a trading volume of 211,625 shares. Ryanair Holdings plc has a 1-year low of $66.09 and a 1-year high of 
$109.09. The stock's 50-day moving average price is $97.42 and its 200 day moving average price is $86.66. The 
company has a market capitalization of $26.87 billion, a P/E ratio of 19.46 and a beta of 0.72.  
About Ryanair Holdings plc
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an 
ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-
related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.
Load-Date: June 20, 2017
End of Document

on the company.

Wifi on-board gets thumbs down from Ryanair boss
Wifi on-board gets thumbs down from Ryanair boss
Sunday Business Post
June 3, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 362 words
Byline: Ian Guider
Highlight: O'Leary says service is too costly to provide
Body
Ryanair boss Michael O’Leary has ruled out installing wifi on the airline’s fleet, saying the service is too costly to 
provide.
He told analysts on a conference call last week that he didn’t see wifi generating enough revenue from passengers 
to make it a worthwhile investment.
“Our concern with wifi continues to be the technology at the moment,” he said, explaining that the equipment 
required to provide such a service would create a 4 per cent fuel drag. “It is far too expensive a product with, I think, 
almost no revenue . . . upside. On average, flight distance is still only 1 hour 15 minutes and the vast majority of 
people now are getting onboard our aircraft, they already have downloaded Netflix and whatever else it is. They 
don’t need wifi and they’re unlikely to pay the cost of it.
“We would never introduce wifi as some kind of expensive service enhancement. If it isn’t revenue-generating, 
frankly, we wouldn’t be introducing it.”
O’Leary said he doubted if one out of the 120 million passengers the airline carried last year had booked Ryanair 
“on the basis, ‘I wonder if they have wifi’ ”.
Several airlines offer passengers wifi for free but most restrict usage to simple browsing rather than streaming. Most 
major long-haul carriers, including Aer Lingus, charge passengers for internet access.
O’Leary also told the conference call Ryanair was in talks with Aer Lingus and the fast-growing Norwegian Airlines 
about selling their long-haul routes on its website. Earlier this month it sealed its first such deal, for Spanish carrier 
Air Europa.
Wifi on-board gets thumbs down from Ryanair boss
“The difficulty we’re having in cementing the other agreements is that getting the computer systems to speak to 
each other is somewhat complicated. And Aer Lingus and Norwegian and some of the others don’t move at the 
speed we do,” he said.
Ryanair last week announced that its profits to the end of March had risen 6 per cent to €1.3 billion on the back of a 
13 per cent rise in the number of passengers carried, to 120 million. It is forecasting profits in the current financial 
year of up to €1.45 billion. It is also planning to buy back €600 million of its outstanding shares to return surplus 
cash to investors.
Load-Date: June 4, 2017
End of Document
Breaking the cycle
Breaking the cycle
Sunday Business Post
June 3, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 923 words
Byline: Catherine Healy
Highlight: With new road legislation in the offing, Catherine Healy clears a path through the red mist to offer her 
view on the ongoing cars v bikes battle 
Body
Michael O’Leary pulled no punches in an interview published in this paper last Sunday. “We are just fucking up this 
city,” fumed the Ryanair chief executive. “Headbangers in Dublin fucking Corporation” should focus on sensible 
solutions to traffic congestion, he said, rather than worrying about “fucking cyclists” (“I’d shoot them all”).
It’s not the first time O’Leary has lashed out at his two-wheeled foes. For a timeline, simply Google his name and 
“cyclists”:
•
Ryanair boss Michael O’Leary blasted after anti-cyclist rant (October 2016)
•
Michael O’Leary: Dublin is run by ‘dim and pretty stupid’ cyclists (June 2016)
•
Ryanair’s Michael O’Leary says cyclists should be ‘shot’ (May 2016)
It bears repeating: like Donald Trump, O’Leary is a master of whipping up outrage for free publicity. It’s a reciprocal 
relationship: O’Leary provides easy soundbites, and in exchange he gets time to promote his business. That’s the 
tacit rule.
Poor old cyclists have always been fair game, of course, for indignant drivers. It can be difficult to resist a swipe at 
the helmeted Lycra people zooming through traffic when you’re stuck in a car at rush hour, and I’m sure I’m not the 
only person who’s nearly been mowed down by a Dublin Bikes warrior swerving onto the footpath for that last 
stretch to the docking station.
But whatever about minor annoyances, the level of outright hysteria with which cyclist-friendly initiatives are so 
often greeted never fails to perplex. Let’s take, for example, the lower speed limits recently introduced for residential 
parts of Dublin – on the back of campaigning by the parents of Jake Brennan, the six-year-old who was knocked 
down and killed while playing in his estate in 2014.
Breaking the cycle
If you looked only at online reaction, you might think these new 30km/h zones are the result of some kind of 
underground cyclist conspiracy. The powers that be, one reader commented under an article on TheJournal.ie, 
“don’t want cars in [the] city. There is some utopia plan that [it] will be pedestrians and cyclists only with the 
occasional sprinkling of public transport.” Another common argument goes something along the lines of: “We’ll have 
cyclists overtaking us at this stage!!!” It’s driver versus non-driver in this battle and only one can win, cry the likes of 
O’Leary.
A worrying number of drivers seem to have a ‘no contact, no harm’ attitude
Why the raging fury, then, at others taking up space on public roads? You can understand why drivers might feel it 
only natural to reign over the pedalling mortals. Most towns and cities are designed and managed not with cyclists 
in mind: few have cycle paths and those that are in place all too often disappear into bus lanes. If you want a real 
taster of the hostile showdown between cyclists and drivers, just brave Ormond Quay in Dublin at 9am on a week 
day. Hundreds of cyclists have no option here but to squeeze through rows of cars and buses, counting only on the 
hope that they won’t be tipped over by a sudden lurch in the flow of traffic, and no surprise: there’s plenty of 
beeping.
Cyclist-hating car owners are like manspreaders on public transport: usually entitled, obnoxious and oblivious to the 
hardship they’re causing others. “I have an inalienable right to this space,” think the manspreaders and angry 
drivers. Machinery, as Martin Heidegger once put it, “unfolds a specific character of domination . . . a unique kind of 
consciousness of conquest”, and the same could be said for even the most innocent looking Ford or Volvo. Cars 
are bigger, stronger, faster than you, puny cyclist. This is the survival of the fittest, so get off our road.
But something more serious than pride is at stake here. Anyone who cycles will know that shudder-down-the-spine 
feeling when news emerges of another fatal bike accident, not least when there are two in the space of a week. The 
latest casualty was an American tourist who collided with a vehicle in the Gap of Dunloe on Tuesday, the same day 
a man died after being knocked off his bike in Mayo last Sunday. We don’t know the precise circumstances 
involved, but these deaths are reminders – as if any more reminders were needed – of just how vulnerable cyclists 
still are. So far this year, nine cyclists have been killed on Irish roads, compared to ten for all of 2016.
Some progress has been made. For one thing, legislation banning drivers from overtaking cyclists too closely is 
expected to be passed before the Dáil breaks for summer recess. As TD Ciarán Cannon, who published the bill, put 
it: “A worrying number of drivers seem to have a ‘no contact, no harm’ attitude.”
But there’s still considerable opposition to diverting cars away from heavily congested areas such as the north 
quays in Dublin city centre, and pedestrianising College Green, for instance.
We all understand the frustration some cyclists can cause – especially when they’re inexperienced – but the bigger 
issue here is the need for better public transport and road management systems. The reality that must be faced, 
after all, is that, despite all the challenges, cycling is booming. Council figures show a record number of people 
cycled into Dublin city in 2016, with more than 12,000 commuting by bike on an average morning. Cycle advocates 
are gaining ground, with groups such as the Dublin Cycling Campaign putting forward compelling policy solutions 
as well as critical voices.
What cyclists lack in strength they make up for now in critical mass. So honk away, drivers, but they’re not going 
anywhere. As Dave Bautista would say: deal with it. ■
Load-Date: June 4, 2017
End of Document
Cost-cutter's comedown at lumbering legacy carrier Corporate person in the news: Alex Cruz, Chief executive, 
British Airways
Cost-cutter's comedown at lumbering legacy carrier; Corporate person in 
the news: Alex Cruz, Chief executive, British Airways
Financial Times (London, England)
June 3, 2017 Saturday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES - WEEK IN REVIEW; Pg. 9
Length: 587 words
Byline: Tanya Powley
Body
Not many airline chiefs can boast they have an aircraft named after them. But British Airways boss Alex Cruz, the 
person at the centre of the airline's computer system crash , can.
Mr Cruz's team, when he was in charge of Vueling, the Spanish low-cost carrier, surprised him by putting his name 
on an Airbus A320.
As 50th birthday presents go, it was impressive, and showed he was well liked at a company he headed for seven 
years before he was named chief executive at BA in 2015.
"He is a really nice guy," one aviation analyst says. "He is very approachable and not flashy at all."
Another analyst agrees, noting that Mr Cruz was an "empowering" manager at Vueling, adept at being in front of 
audiences.
But the latter comment may strike some as odd after this week's public relations confusion at BA. More than 75,000 
passengers were stranded on Saturday, and tens of thousands more were hit by flight delays, after a power outage 
grounded all flights at the start of one of the busiest weekends for Britain's flag carrier.
Cost-cutter's comedown at lumbering legacy carrier Corporate person in the news: Alex Cruz, Chief executive, 
British Airways
A bad situation was made worse by Mr Cruz' response. In the first two days, rather than apologising to passengers 
directly at Heathrow, he appeared in videos wearing a high-visibility jacket, surrounded by a room full of computers.
Some in the industry expressed surprise at Mr Cruz's handling of the situation , saying he was not normally a man 
to hide out of sight.
John Strickland, an aviation consultant in London, says: "Alex proved himself at Vueling. I think he's very tech-
savvy. But he's got a challenge in coming from a much smaller-scale airline to the monolith that is BA."
Originally from Bilbao, Mr Cruz graduated as an industrial engineer from Central Michigan University, in the US.
In 2006, the Basque father of four founded Clickair, the Spanish airline, which merged with Vueling three years later 
when he became chief executive. Vueling was acquired by International Airlines Group in 2013, and the fast-
growing carrier became one of the biggest contributors to the group's profits in the following two years.
At the time of Vueling's purchase by IAG, Mr Cruz was riding high on his successes at the Spanish carrier and was 
viewed as one of the airline industry's rising talents. He presided over Vueling's expansion from an airline operating 
a fleet of almost 40 aircraft in 2010 to one with more than 100 today.
The expansion of the low-cost carrier has been widely admired, with growth averaging about 20 per cent a year 
until recently.
Mr Cruz was also a pioneer of a more upmarket low-cost offering, which easyJet and Ryanair have moved towards.
One City analyst says: "He comes from a low-cost background, but Alex does care about the product. His strategy 
at Vueling was about building a premium low-cost carrier with a business class in the front but still low unit costs."
Some aviation commentators think Mr Cruz is feeling the pressure of running a very different type of airline.
An industry commentator says: "He is very self-confident. I think he thought he was going to shock the airline into 
doing things they would never have done before, and he has. But he has fuelled the feeling that it's all about cost 
and they are going to keep cutting the benefits and service and that flyers will put up with it."
After this week, Mr Cruz could not be blamed for looking back at his days at Vueling with fondness. After having the 
finger of blame pointed at him for last weekend's disaster, it is likely to be a long while, if ever, before he has a BA 
plane named after him. Tanya Powley
Load-Date: June 2, 2017
End of Document
Meade living the Derby dream with Eminent; INTERVIEW Geoff Lester caught up with trainer Martyn Meade 
ahead of this afternoon's big race
Meade living the Derby dream with Eminent; INTERVIEW Geoff Lester caught 
up with trainer Martyn Meade ahead of this afternoon's big race
City A.M.
June 3, 2017 Saturday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2017 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 8
Length: 1023 words
Body
MOST racehorse trainers will tell you that trying to make a profit in their profession is like pushing an elephant up 
the stairs. But four years ago Martyn Meade turned his back on the City in an attempt to take on the big beasts of 
Coolmore and Godolphin.
Meade, who trains the talented Eminent, third-favourite for today's Investec Derby at Epsom, explained: "Racing 
has always been a passion of mine, and when it became economically viable to move up to Newmarket and dip our 
toes into deeper waters we decided to give it a go, with the emphasis very much on quality rather than quantity."
The 69-year-old chairman of London-based investment firm Hadleigh PVT, which deals in potential market leaders 
across the manufacturing and industrial sectors, has been here before.
He first dabbled with training on a much smaller scale in the 1970's and, during the two decades that followed, went 
on to enjoy limited success with jumpers from his base in Wiltshire.
Sadly, the numbers didn't add up. Realising that he was going to end up old and poor, Meade decided it was best to 
return to the City. "I couldn't do anything about the former, but I didn't fancy the latter," he says, looking back 
stoically.
The bug had bitten hard, however, and even when he was back in London he always picked up the Racing Post 
each morning before any other paper.
When his partners at Hadleigh were more than capable of keeping the ship afloat, he handed over command in 
2013 and re-took the reins in racing.
Meade living the Derby dream with Eminent; INTERVIEW Geoff Lester caught up with trainer Martyn Meade 
ahead of this afternoon's big race
"We set our hearts on Newmarket as they have the best facilities in the world, and when Sefton Lodge came on the 
market we knew we had to have it," declared Meade, whose predecessors at this historic 50-box yard include the 
Joel family, Charles St George and Tony Ryan, founder of Ryanair.
Meade, who is also heavily involved in the prestigious Snailwell Stud in the town, said: "Sefton Lodge had not been 
used for 10 years so needed plenty of renovation, but we worked hard to bring it back up to scratch. It is in the most 
wonderful position in that we have direct access to the Long Hill and Warren Hill canters and are only a stone's 
throw from the Limekilns, where you'll find the best chalk-based gallop on the globe."
It was now a case of finding the right ammunition. Irish Rookie, one of his first purchases, cost only (EURO)16,000 
and came so close to giving the trainer the perfect start, beating all except subsequent Royal Ascot winner Ervedya 
in the French 1000 Guineas at Longchamp in 2015.
Meade knows that teamwork is everything in whatever business you are in. While he is the one flying the plane, he 
has his son Freddie in the cockpit with him as assistant, as well as the support of some of the best brains in the 
bloodstock world.
Together they have set the coordinates for Epsom today, where Eminent is on the verge of a victory scarcely seen 
since David v Goliath took centre stage.
Observing that the most recent Magnificent Seven on the Derby roll of honour are Aidan O'Brien (three), Andre 
Fabre, John Gosden, Sir Michael Stoute, Jim Bolger, John Oxx and Dermot Weld, he concedes that he sometimes 
has to pinch himself to make sure that he is not in La La Land.
So how come a relative newcomer like Meade, rather than those celebrated trainers ended up with Eminent, who 
not only has top-class form but also a pedigree to match, being one of the first crop of the mighty Frankel? Meade 
digests the question for a few seconds, having no doubt asked himself the same thing many times, before revealing 
the story behind what is the best business deal that even he has made.
He recalled: "We looked at virtually every horse at the Tattersalls Sales and I remember walking past this Frankel 
and thinking to myself 'he'll be out of our league as he'll make between 300-400,000gns.' "However, I kept an eye 
on the board and noticed that he was not selling and, together with bloodstock agent Hubie de Burgh, we agreed 
that he was the most gorgeous individual and that we had to get him, which happily we did at 150,000gns.
"I was buying on spec, but Hubie immediately got in touch with Sir Peter Vela, who is a leading ownerbreeder in 
New Zealand and he quickly agreed to come on board.
"We didn't want an owner who would sell on as soon as he won a maiden, but, like us, Sir Peter is in it for the long 
haul, and I'm delighted he bought the colt. He is coming over for the big day - you couldn't keep him away."
Eminent won his only race as a two-year-old at Newmarket and he thrived through the winter, returning to the 
Rowley Mile to win the Craven Stakes and set a course record in April. "He was immature mentally but physically 
he was ready to go," said Meade, "though we didn't expect him to win so well."
That prompted the trainer to take the traditional route and run in the 2000 Guineas, but things did not go according 
to plan.
He explained: "We thought that the Craven had taken nothing out of him, but in reality, no horse wins a Pattern race 
without having a proper test. The ground was plenty quick enough, and in a race which ultimately developed into a 
sprint, Eminent could not use his amazing long stride.
"However, Jim Crowley looked after him when he realised they would not win, and one thing we learned in the 
Guineas is that he needed to go up in trip. Since then the Investec Derby has been the one thing on our minds.
Meade living the Derby dream with Eminent; INTERVIEW Geoff Lester caught up with trainer Martyn Meade 
ahead of this afternoon's big race
"We took him to Epsom recently for the Breakfast with the Stars morning, and he coped with Tattenham Corner and 
the downhill run very well. Even though we were not pressing any buttons, time students told us that we clocked 
more than 40mph for the last three furlongs.
"Eminent's temperament leads us to think he won't be bothered by all the hullaballoo on the day, and if he gets into 
a rhythm and uses that stride of his, he has that potent finishing kick which might just prove decisive."
Today is a huge day for Meade and his team but he knows you need to plan for the future in this game: "Maybe if 
Eminent does happen to win I can persuade Bernard Kantor [Investec MD] to send me a couple of horses while we 
are on the podium!"
We agreed that he was the most gorgeous individual and that we had to get him
Graphic
 
Martyn Meade pictured with his Investec Derby hope Eminent

Ryanair Holdings plc ( RYAAY ) Earns Daily Coverage Optimism Score of 0.05
Ryanair Holdings plc (RYAAY) Earns Daily Coverage Optimism Score of 0.05
American Banking and Market News
June 1, 2017 Thursday

Body
Ryanair Holdings plc logo Headlines about Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) have been trending somewhat 
positive this week, according to Alpha One Sentiment Analysis. The research group, a unit of Accern, identifies 
negative and positive news coverage by analyzing more than 20 million news and blog sources in real time. Alpha 
One ranks coverage of publicly-traded companies on a scale of negative one to positive one, with scores closest to 
one being the most favorable. Ryanair Holdings plc earned a media sentiment score of 0.05 on Alpha One's scale. 
Alpha One also gave media coverage about the transportation company an impact score of 66 out of 100, indicating 
that recent news coverage is likely to have an impact on the company's share price in the next several days.  
A number of research firms recently commented on RYAAY. Bank of America Corp cut Ryanair Holdings plc from a 
"neutral" rating to an "underperform" rating in a research note on Tuesday, January 3rd. Zacks Investment 
Research cut Ryanair Holdings plc from a "strong-buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a research note on Friday, 
January 6th. Deutsche Bank AG raised Ryanair Holdings plc from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a research note 
on Monday, February 13th. Canaccord Genuity began coverage on Ryanair Holdings plc in a research note on 
Thursday, January 26th. They issued a "buy" rating on the stock. Finally, Barclays PLC  reissued a "buy" rating on 
shares of Ryanair Holdings plc in a research note on Tuesday, January 10th. Two research analysts have rated the 
stock with a sell rating, four have given a hold rating and six have issued  a buy rating to the company. The 
company currently has an average rating of "Hold" and an average price target of $93.00. 
Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY ) traded down 0.59% during mid-day trading on Tuesday, reaching $91.02. 
173,068 shares of the company's stock traded hands. The firm has a market cap of $22.46 billion, a price-to-
earnings ratio of 16.72 and a beta of 0.72. Ryanair Holdings plc has a one year low of $66.09 and a one year high 
of $93.53. The firm's 50-day moving average price is $84.22 and its 200 day moving average price is $81.62.   
Ryanair Holdings plc Company Profile
Ryanair Holdings plc (Ryanair Holdings) is a holding company for Ryanair Limited (Ryanair). Ryanair operates an 
ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in 
other activities connected with its core air passenger service, including non-flight scheduled services, Internet-
related services, and the in-flight sale of beverages, food and merchandise.

Riding on the wings of change
Riding on the wings of change
Sunday Business Post
June 1, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 923 words
Byline: Quinton O'Reilly
Highlight: Four years ago, Ryanair decided to discard its old image and focus on customer satisfaction. Fast 
forward to today and it has one of the most popular and resilient airline sites in the world, writes Quinton O’Reilly 
Body
As far as changing an image is concerned, Ryanair is probably one of the most high-profile examples out there. 
While it prided itself on its low fares, there were other less positive parts of the experience, such as a hardline 
stance on cabin baggage allowance, penalties for not printing out boarding passes, and a hard-to-navigate website, 
among other things.
In 2014, it decided to make a change by launching the Always Getting Better programme, designed to improve the 
customer experience. Fast forward to today and the redesigned site now gets 600 million visits per year, while it has 
20 million users on its iOS and Android app.
Part of that success was a rethink of how its digital services work and for its chief technical officer, John Hurley, the 
company continues to go from strength to strength; it recently opened its third Ryanair Labs in Madrid (the other two 
are in Dublin and Wroclaw in Poland).
“I can’t emphasise how big it was. It was a huge challenge coming from [four years ago], said Hurley. “I don’t want 
to say ground zero, but we weren’t far off it, now what we have is a website that is probably industry leading in that 
space and is probably the best airline website in Europe.
“It was huge. We had to set up teams from scratch, build everything in-house, we had 200 odd developers [and] it 
was a continuous development model . . . It was launched in November of 2015 and we changed every line of code 
of the entire website from that.
“We were lucky in a sense in that we were a bit late to the game in taking advantage of being second mover or third 
mover in technologies .
Riding on the wings of change
“We had huge advantages in speed, reliability and working across all devices. Our web and mobile footprint was 
spot on from day one because we bypassed all of those problems . . . we’re continuously looking to evolve by 
looking for the best way to do things.”
Part of its new digital operations is the ability to take on any problems that may arise. On the most basic side of 
things, it has placed particular emphasis on resilience and protocol if something goes wrong.
“Our website is served up in three different data centres across Europe: Dublin, London and Frankfurt,” he said.
“We have very good resiliency there so if, God forbid, one server goes down, we can run it on the other two. We 
can run the site on one and a half servers if we have to, so we’ve good measures in place.
“One half we need for peak. Peak only happens in evenings due to regular working days . . . [but] it’s very much 
reliability and redundancy at the forefront. It simply can’t go down.”
When Ryanair was designing the site, one of the biggest challenges it would have to deal with was performance 
testing. It wouldn’t be just a case of launching the new site and leaving it as was, there were numerous things that 
the developers wouldn’t necessarily foresee.
Therefore observing how people use the site is vital, not just for its launch, but even to this day, especially since the 
aim was to make the site and experience as easy and as seamless as possible.
“You can do all the testing in the world, but you can’t beat users on a system doing all of the crazy stuff that you 
couldn’t possibly find with A/B testing,” said Hurley.
“Customer data started coming to us with booking models that were working correctly, secure and protecting other 
parts . . . That was a big challenge for us because it’s crazy to design nice pretty pictures and say ‘Move this from 
17 clicks down to three clicks.’ Those 17 clicks evolved over the years for various reasons and to take them all out 
of the system while maintaining the integrity of it and still have a system that works was challenging.”
That level of analysis works on a number of ways. As well as a team working 24/7 every day, every single action or 
error on the site can be compared. The IT team normally compare similar days like Mondays to Mondays instead of 
two days in a row as the needs and customer interaction differs.
Automation, redundancy measures, cloud bursting for when demand is greater than expected, as well as the ability 
to quickly toggle parts of the site, means it would take a significant number of problems for the site to go down.
“It’s fully monitored and automated . . . our developers are in a DevOps model so developers are accountable for 
code that goes into production so if you release something in the morning, you are on call to make sure it’s working 
on it and it’s performing,” said Hurley.
“We’ve an automated rollback system where key features are toggleable so if there was a problem with Rooms, we 
can apply a piece of code there and then to save Rooms and the booking flow so all the nice parts, even if 
MyRyanair had a problem with them, we can temporarily disable them to keep the site running.
“We have micro servers and other IT measures in place, building that in and testing it going forward . . . it is quite 
challenging as the site is never down, it’s always taking bookings.”
For now, the focus is to continue improving the experience through small and incremental changes. As well as the 
introduction of Ryanair credits, a new version of Rooms, and talks with airlines about connecting more flights, it’s all 
systems go. The company’s main aim remains the same though.
“We believe in two types of travellers: the one that books their hotel first and then goes to the flight, and then the 
other type of person who books their flight first and then plans their holidays around it,” said Hurley. “We want to be 
the destination of choice for anyone who takes the flights first.”
Riding on the wings of change
Load-Date: June 4, 2017
End of Document
2017 Paris air show announcements: 20 June
2017 Paris air show announcements: 20 June
AirFinance Journal
June 2017
Copyright 2017 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 1149 words
Byline: Olivier Bonnassies
Body
The second day of the Paris air show attracted more order announcements than the first.
The Max family aircraft dominated the headlines once again with 196 firm orders placed and commitments for 
another 125 units. Avolon committed for a total of 125 aircraft, saying the order represents its single largest order 
placed with Boeing to date.
Airbus recorded 10 firm orders and 95 commitments.
Lessors placed firm orders for 70 new aircraft, while airlines orders totalled 49. In addition, United Airlines 
announced the conversion of 100 Max orders into the Max 10 model.
Leasing companies committed for another 170 aircraft under letters of intent, memorandums of understanding and 
commitments. Airline commitments totalled 109 aircraft.
Embraer announced a series of E1 orders before disclosing 40 E2 orders and commitments from two undisclosed 
customers. AirFinance Journal understands potential customers for the E2 includes Air Astana and Arkia.
Aircraft orders/agreements
Aviation Capital Group announced an order for 20 Boeing 737 Max 10s. ACG is already part of the 737 Max family 
with 60 current orders, including a mix of Max 8s and Max 9s.
Okay Airways announced an order for seven Max 8s and eight Max 10s. The Chinese carrier also signed a 
memorandum of understanding for five 787-9s.
Avolon signed a memorandum of understanding for 125 737 Max 8s. The agreement includes 75 Max 8s as well as 
purchase rights for an additional 50 737 Max 8s.
SpiceJet signed a letter of intent for 50 Bombardier Q400s. The agreement includes 25 firm orders and 25 purchase 
rights.
Blue Air announced an order for six Max aircraft.
2017 Paris air show announcements: 20 June
Ryanair finalised an order for 10 additional 737 Max 200s, five of which will deliver in the first half of 2019, with the 
second 5 delivering in the first half of 2020. The Irish-based low cost carrier has an existing firm order for 100 737 
Max 200s, with a further 100 options remaining.
Azerbaijan Airlines announced a commitment for four 787-8s.
KLM Royal Dutch Airlines ordered two additional Embraer 190s.
CDB Aviation Lease Finance signed a memorandum of understanding for 45 aircraft, consisting of 30 A320neos 
and 15 A321neos. In addition, 15 A320neo positions from CDB Aviation’s previous order will be converted to 
A321neo aircraft.
Japan Airlines signed a firm order for an additional E190 with Embraer for subsidiary J-AIR. J-AIR currently 
operates seven E190s and 17 E170s – 24 E-Jets in total, with an additional eight E-Jets on backlog.
Viva Air signed a memorandum of understanding with Airbus for 50 A320 family aircraft. The transaction includes 
15 A321 and 35 A320neo aircraft.
Belaviaordered one E175 and one E195 - both for delivery in 2018. The aircraft will join the four Embraer two E195s 
and two E175s operated by Belavia.
Fuji Dream Airlines signed a firm order of three E175s, with purchase rights for an additional three aircraft of the 
type. FDA currently operates three E170s and eight E175s. In addition, FDA has also extended the agreement for 
Embraer’s Flight Hour Programme (Pool) for up to eight years.
China Aircraft Leasing Group (CALC) announced an order for 50 737 Max aircraft, including 15 Max 10s. The 
aircraft will be delivered “in stages” up until 2023.
United Airlines announced an agreement to convert 100 of its current 737 Max orders into 737 Max 10s, becoming 
the largest single 737 Max 10 customer in the world. United also announced an order for four additional 777-300ER 
aircraft.
Delta Air Lines placed an order for 10 Airbus A321s after announcing orders for 30 incremental A321s in May.
Embraer announced a 10 E195-E2s firm order, with an additional 10 purchase rights for the E190-E2 from an 
undisclosed customer.
Embraer signed a commitment with an undisclosed customer to purchase 20 E190-E2s.
Japan Investment Adviser (JIA) announced a commitment to purchase 10 Max 8 aircraft. JIA Group activities 
include operating a lease business that manages a fleet of around 60 aircraft through its operating lease arm, JP 
Lease Products & Services.
Ethiopian Airlines placed an order for 10 additional Airbus A350-900 aircraft. The African carrier operates a fleet of 
four A350s, two of which are on lease, from the 12 aircraft it current has on order.
Air Senegal signed a contract for a firm order of two ATR72-600s with ATR. Delivery of these aircraft, which will 
constitute the initial fleet of the airline, are scheduled for November 2017.
Bombardier unveiled Ethiopian Airlines as the customer for five additional Q400s. Bombardier announced the order 
on 9 June with an undisclosed customer.
Ethiopian Airlines announced a commitment agreement for two 777 freighters with Boeing.

A320neo aircraft. The aircraft order was announced in 2014.
Aviation Capital Group announced an order with CFM International for LEAP-1B engines to power 20 new Boeing 
737 Max 10s.

repair and overhaul of the CF34-10E engines powering its four Embraer 190 aircraft.
ALC selected CFM International’s LEAP-1A engine to power 25 additional Airbus A320neo family aircraft. The 
engines are for option aircraft previously announced and are scheduled for delivery between 2019 and 2022.

aircraft. The order includes a long-term support agreement, and the airline is scheduled to begin taking delivery in 
2018. The aircraft order was announced February 2014.

repair and overhaul 41 CF6-80C2 engines that power its fleet of Boeing 767-300F aircraft.

repair and overhaul of its GE90 fleet, including GE90-110B engines powering its 12 Boeing 777 freighter aircraft 
and GE90-115B engines powering its 10 Boeing 777-300ER aircraft.

aircraft with TotalCare&reg; service support. In addition, the order includes TotalCare for 14 aircraft already in 
service or on order. Ethiopian became Africa’s first A350 operator in 2015 and currently has four of its initial 14 
aircraft in service.

and CF34 engines with GE Aviation. The deal enables Hainan Airlines and HNA Technic to serve as an authorized 
service provider for GEnx-1B and CF34-10 engines and perform OEM maintenance, overhaul workscoping and 
component repairs as well as provide comprehensive materials support.

Ryanair Holdings plc logo Shares of Ryanair Holdings plc (NASDAQ:RYAAY) have received a consensus 
recommendation of "Hold" from the thirteen ratings firms that are presently  covering the stock,            
MarketBeat.com  reports. One research analyst  has rated the stock with a sell rating, five have assigned  a hold 
rating and seven have given a buy rating to  the company. The average 1 year target price among brokerages that 
have issued a report on the stock in the last year is $99.50.  
Several analysts have recently issued reports on the company. ValuEngine  lowered Ryanair Holdings plc from a 
"buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a report on Wednesday, May 24th. Kepler Capital Markets lowered Ryanair 
Holdings plc from a "buy" rating to a "hold" rating in a report on Friday, February 10th.            Zacks Investment 
Research  raised Ryanair Holdings plc from a "sell" rating to a "hold" rating in a report on Friday, February 10th. 
Finally, Deutsche Bank AG raised Ryanair Holdings plc from a "hold" rating to a "buy" rating in a report on Monday, 
February 13th.

ultra-low fare, scheduled-passenger airline serving short-haul, point-to-point routes between Ireland, the United 
Kingdom, Continental Europe, Morocco and Israel. Ryanair provides various ancillary services and engages in

Ryanair looks to cut fares and expand after record profit
Ryanair looks to cut fares and expand after record profit
Business World (Digest)
May 31, 2017 Wednesday
Copyright 2017 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 566 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
Ryanair announced a record annual profit on Tuesday in a vindication of its strategy of cutting fares to boost market 
share, and said it would turn up the heat further on rivals.
Its warning to competitors came as one of them, British Airways, was counting the cost of a huge IT failure that left 
75,000 passengers stranded over a holiday weekend.
Ryanair, Europe's largest airline by passenger numbers, has helped drive down short-haul ticket prices in Europe 
by increasing its capacity by 33%, or about 30 million seats, in the past two years.
Its cost base, widely acknowledged as the lowest of Europe's major carriers thanks to low plane purchase, 
maintenance and staff costs, has allowed it to undercut rivals while still making a profit.
The Irish airline made a profit after tax of 1.3 billion euros in the year to the end of March, in line with analyst 
forecasts, even as it slashed ticket prices to fill almost 14 million seats added during the period.
"I take comfort from the fact that we can increase profit in a year where fares fall by 13%," Chief Executive Michael 
O'Leary told analysts.
"We have seen profitability double ... over a three year period and frankly I see no reason why that trend won't 
continue."
At 1400 GMT, Ryanair shares were up 2.5% at 18.185 euros.
Ryanair looks to cut fares and expand after record profit
In the coming year, Ryanair is set to slow the pace of capacity growth to around 8%, or 10 million seats, and 
expects ticket prices to fall by 5-7%.
That will see its average fares fall by around 5 percent over the key summer months, likely putting pressure on 
rivals.
"I see a lot of airlines talking up the first half of the year and talking up (revenue per passenger) yield performance. I 
think that is a little overdone," O'Leary said.
British Airways owner IAG had said before its disastrous IT failure that it expected quarterly revenue per passenger 
mile flown to rise year-on-year for the first time since 2014 in April to June.
Air France and Lufthansa have also said pricing and bookings are improving.
O'Leary was upbeat about priority markets including Italy, where Ryanair expects Alitalia to cut its short-haul 
operations as part of restructuring, and Germany, where he said any acquisition of Air Berlin could open up airport 
slots.
Ryanair would be happy to sacrifice short term profitability to dislodge incumbents and open new markets, he 
added.
Ryanair is in talks with Boeing about buying up to five extra planes and extending the leases on 10 more over the 
next two years. In recent weeks, it has suggested it could source additional planes if AlItalia or Air Berlin were to 
free up capacity.
It has also spoken to around 200 airports about moving capacity from Britain in the event of a "hard Brexit," where 
Britain would leave the EU's single market, O'Leary said.
In a sign of Ryanair's financial confidence, it announced a 600 million euro share buyback to start immediately.
However, O'Leary warned there were clouds on the horizon, including Brexit, which he has said could lead to a total 
breakdown in all flights between Britain and the EU for a time.
Brexit could also force some British investors in Ryanair to sell their stakes as EU airlines must be majority owned 
by EU nationals.
The impact on bookings of the recent suicide bombing in Manchester in which 22 people died was likely to be short-
lived, but a further attack could knock bookings off course, he said. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: June 14, 2017
End of Document

Ryanair lifts full-year profits after slashing fares Airlines
Ryanair lifts full-year profits after slashing fares; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
May 31, 2017 Wednesday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 14
Length: 407 words
Byline: Tanya Powley, Transport Correspondent
Highlight: Revenues climb to EUR6.6bn as passenger numbers hit a record of 120m
Body
Ryanair has lifted full-year profits despite slashing fares to stimulate demand after terrorist attacks and Britain's 
decision to leave the EU.
Europe's biggest low-cost airline posted a EUR1.32bn post-tax profit for the financial year to March 31.
The figure was at the lower end of guidance of between EUR1.3bn and EUR1.35bn, but in line with analysts' 
expectations. Revenues were 2 per cent higher at EUR6.6bn.
Ryanair had lowered its full-year forecast from EUR1.37bn to EUR1.42bn last year because of the impact of the 
weak pound following the UK referendum.
European airlines have been struggling with economic uncertainty unleashed by the Brexit vote, the effect of terror 
attacks in the EU, and a glut of new capacity, which has been pushing down fares.
Ryanair said it had cut average fares 13 per cent over the year to EUR41, which helped it attract a record 120m 
passengers, up from a previous estimate of 116m. However, there have been signs of a wider turnround, with large 
legacy carriers - BA owner International Airlines Group, Lufthansa and Air France-KLM - and UK-based low-cost 
airline easyJet reporting increased demand for tickets and improving pricing.
Ryanair lifts full-year profits after slashing fares Airlines
Ryanair gave a cautious outlook for the year ahead, saying profits would rise to between EUR1.4bn and 
EUR1.45bn, and warned about the risk of any negative Brexit developments or a repeat of last year's terrorist 
attacks.
It expected average fares for the full year to fall by between 5 and 7 per cent because of the weak pound and 
continuing excess capacity in Europe. That would be an improvement from a decline of 13 per cent last year. 
Ryanair expects to fly 130m passengers this year, a growth of 8 per cent, slower than the 13 per cent growth in 
2016-17.
Michael O'Leary , chief executive, said the airline was happy with its performance despite difficult trading 
conditions. "We reacted to these challenges by improving our customer experience, and stimulating growth with 
lower fares," he said.
The airline announced plans for a EUR600m share buyback to be completed by the end of October. Since 2008 
Ryan-air has returned about EUR5.4bn to investors through buybacks and special dividends.
Gerald Khoo, analyst at Liberum, said that while guidance for this year was a "touch light" of consensus, it was not 
enough to cause concern given Ryanair's record of conservative forecasts.
"Average fares are seen remaining under pressure, but less so than in 2017," he said.
See Lex
Load-Date: May 30, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair : restricted leg room
Ryanair: restricted leg room
Financial Times (London, England)
May 31, 2017 Wednesday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: LEX COLUMN; Pg. 10
Length: 394 words
Body
Michael O'Leary is a cheap guy, and he does not mind hearing that from others. Ryanair, the airline he runs, is built 
on keeping costs low and passing on savings in the form of lower fares.
Oddly, investors have to pay a high valuation to own Ryanair shares. The question is not whether the premium is 
deserved but whether the price can travel much higher.
Perennial cost-cutting has enabled Ryanair to squeeze out profits even when sales dip. Yesterday's full-year results 
provided evidence of this.
Revenues grew EUR22m less than expected, up by 2 per cent. Even so, net income grew. Better, earnings per 
share climbed 14 per cent. Share buybacks made the difference. The airline prefers this manner of returning money 
to its shareholders. It has bought back 22 per cent of its shares since 2008, at an average price of EUR8.50. That 
looks cheap compared with EUR18 today. Yet Ryanair has paid an increasingly high valuation for its own shares in 
the past couple of years.
Although it has committed to purchase a further EUR600m of stock this year, expect fewer buybacks in future if the 
shares stay dear.
They are starting to look that way. Consider ratios of price to earnings or enterprise value to earnings before 
interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation. On both measures the valuation is cruising near a five-year high. 
Relative to earnings the stock trades two-thirds higher than the MSCI European Airlines index. Only the shares of 
Ryanair : restricted leg room
Qantas and Aeroflot have outrun it in the past three years. Yet the carrier achieves its sector-leading operating 
profit margins of 23 per cent without the benefit of more lucrative long-haul routes.
Pricing, as Mr O'Leary will tell you, is all about what the market will bear. Ryanair expects fares to fall again this 
year, but will recover some of that via other charges. At 27 per cent of sales, ancillary revenues span everything 
from charging for seat reservations to booking hotels through Ryanair's website. The latter, the company gleefully 
reminds us, is a product of in-house IT efforts. British Airways has outsourced its to, let us say, mixed reviews. The 
plan is to lift these ancillary sales to 30 per cent. Mr O'Leary, like a famous showman before him, sees a silver lining 
in every crowd.
The market will want to see that coined into profit before paying even more for a ticket.
Twitter: @FTLex; Email: lex@ft.com 
Load-Date: May 30, 2017
End of Document
BA brand left stranded in zone of acute reputational risk Airlines: IT outage
BA brand left stranded in zone of acute reputational risk; Airlines: IT outage
Financial Times (London, England)
May 31, 2017 Wednesday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 14
Length: 745 words
Byline: Tanya Powley and Tobias Buck
Highlight: Pressure is on Cruz and the IAG parent to tackle problem of disintegrating goodwill
Body
British Airways chief executive Alex Cruz made his name in his native Spain, where he was largely seen to have 
done a good job at the country's low-cost carrier Vueling.
His time in the UK is not looking as promising as doubts intensify over his handling of BA's disastrous computer 
crash that stranded 75,000 passengers over the bank holiday weekend.
Aviation analysts believe the IT outage that led to a weekend of chaos that is expected to cost as much as 
EUR100m will put pressure on Mr Cruz and the management of International Airlines Group, parent of BA, to 
address deteriorating passenger views on BA.
"I think this will refocus management on how important BA is in the IAG Group," says Robin Byde, analyst at Cantor 
Fitzgerald. "They've had a lot going on in the last few years - acquiring Aer Lingus, improving Iberia - but BA is 
really the important part of the business."
Although investor reaction was relatively calm, with shares only slightly down, Mr Byde thinks management will 
"undoubtedly" have to revisit cost-cutting plans because of the reputational risk to BA's branding as a premium 
airline. IAG fell 1.38 per cent to 605.5p.
BA brand left stranded in zone of acute reputational risk Airlines: IT outage
Mr Cruz spent time at low-cost carrier Clickair and then, after the company's merger with rival Vueling, as head of 
the combined group.
The Basque father of four quickly gained a reputation for pushing aggressively into new markets and destinations, 
and for his evident determination to apply the lessons of low-cost carrier Ryanair to the staid Iberian market.
"Everyone thought he was excellent," says a consultant who worked with the airline industry at the time. "The big 
question was always whether he could lead a group as big as BA. The scale is totally different, and the business 
concept is different."
Whether Mr Cruz is the right man for the job has now come under scrutiny following last weekend's customer 
services disaster.
While he was largely seen to have done a good job during his time at Vueling, Mr Cruz's departure to BA last April 
came just before the Spanish low-cost carrier suffered huge operational problems in the summer.
"The summer operations meltdown at Vueling was due to over scheduling aircraft and leaving no slack for bad 
weather or events. French Air Traffic Control strikes then caused chaos which they seemed to struggle to recover 
from," says one city analyst.
Vueling went from being the favourite child in the IAG family with the highest margins in 2014, to the airline with the 
lowest margins last year.
As Mr Cruz was still chief executive of Vueling when the summer timetable was set, analysts point out he was 
responsible for growing the airline too "aggressively". "Mr Cruz got promoted out of trouble," says one City analyst, 
who wished to remain anonymous. Another adds: "Just as he moved over to BA, Vueling blew up last summer."
For this reason, Mr Cruz was the only one of 12 senior executives at IAG not to receive a bonus for 2016.
For now, it appears that Mr Cruz, who has refused to resign over the scandal , will be the man faced with the task of 
repairing the damage done to BA over the short term. A spokeswoman for IAG told the FT on Tuesday that Mr Cruz 
has the "full support" of IAG chief executive Willie Walsh , noting that Mr Cruz could not have prevented the IT 
glitch.
Several analysts agree that there is no need for heads to roll. "What's that going to solve? Is it actually going to 
make anything better to change the person at the top or would it be better to have the same person enforce change 
with the benefit of painful lessons?" says Gerald Khoo, analyst at Liberum.
Experts believe BA must explain the source of the power surge that the group says triggered the computer system 
failure, now that flights have returned to normal at Heathrow and Gatwick.
On Monday, Mr Cruz blamed the IT failure on an "exceptional" power surge, which he said had been so strong it 
also disabled the airline's back-up system.
The statement left many in the aviation and energy industry confused.
Electricity companies denied there were any issues with networks that serve Heathrow and the surrounding area. 
Ryanair revealed that it had several back-up systems in place to deal with any similar problems. "That's what most 
businesses would do. We take IT very seriously," says Kenny Jacobs, chief marketing officer at Ryanair.
"There is no doubt the incident is going to sharpen attention at BA on operational resilience," says Mr Khoo.
Additional reporting by Nathalie Thomas
ft.com/lombard

Folly of letting the austerity merchants call all the shots Opinion
Folly of letting the austerity merchants call all the shots; Opinion
Financial Times (London, England)
May 31, 2017 Wednesday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 14
Length: 541 words
Byline: Andrew Hill
Body
There are two types of redundancy. One involves laying off staff, the other laying on resources. The IT failures at 
British Airways have exposed a truth: airlines are far better at the first than at the second.
Willie Walsh and Alex Cruz are guilty of allowing that gap to widen. They are merchants of austerity. Their cost-
cutting backgrounds recommended them for their positions defending the British flag carrier's margins against low-
cost competition.
At roughly the same moment that low-cost airlines such as EasyJet and Ryanair realised they could add some 
passenger perks , BA set about trimming its frills. Better than any customer poll or staff engagement survey, the 
chaos has revealed how much goodwill the airline sacrificed in the process.
This is where having different types of people in the top jobs becomes important. Airlines are prone to more factors 
beyond their control than almost any other customer-centric business. Stuff happens, not just IT outages but 
storms, mechanical failures, terror threats, ash clouds, "involuntary denials of boarding" and, heaven forbid, 
accidents. Somebody needs to anchor the public response.
If you set aside Mr Cruz's natural reluctance not to submit to a public stoning before establishing the detail of what 
had happened, he said some of the right things in his direct-to-YouTube videos. In the first , which went online on 
Saturday, he said he was extremely sorry - always the right start - and promised to speed refunds to passengers. 
But his explanation of what went wrong was, and remains, hopelessly sketchy and his tone was unconvincing. What 
Folly of letting the austerity merchants call all the shots Opinion
is more, BA clearly lacked sufficient resources to recover from its IT outage and fulfil its passenger promises 
afterwards. In the latest video , Mr Cruz tells passengers whose luggage is still marooned somewhere in the BA 
system that "we have your bags and will look after them". His reassurance has all the cold conviction of a kidnapper 
submitting a ransom demand.
When Mr Cruz quits - and he will, maybe not this week or even this year, but quietly, at some future point when the 
outrage has died down - the airline should seriously reconsider the job specification for his replacement.
For years, bosses of the old flag-carrying airlines have been hired on the basis that "their whole life is about how to 
squeeze an extra mile out of a gallon of jet fuel". Of course, some of the hysteria about BA's failings is an over-
reaction. Security concerns and financial pressures have turned airports and air travel, even on a good day, into a 
barely tolerable experience. Passengers are quick to crack.
But precisely for that reason, airline chiefs need to have skills that go beyond a good eye for an uncontrolled 
overhead. They need to be able to connect with passengers. They need to be ready to handle emergencies with 
aplomb, conviction and empathy. Critically, they need to be prepared and have the resources available to swamp 
any problems with on-the-ground customer care and compensation.
BA could have cushioned itself from this crisis if it had benefited from a little more redundancy - the second, rather 
than the first type - and had hired a chief executive for customer-friendliness as much as for cost-effectiveness.
andrew.hill@ft.com 
Load-Date: May 30, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair Says Welcomes Ruling By Liverpool County Court Against 'claims Chasers'
Ryanair Says Welcomes Ruling By Liverpool County Court Against 'claims 
Chasers'
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
May 31, 2017 Wednesday 11:52 AM GMT
Copyright 2017 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 168 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Irish no-frills airline Ryanair Holdings Plc (RYA.L, RYAAY) Wednesday said it welcomed 
the Liverpool County Court ruling in the cases involving UK 'Claims Chasers'.   The ruling upheld Ryanair's policy 
requiring EU261 cases involving 'claims chasers' to be heard in the Irish Courts and dismissing an application by 
claims chasing firm Hughes Walker to have their cases heard in England in an effort to needlessly force more 
customers through the courts.  Ryanair calls on all customers with valid EU261 compensation claims to submit their 
claims directly to Ryanair and avoid these 'claims chaser' firms. Customers with valid claims, who claim directly 
from Ryanair, will receive 100% of their EU261 compensation entitlement without the deduction of these excessive 
'claims chaser' fees.  Ryanair again called on the Competition and Markets Authority or CMA to enforce better 
regulations of 'claims chasers' to protect consumers from being ripped off by these self-serving firms.

IT outage caused bank holiday chaos for passengers.
A power failure on Saturday resulted in mass flight cancellations across London Heathrow and Gatwick airports, 
causing chaos for 75,000 passengers. The trouble is expected to land the airline a sky-high bill. Blackstone 
declined to comment. Its shares closed down 1.38 per cent to 605.5p.
Ryanair also opened low, but later pared back most losses after announcing record income. Profits after tax rose 
six per cent to (EURO)1.31bn (£1.14bn). The airline reduced its prices by 13 per cent to an average of (EURO)41 
per fare.

BA debacle puts spotlight on airlines' old IT systems, cuts
BA debacle puts spotlight on airlines' old IT systems, cuts
Associated Press Financial Wire
May 30, 2017 Tuesday 3:53 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 586 words
Byline: By DANICA KIRKA, Associated Press
Dateline: LONDON 
Body
LONDON (AP) - The catastrophic IT failure at British Airways that ruined travel plans for 75,000 people has raised 
questions about some older airlines' focus on costs to the detriment of investment in new computer systems.
As British Airways resumed full service Tuesday, shares in its parent company, International Airlines Group, 
dropped 3 percent as investors appeared to worry that the company's quality of service may have been undermined 
by recent efforts to save money.
Disaster struck on Saturday, when the company's computer systems went down and there was no functioning back-
up. The airline cancelled all flights and only managed to resume full service on Tuesday.
"Although cost cutting has been good for the share price in the last year, it will come back to bite IAG if it stops 
them from doing what they are supposed to do: Fly passengers to their destinations," said Kathleen Brooks, the 
research director at City Index.
IAG has been battling tough competition, even as it has faced pressure on its earnings from a weaker pound 
following Britain's decision to leave the European Union. The company issued a profit warning following the Brexit 
vote nearly a year ago.
Cost pressures aggravated an already complicated situation. Renewing IT systems is complex, time-consuming 
and expensive - a factor that prompts many companies to put it off as long as possible, said Loizos Heracleous, a 
professor of strategy at Warwick Business School.
The problem with IT systems is recurring across the industry, particularly among established airlines. In August, 
Delta Air lines cancelled hundreds of flights when a power outage likewise knocked out its computer systems 
worldwide.
Airlines face challenges with their IT systems also due to linkages across their systems. There's further demand on 
the system when companies consolidate - as has been the case among airlines - since "IT issues get heightened 
and any vulnerabilities are exposed."
BA debacle puts spotlight on airlines' old IT systems, cuts
Such troubles give an advantage to newer airlines such as Ryanair, a cost-cutting BA rival that focuses on short 
haul budget flights.
"The ability to set up an airline from scratch by-passes a lot of the legacy issues, because you can go for state-of-
the-art systems," Heracleous said. "Newer airlines can also invest in IT systems that are more easily upgradeable 
and scaleable. An airline such as Ryanair, that is also financially successful, has more leeway to divert needed 
resources towards upgrading its IT systems."
Capitalizing on BA's troubles, Ryanair said it had seen "strong bookings" over the weekend. Its Twitter account 
rubbed salt into the wound with tweets that poked fun and added the hashtag "ShouldHaveFlownRyanair."
The company's chief marketing officer, Kenny Jacobs, admitted on the BBC "we had a bit of fun on social media."
"We don't take social media seriously but we do take IT very seriously and that is why we've never had an outage," 
he told the BBC.
Ryanair posted a 6 percent increase in annual profits Tuesday to 1.3 billion euros ($1.4 billion) despite "difficult 
trading conditions," caused by terror attacks in European cities and a sharp decline in the British pound.
BA, meanwhile, is counting up the cost of an IT debacle that some have estimated could run into the tens of 
millions. There are also all those news clips of passengers swearing they will never fly the airline again.
"The whole sorry episode has undeniably put a dent in BA's reputation for delivering a premium service," said 
George Salmon, equity analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown.
Load-Date: May 31, 2017
End of Document
LONDON MARKET EARLY CALL: Stocks To Give Back Gains After Long Weekend
LONDON MARKET EARLY CALL: Stocks To Give Back Gains After Long 
Weekend
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
May 30, 2017 Tuesday 2:10 AM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 554 words
Body
  London share prices are set to open lower on Tuesday, following a long weekend with a bank holiday in the UK, 
with the FTSE 100 index having closed at an all-time high on Friday. 
IG says futures indicate the FTSE 100 to open 12.63 points lower at 7,535.00. The blue-chip index closed on Friday 
up 0.4%, or 29.92 points, at 7,547.63. This was only a fraction off the new all-time high reached earlier in the day, 
helping the index to close the week 1.0% higher. 
The FTSE 100 was helped by a weak pound following disappointing UK GDP data, while better-than-expected GDP 
data from the US provided a boost to the dollar. 
The pound has recovered some ground since, having on Friday hit a low of USD1.2774, its lowest against the 
greenback since mid-April. The UK currency was standing at USD1.2816 early Tuesday, compared to USD1.2786 
at the London equities close on Friday. 
Wall Street also was closed on Monday for Memorial Day. On Friday, the DJIA and the the S&P 500 indices both 
ended flat, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.1%.
In Asia, the Shanghai equity market was closed on Monday and remains closed Tuesday for the Dragon Boat 
Festival in China. The Hong Kong market also was closed on Tuesday. 
The Tokyo market is open, with the Japanese Nikkei 225 index flat. 
In the economic calendar on Tuesday, French consumer spending, confidence and GDP is at 0745 BST, eurozone 
economic sentiment and business climate is at 1000 BST and the German consumer price index is at 1330 BST. 
US personal spending and income is at 1330 BST and the Redbook index is at 1355 BST.
In the UK corporate calendar, software firm Kainos Group, gene editor Horizon Discovery Group and chain, gears 
and couplings manufacturer Renold all post full-year reports. 
LONDON MARKET EARLY CALL: Stocks To Give Back Gains After Long Weekend
In early UK company news, Irish budget airline Ryanair Holdings reported profit attributable to shareholders of 
EUR1.32 billion, or 104.64 euro cents per share, for its financial year ended March 31, down from EUR1.56 billion, 
or 115.63 euro cents, in the prior year.
Excluding the exceptional gain of EUR317.5 million on the sale of Ryanair's Aer Lingus shareholding to 
International Consolidated Airlines Group SA in the prior year, financial 2017 profit after tax improved 6%, while 
earnings per share increased 14%.
Operating revenue from continuing operations was EUR6.65 billion, up 1.7% from EUR6.54 billion the previous 
year. Ryanair said the combination of a 13% cut in average fares, coupled with Year 3 of its "Always Getting Better" 
programme delivered 13% traffic growth to 120 million customers, and a load factor of 94%.
British Airways, part of IAG, was running around "95%" of flights to and from London's Heathrow and Gatwick 
airports on Monday following a weekend computer outage that grounded the company's aircraft at both hubs and 
caused delays worldwide.
"We are running at...just over 95% of the flights: That means...all long-haul flights in Heathrow...[and] just over 90% 
of the short-haul flights in Heathrow and all flights in Gatwick," BA chief executive Alex Cruz said in a video 
published on the company's Twitter feed.
He said that over 75,000 passengers had been affected by the weekend computer failure and that two-thirds of 
them would have reached their destinations by the end of Monday, which was a public holiday at the end of a long 
weekend in Britain.

European Shares Extend Declines For Fourth Consecutive Day
European Shares Extend Declines For Fourth Consecutive Day
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
May 30, 2017 Tuesday 5:26 AM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 303 words
Body
 European stocks extended declines for a fourth consecutive session on Tuesday as fresh political worries 
surrounding Britain, Italy and Greece sapped investors' appetite for risk and helped spur demand for safe-haven 
assets.
The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index was down 0.3% at 390.02 in late opening deals, extending losses for 
the fourth straight session.
The German DAX was down about 0.1% while France's CAC 40 index was losing as much as 0.8%.
The UK's FTSE 100 was down 0.3% as traders returned to their desks following a long holiday weekend.
Banks led losses after Deutsche Bank analysts cut their rating on regional banking stocks to "underweight". 
UniCredit, Commerzbank, Societe Generale and Barclays fell over 1% each.
International Consolidated Airlines Group lost almost 3% as British Airways grapples with a massive IT system 
failure over the weekend that led to hundreds of flights being cancelled.
Ryanair Holdings dropped 1.5%. The discount carrier said that the slump of the British currency after the Brexit vote 
will likely lead to a 5-7% decline in average ticket prices for the full financial year.
German luxury car maker BMW edged up marginally. The company has halted production of certain models this 
week because of a shortage of steering gears supplied by Robert Bosch.
In economic releases, French GDP grew 0.4% sequentially in the first quarter, slower than the 0.5% increase seen 
in the fourth quarter but a tad higher then the initial estimate of 0.3%, second estimate from the statistical office 
Insee showed.
A gauge of French consumer confidence strengthened in May to the highest level in nearly ten years, while 
consumer spending rose for the first time in three months in April.
European Shares Extend Declines For Fourth Consecutive Day
Economic sentiment and business confidence data from the euro area are slated for release later in the day.

TOP NEWS: Ryanair Annual Profit Rises 6% Excluding Aer Lingus Gain
TOP NEWS: Ryanair Annual Profit Rises 6% Excluding Aer Lingus Gain
MT Newswires Live Briefs PRO
May 30, 2017 Tuesday 1:52 AM EST
Copyright 2017 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 218 words
Body
 Irish budget airline Ryanair Holdings PLC reported on Tuesday profit attributable to shareholders of EUR1.32 
billion, or 104.64 euro cents per share, for its financial year ended March 31, down from EUR1.56 billion, or 115.63 
euro cents, in the prior year. 
Excluding the exceptional gain of EUR317.5 million on the sale of Ryanair's Aer Lingus shareholding to 
International Consolidated Airlines Group SA in the prior year, financial 2017 profit after tax improved 6%, while 
earnings per share increased 14%.
Operating revenue from continuing operations was EUR6.65 billion, up 1.7% from EUR6.54 billion the previous 
year. Ryanair said the combination of a 13% cut in average fares, coupled with Year 3 of its "Always Getting Better" 
programme delivered 13% traffic growth to 120 million customers, and a load factor of 94%.
Looking forward, Ryanair said, it is cautiously guiding an 8% increase in financial 2018 net profit to a range of 
EUR1.40 billion to EUR1.45 billion. It warned of the risk of negative Brexit developments, or any repeat of previous 
year's security events in European cities, which could damage consumer confidence.
Ryanair said its board has approved a further EUR600 million share buyback which will start current week and, 
subject to market conditions, be completed by the end of October.
