Stocks Remain Mostly Positive In Mid-Day Trading - U.S. Commentary
Stocks Remain Mostly Positive In Mid-Day Trading - U.S. Commentary
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
April 5, 2017 Wednesday 5:57 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 683 words
Body
       WASHINGTON (dpa-AFX) - After showing a strong move to the upside early in the session, stocks remain 
mostly positive in mid-day trading on Wednesday. With the upward move on the day, the tech-heavy Nasdaq 
reached a new record intraday high.  Currently, the major averages remain firmly positive but off their best levels of 
the day. The Dow is up 142.66 points or 0.7 percent at 20,831.90, the Nasdaq is up 27.34 points or 0.5 percent at 
5,925.94 and the S&P 500 is up 13.23 points or 0.6 percent at 2,373.39.  The strength on Wall Street comes 
following the release of a report from payroll processor ADP showing much stronger than expected private sector 
job growth in the month of March. 
 ADP said private sector employment soared by 263,000 jobs in March compared to economist estimates for an 
increase of about 187,000 jobs.  However, the report also said the jump in employment in February was 
downwardly revised to 245,000 jobs from the previously reported 298,000 jobs.  'Job growth is off to a strong start 
in 2017,' said Mark Zandi, chief economist of Moody's Analytics. 'The gains are broad based but most notable in the 
goods producing side of the economy including construction, manufacturing and mining.'  The release of the report 
from ADP comes two days before the release of the Labor Department's more closely watched monthly jobs report, 
which includes both public and private sector jobs.  The Labor Department report is expected to show an increase 
of about 180,000 jobs in March, while the unemployment rate is expected to hold at 4.7 percent.  Meanwhile, 
traders have largely shrugged off a separate report from the Institute for Supply Management showing that service 
sector growth slowed by more than expected in March.  The ISM said its non-manufacturing index dropped to 55.2 
in March from 57.6 in February, although a reading above 50 indicates continued growth in the service sector. 
Economists had expected the index to edged down to 57.0.  The bigger than expected pullback by the index came 
after it reached its highest level since October of 2015 in the previous month.  Later in the day, trading may be 
impacted by reaction to the minutes of the Federal Reserve's latest monetary policy meeting.  The Fed decided to 
raise interest rates by a quarter point at the meeting in mid-March, and traders are likely to analyze the minutes for 
clues about future rate hikes.  Sector News  Despite the upward move by the broader markets, many of the major 
sectors continue to show only modest moves on the day.  Airline stocks have shown a strong move to the upside, 
however, with the NYSE Arca Airline Index climbing by 1.3 percent. Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) and American 
Airlines (AAL) are turning in two of the sector's best performances.  Significant strength also remains visible among 
Stocks Remain Mostly Positive In Mid-Day Trading - U.S. Commentary
oil service stocks, although the Philadelphia Oil Service Index has pulled back well off its highs. After reaching its 
best intraday level in a month, the index is up by 1.3 percent.  The strength among oil service stocks comes as the 
price of crude oil has pulled back well off its best levels but is currently modestly higher.  Crude oil for May delivery 
is up $0.13 at $51.16 a barrel after climbing as high as $51.88 a barrel. The price of oil pulled back following the 
release of a report showing an unexpected weekly increase in crude oil inventories.  Other Markets  In overseas 
trading, stock markets across the Asia-Pacific region moved mostly higher during trading on Wednesday. Japan's 
Nikkei 225 Index rose by 0.3 percent, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index climbed by 0.6 percent.  Meanwhile, the 
major European markets turned in a mixed performance on the day. While the U.K.'s FTSE 100 Index inched up by 
0.1 percent, the French CAC 40 Index edged down by 0.2 percent and the German DAX Index fell by 0.5 percent.  
In the bond market, treasuries have climbed well off their worst levels but continue to see modest weakness. As a 
result, the yield on the benchmark ten-year note, which moves opposite of its price, is up by 1.4 basis points at 
2.364 percent.

Stocks Remain Mostly Positive In Mid-Day Trading - U.S. Commentary
Stocks Remain Mostly Positive In Mid-Day Trading - U.S. Commentary
RTT News (United States)
April 5, 2017 Wednesday
Copyright 2017 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 689 words
Body
(RTTNews) - After showing a strong move to the upside early in the session, stocks remain mostly positive in mid-
day trading on Wednesday. With the upward move on the day, the tech-heavy Nasdaq reached a new record 
intraday high.
Currently, the major averages remain firmly positive but off their best levels of the day. The Dow is up 142.66 points 
or 0.7 percent at 20,831.90, the Nasdaq is up 27.34 points or 0.5 percent at 5,925.94 and the S&P 500 is up 13.23 
points or 0.6 percent at 2,373.39.
The strength on Wall Street comes following the release of a report from payroll processor ADP showing much 
stronger than expected private sector job growth in the month of March.
ADP said private sector employment soared by 263,000 jobs in March compared to economist estimates for an 
increase of about 187,000 jobs.
However, the report also said the jump in employment in February was downwardly revised to 245,000 jobs from 
the previously reported 298,000 jobs.
"Job growth is off to a strong start in 2017," said Mark Zandi, chief economist of Moody's Analytics. "The gains are 
broad based but most notable in the goods producing side of the economy including construction, manufacturing 
and mining."
The release of the report from ADP comes two days before the release of the Labor Department's more closely 
watched monthly jobs report, which includes both public and private sector jobs.
The Labor Department report is expected to show an increase of about 180,000 jobs in March, while the 
unemployment rate is expected to hold at 4.7 percent.
Meanwhile, traders have largely shrugged off a separate report from the Institute for Supply Management showing 
that service sector growth slowed by more than expected in March.
The ISM said its non-manufacturing index dropped to 55.2 in March from 57.6 in February, although a reading 
above 50 indicates continued growth in the service sector. Economists had expected the index to edged down to 
57.0.
Stocks Remain Mostly Positive In Mid-Day Trading - U.S. Commentary
The bigger than expected pullback by the index came after it reached its highest level since October of 2015 in the 
previous month.
Later in the day, trading may be impacted by reaction to the minutes of the Federal Reserve's latest monetary 
policy meeting.
The Fed decided to raise interest rates by a quarter point at the meeting in mid-March, and traders are likely to 
analyze the minutes for clues about future rate hikes.
Sector News
Despite the upward move by the broader markets, many of the major sectors continue to show only modest moves 
on the day.
Airline stocks have shown a strong move to the upside, however, with the NYSE Arca Airline Index climbing by 1.3 
percent. Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) and American Airlines (AAL) are turning in two of the sector's best 
performances.
Significant strength also remains visible among oil service stocks, although the Philadelphia Oil Service Index has 
pulled back well off its highs. After reaching its best intraday level in a month, the index is up by 1.3 percent.
The strength among oil service stocks comes as the price of crude oil has pulled back well off its best levels but is 
currently modestly higher.
Crude oil for May delivery is up $0.13 at $51.16 a barrel after climbing as high as $51.88 a barrel. The price of oil 
pulled back following the release of a report showing an unexpected weekly increase in crude oil inventories.
Other Markets
In overseas trading, stock markets across the Asia-Pacific region moved mostly higher during trading on 
Wednesday. Japan's Nikkei 225 Index rose by 0.3 percent, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index climbed by 0.6 
percent.
Meanwhile, the major European markets turned in a mixed performance on the day. While the U.K.'s FTSE 100 
Index inched up by 0.1 percent, the French CAC 40 Index edged down by 0.2 percent and the German DAX Index 
fell by 0.5 percent.
In the bond market, treasuries have climbed well off their worst levels but continue to see modest weakness. As a 
result, the yield on the benchmark ten-year note, which moves opposite of its price, is up by 1.4 basis points at 
2.364 percent.
For comments and feedback: contact editorial@rttnews.com

Load-Date: April 5, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair launches new Glasgow Prestwick route to Rzeszow as part of winter 2017 schedule
Ryanair launches new Glasgow Prestwick route to Rzeszow as part of winter 
2017 schedule
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
April 5, 2017 Wednesday 12:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2017 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS; Food
Length: 386 words
Highlight: Ryanair has launched a new Glasgow Prestwick route to Rzeszow as part of its winter 2017 schedule, 
with a twice weekly service starting in October, which will help deliver over 675,000 customers p.a. at Glasgow 
Prestwick Airport.
Body
Ryanair&#39;s Glasgow Prestwick winter 2017 schedule will deliver: 1 new route to Rzeszow (2 x weekly); 10 
routes in total (including Alicante, Lanzarote & Tenerife) and Over 675,000 customers p.a. (+4%).This new Glasgow 
Prestwick route comes in the wake of the Scottish Finance Committee backing the Scottish Government&#39;s 
commitment to halve APD in Scotland. Ryanair again called on the Scottish Government to go even further and 
follow the Irish example by scrapping APD entirely to allow Scottish traffic, tourism and jobs to continue to grow and 
ensure Scottish airports can compete and attract more business.Ryanair&#39;s Robin Kiely said: "We are pleased 
to add a new Rzeszow route to our Glasgow Prestwick winter 2017 schedule, which will operate twice weekly from 
October. Our Glasgow Prestwick winter 2017 schedule also includes popular winter sun routes to Alicante, 
Lanzarote and Tenerife, with 10 routes in total, which will deliver over 675,000 customers p.a. at Glasgow Prestwick 
Airport.We welcome the Scottish Parliament Finance Committee&#39;s support for the Government&#39;s plan to 
halve APD, and we call on the Government to fully abolish APD, which would enable Ryanair to base more aircraft 
in Scotland, add even more routes and create thousands of jobs. 
Fares on our new Rzeszow route are on sale now from just GBP29.99 for travel in October and November, which 
are available on the Ryanair.com website until Thursday (6 Apr). Since these amazing low prices will be snapped 
up quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and book a low fare break from Glasgow Prestwick."Ron 
Smith, CEO of Glasgow Prestwick Airport, said: "We&#39;re delighted to be bringing back direct connections from 
Glasgow Prestwick Airport to Poland for winter 2017/18. We have a significant amount of experience in serving the 
passengers who would use this route to visit friends and family, for business travel or who are looking for a city 
break with a difference. This will be the only route available in Scotland over the winter months to South East 
Poland. Our excellent transport connections including direct motorway access, low cost car parking and rail access 
Ryanair launches new Glasgow Prestwick route to Rzeszow as part of winter 2017 schedule
straight to the terminal building make our airport, and this route, an affordable, convenient and enjoyable way to 
experience Eastern Europe."

Why David Robinson has the luck of the Irish
Why David Robinson has the luck of the Irish
Citywire
April 5, 2017 Wednesday 8:01 AM GMT
Copyright 2017 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 960 words
Byline: Dalvinder Kular
Highlight: Citywire AAA-rated manager reveals the domestic success story taking off.
Body
The fourth largest country exposure in David Robinson’s Melchior European Opportunities  fund is Ireland at 10.1%. 
His Irish holdings were hit hard after Britain voted to leave the European Union, as the UK is Ireland’s biggest 
trading partner.
‘Clearly if the UK sneezes, Ireland catches a chill. But I felt at the time that the market reaction to a number of 
stocks in Ireland was overdone because there is quite a strong internal dynamic in Ireland. We estimate that for 
every 1% reduction of UK GDP it would knock off 0.3% in Ireland,’ the AAA-rated manager says.
‘Not insignificant, but manageable in the context of an economy that is growing at 4-5%. We thought that was an 
opportunity, and, certainly in the period since Brexit, the Irish economy has continued to grow and the fundamentals 
still look fairly robust.’
Robinson says his interest in the country is down to the many good companies located there, which dovetail with 
his bottomup strategy. In addition, its low taxes, pro-business environment and young English-speaking population 
has attracted global household names such as Google.
‘We have overweighted the Irish market for a number of years and during that period, the country has generated the 
best economic growth in Europe. Ireland embraced reform fairly early as it was hit very badly in the downturn.
‘It went through a period of reorganisation and deflation and has emerged as more competitive. It is an open 
economy that has really benefited by being an attractive destination for foreign investment,’ he says.
Flying ahead
Robinson says there are many good companies in Ireland that are doing better than their competitors. Strong 
management ensures that they grow and generate profit. He highlights budget airline Ryanair as an example of a 
domestic success story.
‘It is a very well-managed airline. If you take out fuel, its operating costs are 50% below EasyJet. What that means 
is that no one can come close to it in terms of pricing and yield – it is able to offer cheaper fares and make a better 
Why David Robinson has the luck of the Irish
return. Ryanair can continue to grow market share in the European short-haul market by generating a huge amount 
of cash,’ he says.
However, Robinson hasn’t dropped his guard completely. Ireland’s GDP fell by around 18% in the wake of the 2008 
financial crisis and while it is recovering well, and the manager is still cautious despite seeing signs of recovery, 
particularly with companies focused on the country itself.
‘Irish GDP has recovered along with investment, but consumer confidence and consumption has only really 
improved in the last 18 months. You now have a situation where unemployment is falling, wages are rising, and 
income taxes are reducing as the government refines its approach.
‘There are a number of favourable dynamics. However, a lot of the domestic parts of the economy have not 
recovered yet, so we remain positive on Ireland and towards companies that are exposed to construction and 
consumption generally.’
European outlook
Away from Ireland, France is the second-largest exposure in the fund at 13.1%. In contrast to his counterparts in 
European equities, Robinson is underweight Germany and Switzerland. The manager stresses that this is part of 
his bottom-up stock selection method.
The fund has a 10.5% allocation to Germany, compared with the MSCI Europe benchmark of 14.7%, along with just 
6.4% in Switzerland compared with the benchmark’s 13.7%.
‘Our current underweight on Germany and Switzerland is not really a call on those markets, it just happens to reflect 
the opportunities at the moment. Nevertheless, there are some outstanding German companies which meet our 
criteria.
‘Equally, there are some amazing businesses in Switzerland but the market has been dominated by some big 
defensive businesses like healthcare and we happen to be underweight that sector,’ he says.
Robinson has only 8.6% of the fund focused on the healthcare sector, compared with the benchmark’s 12.8% and 
again stresses that his bottom-up stock selection method means he does not place sector bets.
Odds on volatility
Political events can move markets, but Robinson believes their effect is over blown. The manager is not betting on 
certain countries or sectors for upcoming European elections.
‘Politics can be unpredictable but its impact on the economy can be hard to gauge. It is too early to say what the 
impact of Brexit will be on the UK, but there is no doubt that so far its economy has held up remarkably well, better 
than virtually every economist would have had you believe.’
He adds that the sell-off in the market as a result of the US presidential election only lasted a few hours before it 
reverted to normal. He doubts that right wing candidate Marine Le Pen will win the French elections due to the 
structure of the country’s voting system. But he does think her victory would cause the most chaos of all the 
upcoming elections.
‘I’m not going to make political risk and political events central to my portfolio construction in 2017. But I am mindful 
of risk, and Europe’s big election schedule ahead.
‘Over the last eight or nine years a huge amount has happened economically, politically and financially and in ways 
that most people wouldn’t have predicted. As an investor there is always a temptation to look through the crystal 
ball but the world is inherently unpredictable, it always has been,’ he says.
Why David Robinson has the luck of the Irish
‘One thing I have learnt as an investor is one should be reasonable, humble and aware of the limitations of trying to 
predict what is going to happen. However, at the same time you should recognise that good well-managed 
businesses can cope with different environments. Capitalism is quite flexible – businesses do adjust.’
This article originally appeared in the February edition of Citywire Selector magazine.
Load-Date: April 5, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair expands into the mainstream But low-cost carrier's increasing use of primary airports does not signal 
an end to strategy of growth at secondary sites
Ryanair expands into the mainstream; But low-cost carrier's increasing use 
of primary airports does not signal an end to strategy of growth at 
secondary sites
Flight International
April 4, 2017
Copyright 2017 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS FOCUS
Length: 579 words
Body
Ryanair on 28 March made its most eye-catching move yet into more mainstream markets, starting to operate at 
Lufthansa’s Frankfurt fortress – but its interest in bigger hubs does not necessarily signal that it is turning its back 
on secondary airports.
London Stansted and Dublin may be its biggest airports, but FlightGlobal schedules data for March shows 
Bergamo’s Orio al Serio – sometimes called Milan’s third airport – is Ryanair’s third biggest in terms of seat 
capacity.
Bergamo, northeast of Milan, was Ryanair’s first Italian base when it was established in 2003, and the Irish carrier’s 
third in continental Europe after Hahn and Charleroi. All three symbolised not just Ryanair’s pan-European 
ambitions, but its model of serving big cities through out-of-town airports: Charleroi for Brussels and Hahn for 
Frankfurt.
Ryanair’s launch of services this summer from Frankfurt Main airport means it now serves primary airports in all 
three of those cities. But in each case, its still has a larger operation at the alternative airport than the primary one, 
and not just because it has been active at these airports for longer.
Bergamo illustrates this. Ryanair began serving Milan Malpensa in December 2015, and quickly grew to serve nine 
destinations from the airport. FlightGlobal schedules data shows it will offer 800,000 seats from Malpensa this year. 
But growth at Bergamo continued at the same time. After a hiatus in aircraft deliveries, expansion at the airport 
resumed when Ryanair’s new batch of 737-800s started arriving in late 2014. It will offer nearly 5.8 million seats 
from Bergamo across 2017, FlightGlobal schedules show – an increase of almost a million from two years ago.
Although Ryanair’s growth at Charleroi has been outstripped by its expansion at Brussels’ primary airport since 
2014, the former is still clearly the larger operation: in 2017 the carrier will offer respective totals of 3.5 million and 
1.6 million seats, FlightGlobal schedules data shows.
Ryanair expands into the mainstream But low-cost carrier's increasing use of primary airports does not signal 
an end to strategy of growth at secondary sites
It is too early to say what the launch of operations out of Frankfurt Main may mean for Ryanair’s Hahn operations. 
While it has been growing its German presence, it has halved seat capacity at Hahn since 2010, making cuts in 
2011 after implementation of a German aviation tax.
spreading network
Ryanair last year disclosed plans for a base at Frankfurt’s primary airport, initially with leisure routes. It will expand 
its operation this winter by basing seven aircraft at the hub and spreading the network to 20 destinations, including 
five in Italy and seven in Spain and the Canary Islands.
“I would have said Frankfurt Main was the next airport [after Heathrow and Paris Charles de Gaulle] where we 
would never have a base, yet we are opening a base there,” Ryanair chief executive Michael O’Leary told 
FlightGlobal earlier this year. “They have room, no slot constraints, and they’ve come up with an incentive 
programme for low-cost carriers because they want a low-cost business at Frankfurt Main.”
Where Ryanair serves two airports from the same city, excluding London, it tends to have a distinct route strategy 
for each. For example, its flights from Rome’s secondary Ciampino airport have focussed on northern European 
routes, while its operation at the Italian capital’s main international gateway, Fiumicino, largely serves domestic and 
southern European leisure destinations.
Irish airline has received an average of 25 737-800s every year since taking its first delivery in 1999
Boeing
Load-Date: April 6, 2017
End of Document

Soaring fleet size explains why it is not a question of either/or
Soaring fleet size explains why it is not a question of either/or
Flight International
April 4, 2017
Copyright 2017 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS FOCUS
Length: 156 words
Body
On 21 March Ryanair hit yet another milestone in its relationship with the Boeing 737-800, with the Irish low-cost 
carrier taking delivery of its 450th example.
That figure has been reached in less than two decades, the airline having taken an average of 25 of the Boeing 
narrowbodies each year since 1999.
Ryanair has operated an all-Boeing fleet since 1994 and its current outstanding orders for 80 737-800s and 100 
Max 200s will allow it to increase its fleet to 585 aircraft by 2024, it says.
To reach that total, it will have grown its 737-800 fleet by 42 to 383 aircraft over the course of its financial year 
ending 31 March, and will add 44 aircraft in its 2018 financial year. It is this impressive rate of expansion that is the 
backdrop to all of Ryanair’s capacity and network decisions over the past couple of years – and for the foreseeable 
future.
As a result, it is not necessarily facing either/or decisions on where to grow.
Load-Date: April 6, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair March passenger traffic up 10%
Ryanair March passenger traffic up 10%
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
April 4, 2017 Tuesday 12:00 AM GMT

Length: 98 words
Highlight: Ryanair Ltd. has reported that passenger traffic for the month of March 2017 was 9.4 million, an 
increase of 10%, compared to 8.5 million for March 2016.
Body
Load Factor for the month of March 2017 was 94% compared to 94% for March 2016.Ryanair&#39;s Kenny Jacobs 
said: "Ryanair&#39;s March traffic grew by 10% to 9.4m customers, while our load factor was unchanged (despite 
the absence of Easter) from last year at 94%, on the back of lower fares and the continuing success of our "Always 
Getting Better" customer experience programme. Our rolling annual traffic reached 120m. March traffic was also 
impacted by the cancellation of over 530 flights due to repeated ATC and some handling strikes, which cut our 
traffic by approx. 100,000 customers."

Irish business dynasties: Taking stock of success
Irish business dynasties: Taking stock of success
Sunday Business Post
April 3, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1644 words
Byline: Michael Murray
Highlight: Several Irish stock market companies are global leaders. But their success has been overshadowed by 
the decline of the banking sector and the indifferent performance of companies led by family dynasties
Body
It is easy to lose perspective when corporations that are demonstrably Irish in brand and in market position – and 
that were once perceived as bluechips – come crumbling down.
But in a small country, the risks of corporate governance being weak, perspectives being inward looking, and 
nepotism or small-mindedness being prevalent are high. That, however, shouldn’t cloud the extraordinary success 
of some of our stock market-listed companies that are European or world leaders in their sector, and headquartered 
in, run and led from Ireland.
Yes, our entire banking sector, which once dominated the Iseq, saw over 90 per cent of its value wiped out. The 
fact that the most exalted of them, Anglo Irish, became the most disgraced undermined confidence in our system of 
corporate governance.
And yes, a seemingly iconic family empire - as personified by bits of the O’Reilly clan - fell to the ground, as 
Waterford Wedgwood, whose brand was once renowned worldwide, went bust, and the same family member-led 
Independent News & Media empire was reduced to ‘penny share’ status.
The top class public relations machine that was at the disposal of O’Reilly kept the image so well polished for so 
long that when the outposts collapsed or were acquired for cents confidence in Irish corporate/family business 
dynasties took a hit.
Several of the non-family led companies that were relatively low key in their public relations and personalised image 
management could afford to let their numbers speak for themselves having come through the past 40 years to 
positions of European, and in some cases world, leadership in their chosen industries or niches.
I count six Irish-listed companies in this category. Several more are demonstrating their potential to progressively 
move into it.
Irish business dynasties: Taking stock of success
Perhaps the most remarkable success story – because it was achieved from a later starting point than all of the 
others – has been one that probably every reader has been a customer of over the year, Ryanair.
Starting with the initial step by the late Tony Ryan of a single route from Waterford to London in 1984, the low-cost 
carrier commenced operations under the Ryanair brand in 1985.
Within a decade it was carrying 2.25 million passengers per annum. But since the deregulation of the airline 
industry in 1997, the company has gone from strength to strength.
It now serves 34 countries across Europe, Africa and the Middle East, and is by far the biggest low-fares pan-
European airline, outstripping all of its quoted rivals.
Today, despite being 60 years younger, in stock market value terms Ryanair is 1.5 times bigger than the 
International Consolidated Airlines Group, the global operator that took over the sleepy and sclerotic Aer Lingus.
As to its size relative to the other quoted low-cost European airlines - Easyjet and Wizair – Ryanair’s market 
capitalisation of €17.6 billion is nine times greater than that of Wizair and nearly four times more valuable than 
Easyjet.
This is a fantastic example as to how a no-nonsense leadership team – Tony Ryan followed by Michael O’Leary – 
have built up a world class business with clear market leadership over all of its rivals from a standing start of 
nothing three decades ago.
The good news is that despite appearances perhaps to the contrary, Ryanair is no one-man band.
O’Leary will be a loss when he comes to step down from the top job, but he has in Neil Sorohan as chief financial 
officer who appears cut from the same cloth as himself. And if you watch their investor relations presentations 
together you will see exactly what I mean.
A second major success story has been our native gambling business Paddy Power, founded back in 1988 through 
the merger of 40 bookies shops. It has now, with the takeover of Betfair, risen to a position where its market value 
at €8.4 billion is almost double the combined market values of Britain’s two long-established publicly quoted 
bookies, Ladbrokes and William Hill.
Its innovative, imaginative and provocative advertising, its expansion from conventional betting on horses and 
sports through bookies shops and on course to broadened betting choices and channels – with online sports 
betting, as well as online bingo, poker, casino games and spread betting having combined to make the company 
what it is today - 20 times more valuable than what it was a decade and a half ago.
Its provocative advertising and the controversy it sometimes created has also been an economic way of getting a 
huge marketing ‘bang’ for its ‘buck’:
The recent death of Bishop Eamon Casey reminds me of Paddy Power’s well-publicised decision many years ago 
to pull a proposed advertisement captioned “Paddy Power: The Father of All Bookies’’ at the time of the 
announcement of the birth of the now late Bishop’s child!
The publication of the decision to pull the advertisement was in itself a free brand builder for the company, while at 
the same time pleasing the remaining Catholic congregations who are not all averse to the odd flutter - or sexual 
misdemeanour.
But in a global sense, perhaps the two most spectacular successes of our indigenous headquartered companies 
have been the Tralee-based Kerry Group and Cavan-based Kingspan. Over 30 years, Kerry Group has gone from 
local cooperative to a global leader in ingredients and flavours.
Irish business dynasties: Taking stock of success
Now with a market capitalisation of over €13 billion, the company has no peer in Europe in terms of the scale and 
breadth of its ingredient and flavour offerings and this business now dwarfs the company’s more conventional food 
business.
Operational excellence, a healthy, focused and well embedded corporate culture, strong strategic management, 
focus on the value of science and innovation, top class professional, scientific and other graduate recruitment and 
development programmes and world class expertise in acquisitions have combined to propel the ingredient and 
flavours group to the global market leadership position it enjoys today in terms of its scale, scope and reach.
In building products, Kingspan – in its specialist insulation boards and panels - is a global leader with a market 
presence spanning the US and Canada, Latin America, Europe, the Indian Ocean, Turkey, the Middle East, South 
and Central Asia, Australasia, the Far East and Africa.
In that sense, this Cavan-headquartered company is undoubtedly the most global of our plcs and has played with 
great success into the modern insulation opportunities presented by regulatory requirements for insulation and 
other aspects of building specification and design.
Although its market value is just over €5 billion, it has increased more than fourfold over the past five years and 
looks well set for further advance as regulatory trends offer good structural growth opportunities in many of its 
markets.
While CRH’s presence is less global than Kingspan’s, its scale and diversity in aggregates and building materials 
and depth and presence across the United States and Europe gives it a stock market value of €27 billion, making it 
double the size in value terms of any other indigenous Irish-listed industrial company.
Meanwhile, our banks - once the biggest companies on the Irish market – have been demoted to ‘penny share’ 
status (AIB is listed with a similar market capitalisation to CRH, but 99 per cent of that is capital injected by the 
taxpayer under duress to keep it afloat).
Aside from that, all of our major banks – before the financial crisis – had disastrous acquisition forays which 
destroyed shareholder value, especially in the United States.
Although a dull and boring business, I cannot leave out the best performing share in my portfolio DCC, now a clear 
leader in energy distribution across Europe with its share price rising more than fourfold over the past five years.
Apart from a combination of operational excellence, outstanding management, well chosen niches and a disciplined 
approach to achieving returns on capital employed, what CRH, DCC, Kingspan and Kerry Group all have in 
common is their deep due diligence processes prior to what have been serially successful acquisitions.
They seek to ensure they do not overpay, and that they can extract costs and boost operating efficiencies and 
synergies, and do not compromise their return on capital criteria.
Virtually all of their acquisitions have been value accretive over the medium term and well integrated to generate 
the necessary savings and cross sales opportunities.
By contrast, our banking sector - when in acquisition mode – failed more often than it succeeded and has since 
disposed of almost everything it ever acquired – Maryland, Citizens Bank, Bristol & West and more.
The good news is that - banking aside – below our tier of acquisitive leaders are rapidly growing smaller players 
who look to have real promise given their success with bolt-on acquisitions to date.
The two in my own portfolio include UDG Healthcare, which has transitioned from an almost sole focus on 
distribution to higher value added healthcare support and services businesses whose structural growth 
characteristics are strong. UDG’s share price has more than quadrupled since it departed from its “distribution only” 
platform.
Irish business dynasties: Taking stock of success
The other, Greencore, with its focus on food-to-go and acquisition programme, has shown good results to date, 
albeit with the jury remaining out on the recent acquisition of Peacock Foods in the US and the impact of Brexit on 
its British supply chain and labour market.
Other businesses I am keeping my eye on for possible future investment are the Dermot Desmond-led Datalex and 
Northern Ireland’s First Derivatives – topics to return to.
Meanwhile, we can count ourselves lucky to have so many opportunities to invest in Irish-headquartered companies 
with the depth of expertise, proven track records and robust business models that have propelled such tremendous 
growth in the past and look well set to do so into the future.
Load-Date: April 3, 2017

The week in business
The week in business
Sunday Business Post
April 3, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1034 words
Byline: Róisín Burke
Highlight: A look behind the stories with Róisín Burke
Body
Our Cheltenham pundits and Boylesports gallop home with two grand for charity 
It was hard to make money at this year’s Cheltenham Festival, developer and shrewd judge of horseflesh Michael 
O’Flynn tells me.
Thankfully, the link up between The Sunday Business Post and Boylesports for our annual charity betting proved 
successful.
O’Flynn played a big role – his tip galloped strongly to victory in the Mares Novices’ Hurdle. Let’s Dance gave Willie 
Mullins and Ruby Walsh an incredible fourth win on that one day, and gave us a €200 win for charity.
[caption id="attachment_383004" align="alignnone" width="300"] Michael O’Flynn[/caption]
But our biggest win came from James Osborne’s selection. The Ryanair director backed Cheltenham Gold Cup 
victor Sizing John, landing us €900 in the process.
Trained by veteran Cheltenham winner Jessica Harrington, who boasts names like Moscow Flyer, Jezki and Space 
Trucker to her credit, Osborne rightly bet that Sizing John would match his Lexus Chase Leopardstown win.
To sweeten our winnings pot a little more, Boylesports is not only giving a money back guarantee on each winning 
€100 stake, it is also generously paying out on an each way basis as well.
That means that Cardinal Capital co-founder Nigel McDermott’s pick, Petit Mouchoir – a horse from Michael 
O’Leary’s Gigginstown stables that placed third in the Champion Hurdle – has raked us in a stonking €700 for our 
charity punt.
[caption id="attachment_383003" align="alignnone" width="300"] James Osborne[/caption]
The week in business
And former Kerry Group boss and Horse Racing Ireland chairman Denis Brosnan, who named the heavily backed 
Unowhatimeanharry in the Stayers’ Hurdle (which came third) made €190 for us.
So, totting up and rounding up a little we’re at €2,000, and Boylesports will write a big cheque for the Peter McVerry 
Trust, the charity helping to tackle homelessness.
Other big names who kindly saddled up to give us their favourites ahead of Cheltenham were PayPal boss Louise 
Phelan, Minister for Social Protection Leo Varadkar, H&K International founder and racehorse owner David 
Bobbett, Glanbia chief Siobhan Talbot, One51 boss Alan Walsh, Tammy O’Brien of Tattersalls, and Boylesports 
founder John Boyle. Many thanks to one and all.
 Dermot Desmond racks up another honour 
I hear that congratulations are in order for billionaire Dermot Desmond, who is due to add yet another gong to his 
collection.
He’s among those to be awarded by Michigan State University later this year with an honorary Doctorate of 
Humanities, along with former baseball star Kirk Gibson and Ford Foundation president Darren Walker.
The university has partnered with Respect, the disabilities charity that Desmond has chaired since 1995, on 
research to improve the understanding of intellectual disability and autism.
Desmond has received honours in the past from Trinity College, University College Dublin, Queen’s University and 
the University of Massachusetts Medical School.
 Johnny Ronan’s mighty wind investment 
[caption id="attachment_383005" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] The Village at Lyons: reduced losses[/caption]
Now that energy minister Denis Naughten has promised to introduce a price subsidy for offshore wind farms, 
among the many developers who will be rubbing their hands is one Johnny Ronan, better known for property than 
tilting at windmills.
JR and family are shareholders in Hazelshore Ltd, which is in turn a shareholder in Codling Holdings, a joint venture 
with Norwegian utility Fred Olsen.
The Codling Wind Park has an estimated value of €3 billion, meaning that the Hazelshore stake could be worth a 
pretty penny to Ronan and other shareholders, which include the former top civil servant Paddy Teahon and 
Ronan’s one-time development partner in Treasury Holdings, Richard Barrett.
As recently as last year, the company seemed to have given up the ghost on Codling in the absence of a subsidy.
But a filing on the lobbying database shows that the lads weren’t sitting back. None other than former Fine Gael 
hotshot Frank Flannery was talking to former energy minister Pat Rabbitte about the project on behalf of 
Hazelshore (which used a Ronan Group Real Estate email for the filing) in late 2015. All that work may now set free 
a cash windfall, it seems.
 HWBC Six Nations pundit glory goes to Finance Ireland 
As memory fades of last weekend’s win over England, bragging rights in property agency HWBC’s Six Nations 
Armchair Pundit competition are still being argued over.
High rankers included CHQ boss Mervyn Greene, Tilman Brewin Dolphin stock picker Ray Tilson, and Green Reit’s 
director of asset management Ronan Webster.
The overall winner, from among more than 200 participants, was David Gavin from Billy Kane’s Finance Ireland 
Group, who will enjoy a luxury weekend away in London.
The week in business
While we are too kind to name the bottom performers, it would be fair to say that those in the more ‘Italian-
flavoured’ end of the league table included TWM director Sean O’Neill, and Ocean Capital’s Paul McGowan.
 O’Callaghan’s Lyons lessens losses 
In the year prior to its being taken over by education entrepreneur and hotel owner Barry O’Callaghan, the Village at 
Lyons substantially reduced its losses, new filings show.
Formerly owned by aviation legend Tony Ryan’s family, the 16-acre Kildare resort estate sold for around €6 million 
to Arkle Ltd last year. Ryan’s son Declan was owed €3.38 million, the accounts say. A further €1.3 million due to 
Ryan in relation to a property lease was written off after the sale, and the Ryan family were owed a further €3.13 
million, which was also written off.
Renamed the Cliff at Lyons as a companion property to O’Callaghan’s Cliff Hotel in Waterford and Cliff Townhouse 
in Dublin, losses stood at €2.8 million in accounts signed off at the end of 2016, down from €7.4 million the previous 
year.
 Tweete of the week 
“The presumption that it is a competition between London and another European centre has a degree of naivety. It’ll 
be between London and New York.”
Richie Boucher of Bank of Ireland gives a rather interesting ‘Brexit bounce’ view to the Financial Times

A very senior figure at RTÉ considered resigning over the way forward on cost- cutting

Murphy’s Monex pays out €9m dividends and sets IPO timeline
Murphy’s Monex pays out €9m dividends and sets IPO timeline
Sunday Business Post
April 3, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 285 words
Byline: Róisín Burke
Highlight: Founder Frank Murphy says stock market float is being explored in next two years
Body
Shareholders of Monex, the Kerry financial technology company specialising in currency conversion, received over 
€9 million in dividends, new filings show.
Founder Frank Murphy said a New York or Ireland stock market float in the next two years was being explored 
following a set of bumper financial results.
New market territory expansion will continue at the company, which exceeded €100 million turnover for the first time 
over 2016, he said.
Fresh company filings show that Monex’s two shareholders, Murphy and chief operations officer Michael Crowley, 
shared €9.32 million in dividends.
Profits after tax came to €7.42 million in 2016, up from €5.66 million the previous year. Turnover increased to €108 
million from €99 million.
“A flotation is absolutely something we will look at in either New York or Ireland in the coming two years,” Murphy 
said. “The figures were so strong we said we’d need to look at it.
“We have been approached [by prospective advisers] and there have been discussions but there is nothing specific 
yet.
“But we are keeping an open mind with bankers and advisers. For now, we’ll keep doing what we’re doing.
“There will be significant new investment in new markets announced during the year and we expect things to be 
strong on that front as well,” Murphy said.
“With profits being so good, we’re going to continue with a strong pipeline.”
Murphy’s Monex pays out €9m dividends and sets IPO timeline
Monex runs the software behind Ryanair’s secure booking system and will partner with more blue chip names in 
coming months, he said.
The business will continue to invest in research and development, particularly in its digital wallet innovation, he said.
Monex provides a rapid currency exchange service in 48 countries worldwide at more than 68,000 ATMs.
Load-Date: April 3, 2017
End of Document
Shaking up the fintech sector
Shaking up the fintech sector
Sunday Business Post
April 3, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 455 words
Byline: Post Reporter
Body
Due to come in next year, PSD2 will bring significant changes to the financial market.
It will allow consumers and businesses to use third-party services to help manage their finances and will see banks 
compete against anyone offering financial services. The regulations will also help improve customer protection and 
data security.
It will introduce two new types of providers. One is AISP (Account Information Service Provider), which provides 
access to bank customers’ account information, while the other is a PISP (Payment Initiation Service Provider) who 
carries out the payment on behalf of the user.
Instead of using traditional banks, the next few years could see you using a specific app or service to pay for goods 
or services or send money to other contacts while still using your bank account. For banks, it means they will be 
obliged to offer these third parties access to their customer accounts through open APIs (Application Program 
Interface).
Among the organisations we spoke to, the attitude is very positive, although there is a healthy degree of caution. 
For Paul Prior, chief innovation officer of FTI Consulting, the risk isn’t just understanding the regulations, but the 
customer as well.
“There is a willingness, particularly in the banking sector, to work with fintech industries, but there is a level of risk 
adversity in terms of ‘Will they understand the customer in five or ten years?’
“The emotional journey point is a really interesting one . . . you think about someone’s journey with car insurance, a 
lot of insurers think it starts when they type in ‘car insurance’ into Google. It’s not. It’s the point where they’re 16 and 
getting their driver’s licence.
“What we find with the clients we work with is they’re starting earlier when identifying the customer experience and 
[looking more at] how they follow up.”
Shaking up the fintech sector
The new regulations offer interesting possibilities, according to Oliver Lynch, business development director of 
Comtrade Digital Services.
“What we think is interesting is you could have other brands that are non-banking brands, say Aer Lingus or 
Ryanair, they decide ‘Okay, listen let’s cut out credit card processing fees’ and reduce them greatly,” he said.
“Companies who have massive brand trust and equity already will be able to be active in the payment processing 
area and greatly reduce the costs of payment processing for their clients.”
Dominic Conlon, the head of corporate at Leman Solicitors, Ireland, believes that all parties – banks, financial 
institutions, fintech companies and customers – will benefit going forward.
“Most companies in the B2C fintech space welcome sensible regulation because it gives a sense of comfort for 
consumers who can say ‘My money is safe’,” he said.
Load-Date: April 3, 2017
End of Document
Mixing bluechips with younger company shares
Mixing bluechips with younger company shares
Sunday Business Post
April 3, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 1473 words
Byline: Michael Murray
Highlight: The banking crisis proved that bluechip status is not eternal, but mixing bluechips shares with those of 
well-managed companies is a good way of combining relative security with long-term growth
Body
The word bluechip derives from poker but, according to Wikipedia, a bluechip is a “corporation with a national 
reputation for quality, reliability, and the ability to operate profitably in good times and bad”.
The term bluechip, as defined and attributed to a company, does not mean that it can do no wrong – or even that it 
cannot fail.
Back in the 1990s, AIB and Bank of Ireland were two of Ireland’s top five bluechips by virtue of their scale, financial 
strength, market leadership in their core market, and pricing power in at least some of the banking segments in 
which they operated. So also were the two main Scottish banks in Britain – Bank of Scotland and Royal Bank of 
Scotland (RBS).
But all of these institutions’ bluechip characteristics were not just chipped away, they were destroyed with the onset 
of the banking crisis. They have continued to struggle for worthwhile profitability and capital generation that would 
help to restore dividend flows. So life in the bluechip lane is not eternal.
Ireland as a country can still be proud of the many bluechip companies we do have: CRH in building materials, 
Kerry Group in food ingredients, Ryanair in air travel. All three are market leaders in their field, all three have robust 
balance sheets and cashflows, all three have multinational exposure, and all three have significant sources of 
competitive advantage.
While Ryanair’s brand might not conjure up a bluechip image, the image has – or should have – nothing to do with 
it. It is a market leader in the low-cost air travel industry, it has a balance sheet of unrivalled strength, it has 
operating margins of unrivalled sectoral scale, its brand is associated with efficiency and value, and through share 
buybacks and special dividends, it has returned €2.4 billion to shareholders over the past eight years. That’s why it 
is certainly an excellent fit in the bluechip tent and from the track record to date, shareholders have the confidence 
Mixing bluechips with younger company shares
that Michael O’Leary and his board will not misallocate surplus capital, but return it to shareholders in the absence 
of value-adding opportunities to deploy it in the business.
Achieving and maintaining bluechip status doesn’t necessarily mean delivering sustained earnings growth. It does, 
however, mean being proven capable of delivering sustained dividends through good industry cycles – and bad.
That is why Smurfit, for example, although a leader in its sector, doesn’t qualify for the bluechip badge. It had to 
suspend its dividend payments from 2008 to 2011 due to the cyclical downturn in the market. By contrast, CRH 
continued paying its generous dividend (albeit with no growth) through the vicious downturn in the construction 
industry that paralleled the banking crisis, and has now begun to grow it again.
Shareholders have been rewarded for their patience. Kerry Group, a world leader in ingredients and flavours, is a 
much less cyclical business and it has a 30-year track record of uninterrupted dividend growth (ignoring a special 
dividend 18 years ago).
What bluechips have in common is their strong, global, everyday consumer and functional brands – all highly 
resistant to the disruptive efforts of regulators and recessionary forces
Looking at other sectors internationally, it is not hard to identify the leaders. Mining has traditionally been a highly 
cyclical sector. But there are bluechip miners who by virtue of their diversified hard commodity base and global 
spread have been able to ride through the significant cyclical swings in the mining sector overall and have been 
able to sustain dividend payments through and through.
Rio Tinto is one of the top bluechips in the sector, despite its cyclical earnings profile due to the nature of the 
industry in which it operates. What gives it its bluechip status is its position in the Ftse 100 (insufficient in itself), its 
consistency with dividend payments (although the very occasional cut, such as happened back in 2009 due to a 
savage industry cycle), its geographic and mineral resource diversity and its low costs of production relative to 
peers. These are the characteristics that have enabled the company to sustain profitability and dividends through 
good cycles and bad.
As to bluechips in the retail sector, the landscape has changed utterly. Historically, Tesco would have been 
regarded as a bluechip. But intensifying competition and technological disruption in the retail sector, a costly 
misadventure into the US, and a very high fixed cost base by virtue of its real estate portfolio and the high incidence 
of upward-only rent reviews on standard British and Irish leases on its commercial property stripped the company of 
its bluechip status – despite still being the market leader in food retailing in Britain with close to a 30 per cent share.
Today Amazon is the biggest technological disrupter in retailing and one of the few retailers, along with Walmart, 
that now deserves bluechip status. The sheer scale, technological excellence and cheap warehousing storage has 
propelled it far beyond its big box store competitors burdened with onerous leases on legacy retail property and 
overcapacity in lead markets, hence their squeezed margins and cancelled dividends.
However some retailers, despite having trading difficulties from time to time, have come through without suspending 
dividends, even if there have been modest cuts.
Marks & Spencer, which lost its way for a couple of years around the turn of the century, has since been able to 
trade at levels which have enabled uninterrupted dividend payments with just a short-term cut in the 2009-2010 
period. It is arguably close to bluechip status, but remaining and strengthening its position will be challenging and 
very dependent on top-class management, strategy and investment in online channels and distribution.
In the banking sector, it wasn’t just the Irish banks that lost their bluechip status, many British and European ones 
did too. With the exception of HSBC, which has a global presence and relative defensiveness, it is hard to 
categorise any of the other clearing banks on these islands today as bluechips.
In the property sector, British Land is a company with a trophy commercial property portfolio in Britain that looks to 
be withstanding the Brexit risks well. Its prime office and retail portfolio, soundly structured balance sheet, relatively 
Mixing bluechips with younger company shares
modest level of speculative development and strong dividend paying capacity certainly merits a seat at the bluechip 
table.
Within the consumer goods sector, there is an abundance of companies that qualify for bluechip status, having 
ridden through half a century and more of sustained dividend payments and, if not, no more than one or two short-
term cuts.
To the amazement of many, British American Tobacco has been able to ride through the wave of hostile regulation 
in many developed markets and use its global reach to build new markets and continue to grow strongly in many 
emerging markets. It is now proving its capacity to innovate with healthier nicotine alternatives, so while having 
been written off by many investors decades ago, those who have stuck with it have received handsome rewards. In 
terms of fat dividends, fat dividend growth rates and strong capital appreciation on top, it remains a favourite 
bluechip, as does Imperial Tobacco.
Finally the global consumer brand leaders, such as Coca-Cola, Pepsi, Colgate Palmolive, Procter & Gamble, 
Diageo, Unilever and Reckitt Benckiser all qualify as bluechips.
What they have in common is their strong, global, everyday consumer and functional brands producing everyday 
functional products or addictive alcohol, soft drink and sugar-rich foods – all highly resistant to the disruptive efforts 
of regulators and recessionary forces, thus delivering almost uninterrupted dividend and earnings growth through 
the decades and in many cases, over half a century and more.
Aside from Wikipedia’s top-line definition of what a bluechip is, it elaborates by saying that it is a stock in a 
corporation with a national reputation for quality, reliability and the ability to operate profitably in good times and 
bad. Bluechips generally sell high quality, widely accepted products and services. Bluechip companies are known to 
weather downturns and to operate profitably in the face of adverse economic conditions, which helps to contribute 
to their long record of stable and reliable growth.
All of the above companies have done just that and as an investor seeking a reliable income in retirement, I am 
happy to own shares in ten of them. I believe strongly that mixing bluechip shares with younger company shares 
which are not bluechips, but are well managed, and playing into the structural growth characteristics of specific 
growth markets is the most comfortable way of marrying relative security with decent long-term growth.
Load-Date: April 3, 2017
End of Document
Of its time: revenues surge at New Relic ’s Dublin office
Of its time: revenues surge at New Relic’s Dublin office
Sunday Business Post
April 3, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 515 words
Byline: Patrick Murtagh
Highlight: New Relic is a software monitoring and analytics company to helps businesses understand what is 
happening in the digital sector
Body
Revenues at the Dublin office of the software-as-a-service company New Relic are growing by close to 50 per cent 
year on year, according to the company’s head of SME sales in Ireland and Britain.
“We have a number of large and small companies here that we work with, and we cover a lot of different vertical 
markets,” Glenn Cahill told The Sunday Business Post.
“Whereas markets like finance, gaming or media would have traditionally been tech-savvy, now we’re finding more 
markets like travel or food are becoming more tech-savvy as well.”
New Relic is a software monitoring and analytics company that helps businesses to understand what is happening 
in their digital sector and improve it in order to deliver a more efficient customer experience.
It gathers one billion pieces of data per minute, making it one of the biggest data companies in the world. It then 
presents the data in a format that is easily understood, making improvements and alterations easier.
Last May it announced its fourth-quarter financial highlights, with revenue of $52.5 million, up 57 per cent from 
2015. The company’s fiscal revenue for the same year was $181.3 million, up 64 per cent from 2015.
During that fourth quarter, it also signed up customers including Ryanair, Under Armour, Thomas Cook, LinkedIn 
and Harvard Business Publishing.
“More and more companies are defined by what they do online,” Cahill said.
“The main ones are big brands who offer a purely digital experience, but our play is that there are many more 
markets like this, where the digital market is the most important aspect of the company.”
Of its time: revenues surge at New Relic ’s Dublin office
Cahill described the employment market in Dublin, where New Relic employs 100 staff at its European HQ, as 
“really competitive. But we’ve done pretty well because of the kind of company that we are, and the kind of 
technology that we provide”.
New Relic chose Dublin as its European HQ primarily due to the talent of the Irish workforce, but also because it 
sees Dublin as a tech and innovation hub that is easy to do business in.
As a software-as-a-service company in a fast growing market, specifically in helping people who are moving to 
public cloud, New Relic is trying to position itself as an attractive company to work for in the tech sector. Cahill said 
the company intends to grow its staff numbers in Dublin as it expands.
“We’re a very values driven organisation. We encourage people to be their best selves, and encourage them to 
express themselves and be authentic. We provide them with the facilities to do that and to have a successful career 
in a competitive market,” he said.
“We’re growing in terms of geographic reach, the number of products we sell and also the volume of business that 
we do.”
The firm has gone from selling two products to six in recent years, and is now servicing not only major European 
cities, but also Russia, South Africa and Israel.
“We’re a digital business that reaches into almost every sector. We have thousands of customers, but because it’s 
a technical offering, only the IT folks really know about it. But the impact we have is quite significant,” said Cahill.
Load-Date: April 3, 2017
End of Document
Stock take: market week
Stock take: market week
Sunday Business Post
April 3, 2017
Copyright 2017 Post Publications Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Length: 216 words
Byline: Emma Kennedy
Body
Strong iPhone sales boost Apple’s revenues 
Strong festive sales of the iPhone 7 has seen Apple report its first rise in sales in nine months.
“We’re thrilled to report that our holiday quarter results generated Apple’s highest quarterly revenue ever, and broke 
multiple records along the way.”
Tim Cook, chief executive, Apple
 Ralph Lauren boss to step down in May 
Luxury fashion firm Ralph Lauren has announced that its chief executive Stefan Larsson will leave the company at 
the start of May, after he clashed with the company’s chairman Ralph Lauren.
“Stefan and I share a love and respect for the DNA of this great brand, and we both recognise the need to evolve. 
However, we have found that we have different views on how to evolve the creative and consumer-facing parts of 
the business. After many conversations with one another, and our board of directors, we have agreed to part ways.”
Ralph Lauren
 Passenger traffic takes off at Ryanair 
Airline Ryanair has reported a double digit percentage increase in passenger numbers for January, carrying close 
to nine million customers.
“Ryanair’s January traffic grew by 17 per cent to 8.77 million customers, while our load factor jumped two 
percentage points to 90 per cent, on the back of lower fares.”
Kenny Jacobs, chief marketing officer, Ryanair
Stock take: market week
