Norwegian eyes further transatlantic savings; Airlines
Norwegian eyes further transatlantic savings; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
January 3, 2017 Tuesday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2017 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 13
Length: 341 words
Byline: Robert Wright, Transport Correspondent
Body
The introduction of transatlantic flights to secondary airports will help to slash costs at Norwegian Air Shuttle, its 
chief executive has said.
Bjørn Kjos was speaking as his airline, a pioneer in no-frills long haul, prepares to launch services between regional 
European hubs and minor eastern US airports during 2017.
Norwegian is one of the most expensive European budget operators.
The operation will use single-aisle jets normally used only for short-haul operations and, like many of Norwegian's 
activities, has been made possible by a new generation of fuel-efficient aircraft.
Norwegian plans to introduce an ultra-low fare of £56 for a one-way flight between Edinburgh and a secondary 
airport in New York.
The new services - between cities such as Edinburgh and Cork, and Stewart International Airport, about 70 miles 
upstate of New York City, or Providence, Rhode Island - will bring down Norwegian's costs, which are about 4.3 
euro cents per available seat kilometre, a standard industry metric.
Analysts calculate that for Ryanair the cost is about 3.6 euro cents. The Irish carrier, the industry cost leader, does 
not release comparable figures.
Norwegian eyes further transatlantic savings; Airlines
"Our long haul is working," Mr Kjos said. "And the more efficient an operation we have, the more aircraft we can put 
in long haul, the less costs we will have."
Norwegian's costs would be divided across more passengers after the planned long-haul expansion, he added.
The flights to secondary airports will be use Boeing's new, highly efficient 737 Max aircraft .
Starting in 2019 Norwegian plans to operate Airbus's largest single-aisle product, a longer-range version of the 
A321.
Both aircraft offer improved fuel economy and have the range to fly from Europe to eastern US.
"We fly extremely modern aircraft," Mr Kjos said. "That's the key with cost in long haul."
For its current long-haul operations - which include many from London Gatwick to destinations such as Fort 
Lauderdale - Norwegian uses Boeing's 787 Dreamliner .
Its short-haul network around Scandinavia has some of the highest costs.
Load-Date: January 2, 2017
End of Document

My midsummer morning
My midsummer morning
Financial Times (London, England)
December 24, 2016 Saturday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: FT WEEKEND SUPPLEMENT - LIFE & ARTS; Pg. 5
Length: 1963 words
Byline: Alastair Humphreys
Highlight: He has rowed the Atlantic and cycled round the world but this year Alastair Humphreys found true 
adventure closer to home - busking across Spain in the footsteps of Laurie Lee
Body
A year ago I was on a train, rattling slowly through December's grey towns and leafless landscapes. I was reading a 
book, a tale of bright sunshine, colourful village fiestas, and adventure. I looked up from my book and let out a sigh.
For most of my adult life I have either been wandering the world or reading stories of people wandering the world. 
Laurie Lee's As I Walked Out One Midsummer Morning was one of the books that got me started and I still read it 
almost annually.
Lee arrived in Spain in the summer of 1935. He had never been overseas, had rarely even left the quiet 
Gloucestershire village he grew up in. He was searching for adventure and chose Spain simply because he knew 
one phrase in Spanish - ¿ un vaso de agua, por favor? His vague, romantic idea was to walk through the country, 
paying his way by playing his violin. Lee travelled slowly, lived simply, slept on hilltops and relished spontaneity.
Every time I read his story I yearned to follow in Lee's bucolic footsteps but there was one significant problem. I 
could not play the violin or any other instrument. Even the thought of performing, dancing or singing in public 
terrified me. But the walk without the music would be missing the point.
My midsummer morning
And so for 15 years I shelved the idea of walking out one midsummer morning in Spain. Instead I embarked on a 
series of physical challenges in remote environments. I cycled round the world for four years. I walked across 
southern India and the Empty Quarter desert. I crossed Iceland. I rowed the Atlantic.
But the more expeditions I did, the better I became at them. I realised I had begun sticking to what I was good at, 
living precisely the unchallenging, routine life that this was all supposed to help me avoid. The essence of 
adventure is to seek out that which scares you and to risk uncertainty and failure. I realised that if I wanted to 
continue testing myself, I needed to move away from meaningless penances in the wilderness.
As the train rumbled on, I pulled my phone from my pocket. But this time, instead of the escapism of social media, I 
opened Google and typed the words "find a local violin teacher" before I had time to really think.
I bought a violin the next morning. An impulsive, flippant email sent while bored on a train had set something in 
motion. Becoming a beginner again was a refreshing experience - I loved the tangible steps of improvement. I 
quickly learned, however, that the violin cannot be quickly learnt.
After seven months I was still appalling. But it was time to begin what promised to be a hungry and deeply 
embarrassing journey. I would catch a Ryanair flight to Vigo, where Lee began his walk, take no money, busk to 
survive, and try to make it all the way to Madrid.
At Vigo airport I sealed my passport, return plane ticket and credit card in a plastic bag with a note to myself saying 
"if you open this before the end you have failed". From now on it was just me, my violin, and five pitiful tunes that 
most seven-year-old violinists would turn their noses up at. I hoisted my pack on to my back and walked down to 
the harbour. I was more nervous than I had been since the day I set off to row across the Atlantic.
It was a disaster. My songs sounded as pitiful as I knew they would. I deeply regretted this farce. There was no 
crowd, no cascade of coins, no applause. Just indifference, disbelief, laughter or wrinkled noses as people 
accelerated past my empty violin case, eyes averted.
After a fruitless, mortifying hour sawing away in the charming, once peaceful plaza, I saw an elderly man rise from 
his bench and walk slowly towards me. I assumed that he was going to reprimand me. "Enough! Time to move on." 
But instead he put his hand into his pocket. Surely not! He pulled out a coin and I felt I was going to burst with 
excitement and amusement and relief. A whole euro - and with it hope.
I consulted my map and walked out of Vigo. I had a month to follow Lee's route as far as Madrid but this was the 
first time I had given much thought to the 500 or so miles ahead - confirmation that walking almost 20 miles a day 
was far less daunting than playing a ditty to a dozen people. Eventually the fierce heat and the hard city streets 
gave way to fragrant eucalyptus woods, views back down the mountains to the sea, and my first night under the 
stars. I cooked rice bought with my first earnings on a tiny fire, eating gratefully from the pan, and fell asleep in a 
field, buzzing with the excitement of beginning.
I soon settled into the slow, ageless rhythms of walking journeys that heft you to a landscape: waking at dawn, 
walking through pine forests or hillsides of bracken, chatting with shepherds on dusty white droving roads, 
swimming in trout pools, snoozing in sweet chestnut groves and rolling out my bedding each night. This was the 
same way Lee experienced his Spain. The wayside blackberries, apples and grapes were not yet ripe, taunting my 
hungry belly as I eked out crusts of bread.
I suffered, as Lee had done, across the fiercely hot plains of Castile. Sunflowers marched for miles across the 
empty world, yellow armies of nodding heads and my only companion in those shimmering, lonely miles. Wheat 
fields whispered in the faintest breeze as I trudged towards Toro, in Lee's words "an ancient, eroded, red-walled 
town spread along the top of a huge flat boulder". One advantage I had over him was the existence of irrigation 
sprinklers. One scorching afternoon I stripped naked in a cabbage field for a delightful cold shower. All I had to do 
each day was walk, and then work (busk) in order to afford to walk another day. Life was simple. Simple but not 
easy.
My midsummer morning
I fretted that my beginner's luck would expire and my incompetence be shouted out of town. I nervously dragged 
out the process of finding strategic spots to busk, unpacking my violin and arranging my music sheets slowly before 
the first violent screech shattered the town's peace and my happy anonymity. The thrill of earning the day's first coin 
never diminished, however, and I grew increasingly confident with my performances. Declare and embrace your 
vulnerabilities and they cease to be weaknesses.
One hot, still morning I arrived in pretty Puebla de Sanabria on the banks of the meandering Río Castro. My timing 
was fortuitous: it was Sunday and the town was filling with ambling, affable tourists. By the time my patch of shade 
beneath the castle walls had run out and the cobbled streets lulled to siesta stillness I had earned a scarcely 
imaginable EUR20.05. I feasted on chorizo and ice cream. Then, on my way out of town, I was beckoned over to a 
street party outside a bar. I was fed chicken wings and beer and danced through the tipsy afternoon. My attempt to 
play a duet with the local guitarist was a predictable disaster, but the day was a triumph. I wove my way into the 
sunset, singing happily, feeling like Lee.
Every day I counted my earnings down to the last cent. My total income for the month was EUR125.40, ample for 
so many miles of memories. In shops I calculated fastidiously, focusing on the calorie-to-price ratio of foods rather 
than their taste appeal.
Despite this frugal existence, or perhaps because of it, I cannot remember when last I felt so self-contained, so sure 
about what I was doing, so content to be in the moment. Every time I played, every time I headed back up into the 
hills with a loaf of bread sticking out of my rucksack, I felt incredibly happy. I whistled Guantanamera (one of my five 
busking tunes) and stamped the rhythm with my hiking poles. I treasured the gift of time as I walked through the 
slow summer.
The journey was primarily a solitary experience. I spent day after day on footpaths far from anyone, and even 
accidentally strolled through the high security grounds of the Royal Palace of El Pardo, near Madrid, for a few 
hours. With hindsight my trespass seems obvious, but at the time I thought nothing of it as I climbed a high stone 
wall in order to cross what looked merely like a tantalising expanse of open countryside on my map (the guard who 
eventually spotted me was too surprised to be particularly angry). Above all, standing in a busy street where nobody 
knows your name, playing the same songs very badly in hope of a coin for your supper, is an extremely lonely place 
to be.
Yet the loneliness made the encounters and conversations along the way all the richer. An elderly gentleman sat 
me down on a bench and mused that my journey was akin to the board game La Oca, similar to Snakes and 
Ladders, rolling my dice and taking my chances as I went along my way. One morning I accompanied a postman, 
Marcelino, on his morning round, delivering letters and chatting in the street. He treated me to an espresso at noon.
One evening I was invited to sleep indoors, the only night of the whole trip. Sergio bumped into me just after sunset 
in the quiet village of Matapozuelos, an island amid a flat sea of farmland. A seasoned traveller himself, Sergio was 
excited to hear my story and knew well the impact of kindness on a lonely soul in a foreign land. I accepted 
gratefully - a shower! a bed! - and followed him to his home. Sergio lived with his mother, who was taken aback by 
the dirty vagabond on the doorstep. She fussed that the spare room I would stay in was not sufficiently prepared. It 
was perfect, of course. She studied, unimpressed, the sewing repairs that I had made on my shirt. And then she 
proceeded to fuss over me, mother me and force-feed me terrific quantities of delicious food.
After the disappointment of beautiful Segovia, where the foreign tourists ignored my busking efforts beneath the 
Roman aqueduct and the police moved me on for the only time in the trip, I climbed up into the glory of the Sierra 
de Guadarrama mountains. The sun set to the sound of cowbells and the scent of crushed thyme as I walked a 
Roman road up meadows dotted with oak trees.
"A green haze of pine-dust floated in shafts of sunlight and squirrels swung and chattered above me," wrote Lee as 
he climbed these same hills. "Gulping the fine dry air and sniffing the pitch-pine mountain I was perhaps never so 
alive and so alone again."
My midsummer morning
Cresting the rocky mountain escarpment, I followed the Río Manzanares down from its source, galloping down a 
grassy bowl of a valley and swimming in deep, clear pools. It was a beautiful end to the wilderness. I would follow 
this river all the way to the capital, only a couple of days' from here. I savoured the silence of these final few days, 
waking at dawn in forests with the evening cicadas all gone. I would pack up, leave no trace, and be hours down 
the path before first speaking a word.
Arriving at last in the baking heart of Madrid I shrugged off my sweaty rucksack for the final time, flopping down in a 
shaded pavement café. The crowds, the traffic, the heat of the tall avenues all felt unsettling. After a month on the 
road, this was my end. I asked the waiter the cost of a pint. He told me and I headed out to the nearest plaza to 
perform for the final time. Returning to the café with sufficient money I ordered a small celebratory beer.
The first sip exploded in my mouth like frosted stars. I had earned that beer. I truly savoured it. I left the remainder 
of my coins on the bar as a tip, my own small gesture of goodwill to a stranger. I had begun with nothing; I ended 
with nothing.
Part of me wished that my journey could continue for months like Lee's did. But now that I knew I could busk my 
way across a country, I did not need to keep doing it. Now that it had become just a delightful way of life it was no 
longer a challenge. The purpose of this walk had been the unknowing, the uncertainty and the risk. My summer with 
Laurie Lee had been my most challenging, fresh and surprising adventure in years.
Load-Date: December 23, 2016
End of Document

Aer Lingus / Ryanair ECJ state aid bill
Aer Lingus/Ryanair; ECJ state aid bill
Financial Times (London, England)
December 22, 2016 Thursday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 19
Length: 269 words
Byline: Vincent Boland
Body
er Lingus and Ryanair face a combined bill of at least EUR16m after the European Court of Justice yesterday ruled 
that they had benefited from illegal state aid.
The ECJ said the two airlines had obtained state aid after the Irish government introduced a controversial air travel 
tax in 2009, at the height of the financial crisis.
The government said airlines would pay EUR2 per passenger on short-haul flights operated from Dublin, but 
EUR10 on long-haul flights.
The ECJ concluded the EUR8 differential constituted illegal state aid, and must be paid by the airlines to the 
government.
Ryanair said it faced a bill of EUR12m as a result of the ECJ judgment, while Aer Lingus estimated it would have to 
pay EUR4m.
The airlines said they would pursue the Irish government for damages incurred in having to pay what they said was 
an "illegal" tax.
Aer Lingus / Ryanair ECJ state aid bill
Ryanair said: "This ruling now clears the way for Ryanair (and other airlines) to pursue our High Court action 
against the Irish government to recover the EUR88m of damages we suffered as a result of being forced to pay this 
illegal tax."
Aer Lingus, owned by International Airlines Group, said it was studying the ECJ judgment and that it was seeking 
"substantial damages" from the Irish government "for losses flowing from the infringement of EU rules on free 
movement of services arising from the air travel tax".
Ryanair and Aer Lingus opposed the introduction of the tax, saying it damaged the travel sector and hurt their 
businesses.
The tax was introduced seven years ago as Ireland faced a financial crunch after the collapse of much of its 
banking sector.
Vincent Boland

 American depository receipts of European stocks were 0.2% higher at 119.83 on the Bank of New York Mellon 
Europe ADR Index on Wednesday morning.
Pharmaceutical companies led the gainers in Continental Europe with Forward Pharma (FWP), a Danish 
biopharmaceutical company, and Cellectis (CLLS), a French genome engineering company, both 4.2% higher, 
followed by Oasmia Pharmaceuticals (OASM),  an Austria-based clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company and 
Nabriva Therapeutics, 4.1% and 2.4% higher, respectively. 
In the UK, gainers were led by by Motif Bio (MTFB), a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company, 3.3% higher, 
followed by GW Pharmaceuticals (GWPH), up by 1.4% and Amarin (AMRN), 1.3% higher. BP (BP), an oil and gas 
production company, was up by 1.0%. 
Decliners in Continental Europe were led by Advanced Accelorator Applications (AAAP), a radiopharmaceutical 
company, 4.7% lower, followed by Edap (EDAP),  a French medical devices developer, down by 2.4% and Talend 
(TLND), a provider of open source integration solutions, down by 2.3% and Banco Bilbao Vizcaya Argentaria 
(BBVA), a Spanish financial group, 1.8% lower.
And, in the UK, Midatech (MTP), an early-stage biopharmaceutical company, was 3.5% lower, followed by 
diversified mining company BHP Billiton (BBL), down by 0.8% and Trinity Biotech (TRIB), a manufacturer of medical 
diagnostic products, 0.7% lower. Low-cost airline Ryanair (RYAAY), down by 0.6%.

Ryanair and Aer Lingus face tax bill after EU court ruling on state aid
Ryanair and Aer Lingus face tax bill after EU court ruling on state aid
Business World (Digest)
December 21, 2016 Wednesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 304 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
Ryanair and Aer Lingus face paying back millions of euros in air travel taxes after the European Court of Justice 
ruled on Wednesday that they had benefited from unlawful aid from the Irish government.
Ryanair, Europe's largest budget airline, said the ruling would require it to repay 12 million euros to the Irish 
government, but also said airlines would be able to take legal action to claim compensation from the government 
over the tax.
Aer Lingus, which is part of International Airlines Group , said Ireland was seeking 4 million euros, but that this 
figure was being contested.
The European Court of Justice upheld a decision by the European Commission in 2011 that lower air tax rates in 
Ireland for shorter flights, including on some services to Britain, between 2009 and 2011 were illegal subsidies.
Ryanair and Aer Lingus went to the court in Luxembourg after the Commission said Ireland was wrong to set air tax 
on short-haul flights at 8 euros lower per passenger than on longer flights as it disproportionately benefited Irish 
carriers who flew more short routes.
"The advantage in question did not consist in the fact that those airlines were able to offer more competitive prices 
than their competitors," the Court said in a statement.
"It resulted quite simply from the fact that those companies had to pay a lower amount than they would have had to 
pay if their flights had been subject to the standard rate."
Ryanair and Aer Lingus face tax bill after EU court ruling on state aid
Ireland modified its air travel tax in 2011 to a flat rate for all flights, domestic and international, following the 
Commission's investigation.
Ryanair in an emailed statement said Wednesday's ruling cleared the way for legal action by airlines to recover 88 
million euros from the Irish government for the imposition of what it described as an illegal tax. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie

CITY MOVES WHO'S SWITCHING JOBS
CITY MOVES WHO'S SWITCHING JOBS
City A.M.
December 15, 2016 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 18
Length: 395 words
Body
THE INSTANT GROUP John Duckworth has been appointed managing director of The Instant Group, responsible 
for all sales and business operations in the UK and EMEA region. An experienced real estate executive, John joins 
from JLL where he was a member of the UK board and, among other responsibilities, ran its corporate services 
business. In his 18 years at the company John worked across the EMEA market in a number of roles, starting with 
the tenant representation team in Paris and ultimately becoming managing director for JLL Central & Eastern 
Europe, based in Warsaw.
WILLIS TOWERS WATSON Willis Towers Watson has appointed Mary O'Connor to lead the client and business 
development function. Mary also continues to co-lead the global financial institutions industry group. Mary will report 
to head of Great Britain, Nicolas Aubert, and global industries lead, Eric Speer. Reflecting the significance of clients 
to the success of the organisation, Mary will also have a seat on the boards of Willis Limited and Towers Watson 
Limited, subject to regulatory approval. Mary was also the co-lead for the global financial lines business in corporate 
risk and broking with Alexis Faber. Going forward, Alexis will assume sole leadership for this global business.
STOBART GROUP Stobart Group has appointed Warwick Brady as deputy group CEO. It is intended that Warwick 
will join the board following the Group's annual general meeting in June 2017. Warwick was chief operating officer 
of EasyJet until 30 September 2016 and has extensive commercial and management experience. Previously, he 
was also CEO at Mandala Airlines in Asia and spent two years as chief operating officer of Air Deccan/Kingfisher in 
India. Prior to that, Warwick was deputy operations director at Ryanair from 2002 to 2005, where he held various 
senior executive roles including deputy CEO of Buzz, following its acquisition from KLM.
MORNINGSTAR INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT EUROPE Morningstar Investment Management Europe has 
appointed Gavin Corr to the role of director, responsible for key client relationships for the company's investment 
management business in the UK and Europe, Middle East, and Africa (EMEA) region. Gavin has over 25 years of 
CITY MOVES WHO'S SWITCHING JOBS
financial services experience, managing high-profile and highly rated institutional pension funds, in addition to retail 
unit trusts and US-based mutual funds.

Fernandes displays streamlined vision AirAsia boss plays down fears that changes to group will weaken brand, 
but sale of leasing arm may have consequences
Fernandes displays streamlined vision; AirAsia boss plays down fears that 
changes to group will weaken brand, but sale of leasing arm may have 
consequences
Flight International
December 13, 2016
Copyright 2016 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS FOCUS
Length: 858 words
Body
Buried in AirAsia Group’s recent third-quarter results were several items that have broad implications for the 
business’s future.
In two short paragraphs, the carrier group disclosed plans to sell off its aircraft leasing arm Asia Aviation Capital 
(AAC), and to float two of its other operations, all in 2017.
Group chief executive Tony Fernandes says this is part of his plan “to streamline the business and dispose of non-
core businesses”; if all goes according to plan, 2017 could prove to be a milestone year.
In a recent televised interview, Fernandes dismissed concerns that AirAsia Group’s strategy could dilute the 
company.
“Absolutely not. You don’t get EasyJet or Ryanair operating all over Europe having their brand diluted. If anything, 
it’s stronger. It’s creating a single economic vehicle that allows analysts and investors to see the group as a whole – 
not just as a Malaysian operation with one airline and its associates.”
Fernandes was specifically referring to plans to list its ASEAN-area operations holding company, the imaginatively 
titled ASEAN Holding Co, on the Hong Kong stock exchange.
Hong Kong was selected, he says, for two reasons: to prepare for a time when the southeast Asian trade bloc 
moves towards “one common market”, and to raise the group’s profile in North Asia, as its business has also 
“gravitated towards” that region.
Before that, however, the group will have to focus on turning around the performance at affiliates Indonesia AirAsia 
and Philippines AirAsia, which are also due to undergo initial public offerings (IPOs) in 2017.
Fernandes displays streamlined vision AirAsia boss plays down fears that changes to group will weaken brand, 
but sale of leasing arm may have consequences
Its other planned listing is of its flightcrew training centre, AirAsia Academy, on the Malaysian exchange.
Aaron Kee, an equity research analyst at Affin Hwang Capital, sees the IPOs as a natural step, as the AirAsia 
Group did “moderately well” during the quarter ended 30 September.
“The IPOs will help each unit realise its individual value, and allow for price discovery. The management believes 
that profitability can be sustained, especially for its Indonesian and Philippines businesses, and that turnarounds for 
the two could happen soon.”
Kee thinks the IPOs are not designed to raise capital, since an imminent MYR1.02 billion ($230 million) cash 
infusion into AirAsia Group by co-founders Fernandes and Kamarudin Meranun, as well as the sale of AAC, will 
leave it with “ample” funds.
“The intention is to raise the profile of each unit that will come under ASEAN Holding Co, with the main Malaysia 
operations still listed on Bursa Malaysia,” he says.
The money received from any share issue is expected to help reduce Fernandes’ and Kamarudin’s personal debts, 
as well as the company’s working capital borrowings. More importantly, it could fund the group’s expansion into 
China, says Kee.
In June, a new North Asia president was appointed: Kathleen Tan, the former chief executive of AirAsia Expedia, 
has been tasked with building AirAsia Group’s business in greater China, Japan and South Korea.
Others, however, see the announcements as part of arch-publicist Fernandes’ efforts to drum up interest in a 
flagging operation.
Maybank Investment Bank analyst Mohshin Aziz believes it is still too early for investors to get excited about the 
IPOs, pointing out that AirAsia Group first broached the idea two years ago. “At present, it is all rhetoric. Yes, it’s 
definitely part of the long-term plan, but I’m not going to get excited about it just yet,” he says.
Aziz says that the equity market is “just another opportunity” for the group to expand its financing options. Airlines 
today “need as much money as they can get if they want to stand a chance of surviving,” he notes.
AirAsia Group attributed its improved third-quarter performance in part to a revenue boost led by an increase in 
aircraft operating lease income. AAC more than doubled revenue compared with the same quarter last year, to $66 
million.
Aziz says, however, that when the cost of running AAC is factored in, its net profit margin is lower than that of 
AirAsia’s airline businesses.
Kee, meanwhile, believes the leasing business has evolved into “a $1 billion carrot that is too good to pass up”.
Both analysts, however, agree that there will be repercussions from the sale of AAC and that in contrast the group 
would benefit from keeping the leasing arm in-house over the longer term.
While selling AAC will give AirAsia Group and its owners a massive one-off cash windfall, the slimmed-down parent 
company will no longer enjoy the same economies of scale, especially in sourcing parts and corporate financing.
And once AAC is under outside ownership, there will be nothing to stop it from looking after its own bottom line first, 
leaving the provision of a guaranteed supply of aircraft to AirAsia Group as a secondary consideration.
Airline chief and serial self-publicist has a pan-Asian strategy in mind
REX/Shutterstock
“It’s creating a single
Fernandes displays streamlined vision AirAsia boss plays down fears that changes to group will weaken brand, 
but sale of leasing arm may have consequences
economic vehicle that
allows analysts and
investors to see the
group as a whole”
Tony Fernandes

Village Vic back to pitch his tent at Cheltenham RACING TRADER ; Bill Esdaile previews the best of the action 
from Cheltenham and Sha Tin
Village Vic back to pitch his tent at Cheltenham; RACING TRADER ; Bill 
Esdaile previews the best of the action from Cheltenham and Sha Tin
City A.M.
December 9, 2016 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: SPORT; Pg. 39
Length: 537 words
Body
WHEN the rain finally arrived a month ago in time for Cheltenham's Open meeting, trainers breathed a sigh of relief 
at the prospect of some proper winter jumping conditions.
Yet, just four weeks on and clerk of the course Simon Claisse has been forced to turn on the taps to maintain 
decent ground.
It's been a bizarrely dry winter which means tomorrow's Caspian Caviar Gold Cup (1.50pm) is going to be a totally 
different kind of test to normal.
The best trial for this race has always been the BetVictor Gold Cup and four of the first five are set to line-up again 
tomorrow.
The winner, Taquin De Seuil, is missing on account of the ground but, despite the burden of top weight, I'm going to 
side with VILLAGE VIC who was only just touched off last month.
Philip Hobbs' nine-year-old was a hugely impressive winner of this race 12 months ago and then followed up over 
course and distance on New Year's Day.
He was put in his place by Vautour in the Ryanair, but that was at the end of a hard season and I thought he ran an 
extraordinary race on his come-back.
The type of jumper who puts his rivals to the sword at every fence with his aggressive front-running tactics, he was 
really unlucky to get caught near the line.
Village Vic back to pitch his tent at Cheltenham RACING TRADER ; Bill Esdaile previews the best of the action 
from Cheltenham and Sha Tin
Although he's now far higher in the weights than last year, he's such a solid and consistent horse that you know 
you'll get a decent run for your money.
Bouvreuil looks by far the biggest danger after a respectable fifth in the same race last month. He ran well on a 
number of occasions last season and loves decent ground.
I've no doubt that he's well-handicapped, but his price disintegrated earlier in the week and I'd rather back Village 
Vic each-way at 7/1 with Betway.
There is a dearth of top class two mile hurdlers in the UK at the moment, so there is a decidedly openlooking feel to 
the Stan James International Hurdle (3.00pm).
Final declarations won't be known until later this morning, but I suggest you back MY TENT OR YOURS at 13/8.
The conditions of the race massively favour Nicky Henderson's nine-year-old and on three visits to Cheltenham he's 
finished second in two Champion Hurdles and a Supreme Novices' Hurdle.
Don't read too much into Haydock last time, he was never going to handle that ground. He's the class horse in the 
race, has his ideal conditions and gets weight from all of his rivals.
It was a shame that WHOLESTONE didn't get the job done here last month, but compensation awaits in the Albert 
Bartlett Novices' Hurdle (2.25pm).
Nigel Twiston-Davies' inmate will relish the step back up in trip and is strongly fancied to see off regular rival West 
Approach.
There is some competitive action at Cheltenham this afternoon where the highlight is the Unicoin Group Handicap 
Chase (1.30pm).
I like the look of Tom George's A GOOD SKIN who has some excellent course and distance form, including a 
handicap win in April 2015 and a second in this year's Kim Muir.
The ground is perfect and he should be backed at 15/2 with Betway, who are giving money back as a free bet if 
your horse finishes second in all Channel 4 races today.
POINTERS A Good Skin e/w 1.30pm Cheltenham (Fri) Village Vic e/w 1.50pm Cheltenham (Sat) Wholestone 
2.25pm Cheltenham (Sat) My Tent Or Yours 3.00pm Cheltenham (Sat)
Graphic
 
Village Vic can become only the second dual winner of the Caspian Caviar Gold Cup

Ryanair adds new Zadar route to Bristol summer 2017 schedule
Ryanair adds new Zadar route to Bristol summer 2017 schedule
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
December 7, 2016 Wednesday 12:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: AUTOMOTIVE, TRANSPORT AND LOGISTICS
Length: 408 words
Highlight: Ryanair Ltd. has added a new Zadar route to its Bristol summer 2017 schedule, with a twice weekly 
service beginning at the end of March 2017, which will help deliver over 1.7 million customers p.a. at Bristol airport.
Body
Ryanair&#39;s Bristol summer 2017 schedule includes 31 exciting destinations in total, lower fares (as Ryanair 
passes on lower fuel costs), and an even better customer experience, as it rolls out year 3 of its "Always Getting 
Better" customer experience programme, and will deliver: 1 new route toZadar; New summer services to Bucharest 
(2 x weekly) & Venice Marco Polo (4 x weekly); 31 routes in total; 125 weekly flights; and Over 1.7m customers 
p.a.Ryanair will continue to connect Bristol with popular sun destinations on low fare services including Alicante (10 
weekly), Malaga (8 weekly) and Palma (10 weekly), with better timings and lower fares, making Ryanair the ideal 
choice for UK customers.Ryanair&#39;s Robin Kiely said: "We are pleased to add a new Zadar route to our Bristol 
summer 2017 schedule, which will operate twice weekly from the end of March. Our Bristol summer 2017 schedule 
includes 31 routes in total, including new summer routes to Bucharest and Venice Marco Polo and extra flights to 
Warsaw, which will deliver over 1.7m customers p.a. and support 1,300 jobs at Bristol Airport."Customers can look 
forward to even lower fares when they make advance bookings for summer 2017, so there&#39;s never been a 
better time to book a low fare flight on Ryanair and we urge all customers who wish to book their summer 2017 
holidays to do so now on the Ryanair.com website, where they can avail of the lowest fare air travel to and from 
Bristol. 
"Fares on our new Bristol to Zadar route are on sale now from just GBP24.99 for travel in April and can be booked 
on the Ryanair.com website until midnight Thursday (8 Dec). Since these amazing low prices will be snapped up 
quickly, customers should log onto www.ryanair.com and book a low fare Zadar trip."Peter Downes, Bristol Airport 
said: "We are delighted with the announcement of the new Zadar route commencing from Bristol Airport from 
summer 2017. This destination takes the Ryanair network at Bristol to over 30 routes, offering customers in the 
South West and Wales more choice than ever before."Croatia is one of our fastest-growing country markets, and I 
am sure the addition of this new route will be a great success as customers living in our region seek new and 
exciting destinations to visit next year. Similarly, the addition of Zadar will continue to put the South West on the 
map for international visitors looking to experience everything the region has to offer."
Ryanair adds new Zadar route to Bristol summer 2017 schedule

Are Ryanair 's package holiday ambitions all set for take off?
Are Ryanair's package holiday ambitions all set for take off?
City A.M.
December 7, 2016 Wednesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 16
Length: 378 words
Byline: Stephan Shakespeare
Body
UDGET airline Ryanair is set to sell package holidays alongside its flights, placing it in direct competition with tour 
operators.
BThe company wants to reposition itself - from a business known for cheap flights to a broader leisure offering, all 
while undercutting its rivals.
YouGov data shows that among those that would consider using Ryanair in the future, two thirds (67 per cent) 
booked accommodation and travel separately on their last holiday, suggesting a sizable majority may need to be 
convinced a package booking's benefits. However, around a quarter (24 per cent) booked their vacation as a 
package deal, indicating that there is already an existing market they can target.
Among those that already book package holidays, the brand's challenge is to provide an alternative to established 
rivals. When it comes to those that don't ordinarily consider package deals, they need to persuade them to give it a 
try though competitive prices. Ryanair will need to target consumers that book package holidays. Our data indicates 
that those in this group are more likely than the rest of the population to be aged over 55, followed closely by those 
in the 45-54 age group.
Naturally, Ryanair is expected to undertake a fairly extensive marketing campaign to raise awareness of its new 
offering. Profiles data also enables us to see what type of advertising works well among package holiday users. 
They are more likely than the average to enjoy adverts containing their favourite celebrities (31 per cent vs. 26 per 
cent of the general population), while they are also more likely to notice adverts on posters or billboards (36 per 
cent vs. 32 per cent). YouGov BrandIndex data indicates that, on the whole, consumer perception of Ryanair is 
improving. Among all respondents, its purchase consideration score (that measures whether someone would think 
about buying from the brand) is four points higher than this time last year.
Are Ryanair 's package holiday ambitions all set for take off?
Taking all of this into account, it seems that existing tour operators should take Ryanair's move very seriously. 
Despite some consumers' reservations, the brand continues to attract customers that want cheap travel. Putting all 
of their needs in one place is another way of offering that.
£ Stephan Shakespeare is the chief executive of YouGov
Load-Date: December 7, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair to carry six million customers over Christmas and New Year
Ryanair to carry six million customers over Christmas and New Year
Business World (Digest)
December 07, 2016 Wednesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 101 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
Ryanair will carry over six million customers between 18 December and 7 January across its European network 
with 1.1 million extra seats added for people flying home for the holiday season.
Ryanair flights will operate up to 16.30hrs (GMT) on Christmas Eve, resuming at 08.15hrs (GMT) on St. Stephen’s 
Day, while Friday, 23rd December will be the busiest day of festive flying with over 1,950 Ryanair flights scheduled.
Thirty six percent of customers surveyed booked a winter getaway this year with Tenerife as the most popular 
destination followed by Milan, Warsaw and Brussels.   Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: December 16, 2016

Norwegian Air to start flying to US from Ireland
Norwegian Air to start flying to US from Ireland
Business World (Digest)
December 06, 2016 Tuesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 416 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Budget carrier Norwegian Air Shuttle plans to order more aircraft from Boeing and Airbus after its Irish subsidiary 
received long-awaited flying rights from U.S. authorities, its Chief Executive told Reuters.
After a three-year application process, the U.S. Transportation Department granted those rights on Friday, setting 
the stage for a new battle among airlines for leisure travellers across the Atlantic.
"There is no doubt we'll need even more planes after this," Bjoern Kjos said in an interview on Monday, adding that 
he expected the airline to place orders from both Airbus and Boeing.
Norwegian Air is working on new transatlantic routes from Irish cities like Cork, Dublin and Shannon, and plans to 
double its staff in the United States, he said.
"We expect to start flying from Cork and Dublin already next summer with at least four weekly routes," said Kjos.
"But there, we expect to add more routes, both from Shannon and also from some cities in Scotland."
Shares in Norwegian Air surged 12.4 percent by 1146 GMT on Monday in reaction to the ruling. It gives the carrier's 
Irish-based international arm the right to fly to the United States, and benefit from the European Union's aviation 
agreement with the United States, which is much more comprehensive than Norway's.
Kjos said he now expected the Norwegian low-cost carrier to open several new bases in the United States, with 
staff using such locations as their home base, in the coming years.
Norwegian Air to start flying to US from Ireland
"We will now start working on establishing bases in Los Angeles and San Francisco. LA will most likely be in place 
in 2018 and hopefully San Francisco as well," said Kjos.
The airline expects to double the number of employees in the United States to over 2,000 in 2018, he said.
Last week Ryanair said it was in talks with Norwegian Air about feeding passengers into Norwegian's long-haul 
flights from large cities in Britain. Kjos said the decision from U.S. authorities on Friday makes these talks even 
more relevant.
"We are in talks with Ryanair right now where we are looking at the technical solutions. We hope to have a deal in 
place sometime next year", said Kjos.
"After that we would like similar deals with EasyJet and other airlines who want a cooperation", said Kjos.
Kjos said Norwegian would use European and U.S. crew on these routes, depending on where the hubs are.
"We will create a lot of jobs in the U.S. and we will fly in a lot of tourists who will spend a lot of money over there." 
(Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
About us
Load-Date: December 15, 2016
End of Document

Think twice before picking Uber as a business model
Think twice before picking Uber as a business model
Financial Times (London, England)
December 5, 2016 Monday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: ON MANAGEMENT; Pg. 16
Length: 779 words
Byline: Andrew Hill
Body
Electrolux's chief executive took a beating last week for his excitable comment that the white-goods company was 
testing the idea of "a laundry Uber , where people share their unused laundry time".
"Aside from anything else, why exactly would an equipment maker want people sharing their washing machines? 
Surely they prefer everyone to buy their own instead?" commented one Financial Times reader.
I also wanted to hang Jonas Samuelson out to dry. The phrase this is "the Uber for . . . " has worn as thin as a pair 
of much-laundered underpants. You do not have to search far to find an aspiring Uber for laundry in China - Edaixi - 
and a defunct one, Washio, in the US . In the past two years, we have reported on Ubers for water, private jets, 
drones, pot, rubbish and, indeed, "everything", not to mention an "Amazon for travel" ( Ryanair , since you ask) and 
an "Airbnb for migrants".
Stephan Chambers, former chair of Oxford's Skoll Centre for Social Entrepreneurship, got so fed up with hearing 
new ideas described this way that he outlawed the formula - along with the similarly tired vision of any unlikely 
technology hotspot as "the Silicon Valley of" wherever.
The Uber-for approach may help a few unimaginative venture capitalists picture a new business (or journalists 
describe them). Like the Hollywood movie pitch that shackles together two hits - "It's The Hunger Games meets The 
King's Speech !" - it may tempt some to dream of Uber-sized values for an as yet untested concept. But as a 
strategy template, it is distracting, derivative and limiting.
Think twice before picking Uber as a business model
So I am grateful to Mr Samuelson for stopping the spin cycle for corporate comparisons. But I also thank him for the 
reminder that companies must invent different ways of working, not just different things to sell.
Too often, innovation debates focus on new products, particularly ones with superior technology. But as Alexander 
Osterwalder , who devised the widely used "business model canvas" to help people frame their approach, points 
out, Nintendo's Wii shook up the games console industry with an inferior technology and a much better business 
model that attracted casual gamers and milked revenues from game licences.
"Competing on products was last century's competition; now you need to be able to compete on business model," 
Mr Osterwalder says. Even companies with long pedigrees of product innovation, such as Post-it note maker 3M, 
now realise they could squeeze even more from their business by re-examining the way they operate, too.
This is where an Uber-for provocation can come into its own. Mr Osterwalder uses Nespresso to prompt clients of 
Strategyzer, the consulting company he founded, to think about how they could shake up their systems. The coffee 
pods and machines were a product innovation for Nestlé, for sure, but they were also a new model, based on 
recurring revenue and direct sales.
Rethinking your business as though constrained by someone else's model, can also be fruitful. For example, what if 
you had to give away your most successful product? If only newspapers had brainstormed that idea before it came 
expensively - and, for many, catastrophically - true.
Even assuming you hit on an innovative new way of doing business, nobody can afford to stick with it forever. To 
some degree, this has always been true. Sears, the retailer, started as a mail-order company and only began 
building department stores when threatened by bricks-and-mortar retailers in the 1920s.
A century on, though, the pace at which companies have to reinvent themselves is far more rapid. Amazon - a 
Sears for the online age - is now experimenting with offline bookstores and grocery pick-up hubs . Those 
innovations are founded on the original "everything store". Amazon Web Services , more radically, has developed 
into the fastest-growing and most profitable part of the group, using the same technology but a different model for 
the sale of computing power in the cloud, on demand.
"We could have stuck to the knitting. I'm glad we didn't," Jeff Bezos, Amazon's founder, said in his most recent letter 
to shareholders , while lauding AWS for adopting the same customer-focused approach as the rest of the business.
As for Uber, it is a fast-developing study in the inadequacy of simply laying out an Uber-for future and sitting back. 
Since it launched as a car-sharing service, the group has branched out into parcel dispatch, food delivery and self-
driving tech. It is running an evolving portfolio of business models. Next time you are tempted to describe an idea as 
the Uber for anything, bear this in mind: Uber itself is no longer just "Uber for" the thing it was once Uber for.
Twitter: @andrewtghill 
Load-Date: December 8, 2016
End of Document

the Uber for anything, bear this in mind: Uber itself is no longer just "Uber for" the thing it was once Uber for.

BEST OF THE BROKERS
BEST OF THE BROKERS
City A.M.
December 5, 2016 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 23
Length: 129 words
Body
Soft drinks maker Britvic has been downgraded to "neutral" from "buy" by Goldman Sachs and had its price target 
slashed to 600p from 810p, removing the stock from its conviction list following full-year results. The impending 
sugar tax was one of the reasons Goldman analysts have turned sour on the stock, with rising concerns around the 
company's expected performance in the new year.
RBC Capital Markets cut its stance on EasyJet's stock to "underperform" from "sector perform" arguing that without 
material and significant improvement in pricing outlook in the next three years, EasyJet shares will struggle to return 
a meaningful compound annual growth rate, the analysts say. RBC also pointed out that EasyJet has a lower return 
on equity than peers Ryanair and Wizz Air.
Load-Date: December 5, 2016
End of Document
Friday Papers: EU citizens push UK immigration to record 650,000
Friday Papers: EU citizens push UK immigration to record 650,000
Citywire
December 2, 2016 Friday 3:29 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 Citywire Financial Publishers All Rights Reserved
Length: 1140 words
Byline: Himanshu Singh
Highlight: And pound surges to eight-week high against dollar after Brexit minister hints at EU market access.
Body
Top stories
•
Financial Times: Immigration to Britain from the EU rose to a historic high in the run-up to the referendum 
in June, official figures have shown. 
•
The Daily Telegraph: Pound surges to eight-week high against dollar after Brexit minister hints at EU 
market access. 
•
Daily Mail: UK households face higher shop prices, sluggish economic growth, rising unemployment and a 
further interest rate cut next year, US investment bank Morgan Stanley warns. 
•
The Guardian: Starbucks CEO Howard Schultz will resign from position for second time; the billionaire, 
who stepped down in 2000 before returning during 2008 financial crisis, said he will focus on tech and 
‘social impact agenda’ in new role. 
•
The Daily Telegraph: UBS has merged most of its wealth management operations into a new business in 
Frankfurt, in a significant boost to the German city as it seeks to establish itself as a rival financial hub to 
London following Brexit. 
Business and economics
•
Daily Express: Ryanair is transforming package holidays after launching a service combining flights with 
accommodation and transfers. 
•
Daily Mail: Nokia phoenix firm set up by former employees to release new smartphone early next year.

Ryanair eyes to become Amazon of air travel with package holidays
Ryanair eyes to become Amazon of air travel with package holidays
City A.M.
December 2, 2016 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 14
Length: 162 words
Byline: REBECCA SMITH
Body
RYANAIR has launched a package holiday service, Ryanair Holidays, as it seeks to become the "Amazon of air 
travel".
It is offering its 119m customers flights, accommodation and transfer packages, partnering with Spainbased tour 
operator Logitravel and accommodation provider World2Meet to deliver the service.
It launched in the UK, Ireland and Germany yesterday, with other markets to follow next year.
Ryanair's chief marketing officer Kenny Jacobs said his firm wants to "transform the package holiday market".
"Consumers have been paying too much for package holidays for years and more and more want to put their own 
packages together themselves," he said.
Ryanair customers will be able to choose from a range of hotels throughout the Mediterranean and Europe's capital 
cities.
The company said it plans to undercut rivals by forgoing commissions often charged by holiday firms.
The company also launched Ryanair Car Hire and Ryanair Rooms this year as it aims to branch out.
Load-Date: December 2, 2016

Ex- EasyJet COO joins Stobart Group
Ex-EasyJet COO joins Stobart Group
AirFinance Journal
December 2016
Copyright 2016 Euromoney Institutional Investor PLC All Rights Reserved
Length: 245 words
Byline: Olivier Bonnassies
Body
Stobart Group has announced the appointment of Warwick Brady as deputy chief executive officer, effective 3 
January 2017.
Brady was chief operating officer of easyJet until 30 September 2016 and has extensive commercial and 
management experience which will be extremely valuable to the Group, as a whole, and its Aviation division, in 
particular.
He will join the board of directors following the group’s annual general meeting in June 2017.
Brady was instrumental in developing a highly efficient, low-cost, customer-focused operation and delivering 
significant value for shareholders at Easyjet. He has extensive aviation and broad business experience at senior 
level and has managed high growth, low cost airlines and start-up businesses.
He was chief executive officer at Mandala Airlines in Asia and spent two years as chief operating officer of Air 
Deccan/Kingfisher in India. Prior to that, Warwick was deputy operations director at Ryanair from 2002 to 2005, 
where he held various senior executive roles including deputy chief executive officer of Buzz, following its 
acquisition from KLM.
Group Stobart's chief executive officer Andrew Tinckler said: “I am delighted that Warwick has agreed to join us and 
I look forward to working with him. His commercial and operational experience will benefit the whole Group and his 
proven aviation industry expertise will provide added impetus as we build on the platform we have created in our 
aviation division.”
Load-Date: January 16, 2017

Retail inMotion develops pre-order IT solution
Retail inMotion develops pre-order IT solution
MarketLine NewsWire (Formerly Datamonitor)
December 1, 2016 Thursday 12:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 MarketLine All Rights Reserved
Section: TECHNOLOGY & TELECOMMUNICATIONS; Food
Length: 236 words
Highlight: Retail inMotion has developed a pre-order IT solution with the capability to allow passengers to choose 
from an airline's inflight meal selection before their date of departure.
Body
The pre-order solution, originally developed for Ryanair, is scalable and can be integrated into any airline&#39;s 
booking system to provide order information in real time."The development of our pre-order solution took just ten 
weeks and is a great picture of how customer-centric we are at Retail inMotion," stated Stefan Patermann, CCO 
Retail inMotion. "The implementation of the software extends passengers&#39; onboard experience to the ground 
and it is a true advantage for any airline looking to further develop their passenger interfaces."In combination with 
the rollout of the pre-order solution, Retail inMotion collaborated with Ryanair to introduce a premium Irish breakfast 
meal box for passengers. 
The hot breakfast, which has been flying on Ryanair flights from Dublin since October 1, includes a selection of 
traditional Irish breakfast items and is served with orange juice and a hot drink. Packaged in a picnic-style box that 
unfolds into a picnic blanket, the breakfast entices passengers to enjoy a traditional Irish meal in a non-traditional 
and entertaining way."We are pleased with the longstanding partnership we have cultivated with Retail inMotion. 
The implementation of the pre-order solution and continued support in developing innovative products allows us to 
further enhance our already high-quality and innovative onboard experience," commented Aoife Greene, Head of 
Inflight at Ryanair.

Ryanair have today launched a package holiday service, “Ryanair Holidays”, which will offer accommodation and

Lufthansa 's business image at stake in showdown with pilots
Lufthansa's business image at stake in showdown with pilots
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
November 29, 2016 Tuesday 2:29 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 695 words
Body
       By Andrew McCathie, dpa   The stakes are high for Lufthansa as it continues its long-running battle with pilots 
to make the savings it says are necessary to meet the challenges posed by new airline rivals. Will its image survive 
what seem to be never-ending rounds of labour stoppages?  FRANKFURT (dpa-AFX) - Lufthansa's shares faced a 
turbulent trading session on Tuesday amid the long-running industrial dispute between the German airline and its 
pilots. It's a dangerous game which threatens damage to the carrier's business image. 
 Germany's biggest airline has been forced to ground more than 1,700 flights scheduled for Tuesday and 
Wednesday after its pilots walked off the job at midnight Tuesday(2300 GMT Monday) in a pay battle with the airline 
that dates back to April 2014.  The airline had just endured a days-long labour stoppage last week, part of the same 
fight.  Lufthansa estimates the cost of the new industrial action at up to 10 million euros (10.6 million dollars) a day, 
with both sides hardening their positions as the pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit threatens to extend the strike 
beyond Wednesday.  'The conflict is only superficially about numbers,' said aviation analyst Heinrich 
Grossbongardt. 'At its core remains [the airline's] corporate strategy.  'The era of the flag-carrier, such as Lufthansa, 
is coming to an end and giving way to one of fierce competition with the low-cost airlines, which, of course, is linked 
to cuts in social services for employees,' said Grossbongardt.  Lufthansa is battling to cut costs and restructure its 
operations in the face of competition from budget rivals such as Ryanair and EasyJet in Europe and Middle Eastern 
airlines including Emirates and Etihad on long-haul routes.  Two-and-a-half years ago, Lufthansa chief Carsten 
Spohr promised to ease the industrial tensions between the airline and its pilots.  But the strikes set for Tuesday 
and Wednesday have thrown the travel plans of about 180,000 passengers into chaos. Lufthansa have now been 
hit by 15 pilot walkouts in the last two years.  This has raised questions about what impact the strikes eventually 
could have on the airline's customer base and business image.  Lufthansa's shares were down by nearly 2 per cent 
at one stage during Tuesday trading on the Frankfurt Stock Market, before they bounced back up 0.93 per cent 
later in the trading session.  The airline reported earlier this year that its adjusted earnings before interest and tax 
jumped 55 per cent to a record 1.82 billion euros in 2015 thanks to low fuel costs.  But now, the new round of 
strikes comes as part of the build-up to the crucial Christmas travel period, with Lufthansa's 5,400 pilots demanding 
a backdated 22-per-cent wage hike over five years until April 2017.  A Munich labour court on Monday rejected 
Lufthansa's call for an injunction to stop this week's planned industrial action.  That came after a court in Frankfurt 
Lufthansa 's business image at stake in showdown with pilots
last week rejected a similar request by Lufthansa for an injunction to stop a four-day pilots' strike, which ended 
Sunday.  Last week's industrial action resulted in the cancellation of 2,700 flights and left 350,000 passengers 
scrambling to make alternative travel arrangements.  The new industrial action has been sparked by a breakdown 
in talks between Lufthansa and the pilots, with Vereinigung Cockpit rejecting the management's new offer of a 4.4-
per-cent salary increase and a one-time payout equivalent to 1.8 months' salary.  'There is still no offer from 
Lufthansa on which to negotiate for the remuneration of the pilots, which means that the industrial campaign has to 
be continued,' Joerg Handwerg of Vereinigung Cockpit's executive committee said.  'Both parties are of the opinion 
that they are the stronger,' Hagen Lesch from the Institute of the German Economy told dpa.  'As long as everyone 
believes that 'we can beat the others,' we cannot expect a compromise,' Lesch said.  Lufthansa's budget airline 
operations Eurowings and Germanwings, as well as other carriers in the group - SWISS, Austrian Airlines, Air 
Dolomiti und Brussels Airlines - have not been affected by the pilots' strike.   Copyright dpa    
Load-Date: November 29, 2016
End of Document

Ryanair launches Cyber Monday sale
Business World (Digest)
November 28, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved

Length: 94 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
It was announced today that Ryanair have launched a Cyber Monday sale with up to 20% off 10 million seats.
The sale seats are for travel from December to March but must be booked by midnight tonight (24:00hrs Monday). 
The sale is part of the 8-day ‘Cyber Week’ campaign.
Ryanair's Chief Marketing Officer, Robin Kiely says, "Millions of customers have booked themselves a ‘Cyber 
Week’ bargain over the last week and to celebrate ‘Cyber Monday’ we’ve reduced fares by up to 20% on 10 million 
seats for travel from December to March."

More than 800 flights grounded as Lufthansa dispute intensifies
More than 800 flights grounded as Lufthansa dispute intensifies
Business World (Digest)
November 25, 2016 Friday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: EU
Length: 357 words
Byline: Sim Pinder
Body
German airline Lufthansa canceled around 830 flights on Friday because of a strike by pilots, with long-haul 
journeys facing disruption over the weekend as the dispute intensifies.
Shares in Lufthansa, down more than 13 percent this year, traded lower on Friday as investors fretted over the 
prospect of a long-running walkout at the German airline with neither pilots nor management appearing willing to 
back down.
One of Europe's biggest airlines, Lufthansa has canceled over 2,600 flights since pilots represented by the 
Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) union went on strike on Wednesday, disrupting travel plans for more than 315,000 
passengers.
The union raised the pressure on management and extended the strike for a third time on Thursday, saying all long-
haul flights leaving Germany on Saturday will be affected until midnight. The strike on Friday was affecting short 
and medium-haul flights.
The pilots' strike is their 14th walkout since early 2014. The union wants an average annual pay increase of 3.7 
percent for 5,400 pilots in Germany over a five-year period from 2012. Lufthansa has offered 2.5 percent over six 
years to 2019.
Lufthansa Chief Executive Carsten Spohr has said the carrier's future would be on the line if pilots' wages were 
raised to the level demanded.
Lufthansa insists that despite a record profit in 2015, it has no choice but to cut costs to compete with leaner rivals 
such as Ryanair on short-haul routes and Emirates on long-haul flights.
More than 800 flights grounded as Lufthansa dispute intensifies
Lufthansa has put the cost of the stoppage at around 10 million euros ($11 million) per day.
However, the airline could take a longer-term hit if the strike prompts customers to shun Lufthansa and switch to 
rival airlines. Board member Harry Hohmeister said on Thursday the walkout was hitting mid-term bookings.
Lufthansa shares traded 0.8 percent lower at 12.54 euros by 0900 GMT.
The airline has urged the union to enter mediation, but the union said it wants to see a better offer first.
It has already agreed deals with the main unions representing ground staff and cabin crew in Germany, leaving an 
agreement with its pilots outstanding. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: December 5, 2016
End of Document

Ryanair ditches Momondo for contract breach
Ryanair ditches Momondo for contract breach
City A.M.
November 25, 2016 Friday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 23
Length: 192 words
Byline: REBECCA SMITH
Body
RYANAIR has revoked a licencing agreement with travel search engine Momondo, saying it was due to a breach of 
contract.
The low-cost carrier said Momondo had "displayed links to unauthorised screenscraper websites including Opodo 
and CheapOair, which unlawfully missell Ryanair's low fares".
Ryanair has been plagued with trouble from so-called screenscraper sites, that copy data from other sites. 
EDREAMs has been a particular trouble for the airline over alleged issues with ticket sales and the failure to pass 
on accurate information to customers.
Yesterday, a German court ruled against eDreams, preventing unlawful and anti-consumer practices while mis-
selling Ryanair flights on the German website. It ordered the site to display the final price of flights at the beginning 
of the booking process and include all surcharges as levied by eDreams. A previous ruling in Germany stopped 
eDreams using Ryanair in its German domain name, with the airline saying the site was trying to dupe customers.
Ryanair's also embroiled in proceedings in the Irish High Court against Google and eDreams, saying it wants to 
stop consumers being misled by deceptive ads.
Load-Date: November 25, 2016
End of Document

WHAT THE OTHER PAPERS SAY THIS MORNING
City A.M.
November 23, 2016 Wednesday

Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 2
Length: 442 words
Body
FINANCIAL TIMES WILLIS TOWERS WATSON BOSS TO GET $21M PAY-OFF A top executive at Willis Towers 
Watson is to receive a pay-off of up to $21m when he leaves the insurance broker and consultant at the end of the 
year, according to documents analysed by the Financial Times. The payment to Dominic Casserley, the deputy 
chief executive, comes at the end of a year when shares in Willis Towers Watson have sharply underperformed 
those of its two main rivals.
NORTH POLE HEATING INCREASES CLIMATE FEARS Scientists are struggling to understand why a burst of 
"scary" warming at the North Pole has pushed Arctic temperatures nearly 20 degrees higher than normal for 
November. Experts are shocked by the soaring temperatures recorded in November, when much of the region is 
plunged into winter.
THE DAILY TELEGRAPH ECONOMISTS NEED TO GET INTO THE REAL WORLD Economists are too detached 
from the real world and have failed to learn from the financial crisis, insisting on using mathematical models which 
do not reflect reality, so said Bank of England chief economist Andy Haldane.
ASTRAZENECA APPROVED TO RESUME CANCER TRIALS AstraZeneca has resumed recruiting patients in 
trials on head and neck cancer after US regulators lifted a pause on the studies following cases of bleeding. The 
drug maker was testing whether its experimental drug was effective in prolonging the life of patients with head and 
neck cancer.
THE WALL STREET JOURNAL CARLYLE IN TALKS TO BUY CLOSELY HELD NOVOLEX Buyout firm Carlyle 
Group is in talks to buy packaging company Novolex for a price that could exceed $2.5bn. Novolex is owned by 
another private-equity firm, Wind Point Partners. Novolex's products include plastic bags and paper shopping bags 
used in grocery stores.
WHAT THE OTHER PAPERS SAY THIS MORNING
OVERTIME RULE TO GO INTO EFFECT BUT MAY NOT LAST US employers have spent months adjusting 
employee schedules, job duties and pay ahead of a new overtime rule that takes effect 1 December. The Obama 
regulation, which makes millions more workers eligible for overtime pay, may be scrapped in 2017.
THE TIMES RUDD FORCED TO RETHINK STUDENT WORK VISA PLANS Amber Rudd is set to back away from 
plans to allow only those foreign students who are at the UK's top universities to work in the UK after they graduate. 
A consultation on the student visa regime will now not be published until the new year. Whitehall sources say the 
home secretary, scarred by the reaction to her proposal to force firms to record foreign workers, is determined to 
avoid another immigration row.
RYANAIR BOSS FLOATS ZERO FARES IDEA Michael O'Leary, head of Ryanair, said he was considering moving 
from low fares to no fares for many travellers.

Michael O'Leary accuses UK Government of "lunatic optimism" over Brexit
Michael O'Leary accuses UK Government of "lunatic optimism" over Brexit
Business World (Digest)
November 23, 2016 Wednesday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 162 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
Michael O'Leary yesterday told the annual conference of the Airport Operators Association in west London, that 
Britain is on the verge of walking off a cliff by leaving the EU.
O'Leary also claimed Government Ministers in Britain have no idea what they are doing.
According to the Irish Independent, the Chief Executive of Ryanair told attendees at the conference, "If we get it 
wrong, I'm sure we'll come charging back into the UK with more aircraft and airports doing lower-cost deals. But 
frankly there's very little evidence apart from some mildly lunatic optimism over here that it will be all right on the 
night."
He added, "It's like Dad's Army going off to war here. It'll be all right, Sergeant (sic) Jones. You'll just keep plodding 
along. These guys have no idea where they're going for the next two years and the problem is that in the absence 
of any discussions with the Europeans on Brexit, they're all talking to themselves."

UK says Brexit will allow liberalisation of aviation market Ministers tell industry they will seek to maintain access 
to Europe, but agreements with third count....
UK says Brexit will allow liberalisation of aviation market; Ministers tell 
industry they will seek to maintain access to Europe, but agreements with 
third countries are possible
Flight International
November 22, 2016
Copyright 2016 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: AIR TRANSPORT
Length: 261 words
Body
As part of negotiations to leave the EU, UK officials will seek to maintain “liberal access” to European aviation 
markets and explore “new opportunities for further liberalisation”.
In a joint statement issued with the industry body Airlines UK following a round-table held with aviation industry 
representatives on 14 November, the government says maintaining market access with Europe is “a top priority”.
It also argues that Brexit provides “greater freedom to seek new agreements between the UK and some third 
countries”, including the potential for new bilateral agreements with the USA and Canada.
Other areas it says are of “critical importance” to be addressed during negotiations include “aviation safety, security, 
air traffic management, passenger rights, customs and the environment”.
The round-table, held at London City airport, was attended by Transport Secretary Chris Grayling and the Secretary 
for Exiting the EU, David Davis, along with industry representatives, including those from EasyJet, IAG, Monarch, 
Ryanair and Heathrow, letting ministers “hear their views on the Brexit negotiations”.
The government has pledged to trigger the formal two-year process of exiting the EU in March.
In their statement, the government and Airlines UK say they share “a determination to give as much early certainty 
to the sector as possible, given the long lead-in times associated with developing new routes – and to supporting 
the sector as much as possible in the interim”.
Heathrow airport and UK airlines were represented at the meeting
Gary Dawson/REX/Shutterstock
UK says Brexit will allow liberalisation of aviation market Ministers tell industry they will seek to maintain access 
to Europe, but agreements with third count....

Low-cost trailblazer Irelandia eyes Latin American growth Airline backer sees Argentina as potential market, as 
it plans order to fuel fleet expansion
Low-cost trailblazer Irelandia eyes Latin American growth; Airline backer 
sees Argentina as potential market, as it plans order to fuel fleet expansion
Flight International
November 22, 2016
Copyright 2016 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: AIR TRANSPORT
Length: 305 words
Body
Irelandia Aviation, a developer of low-cost carriers, could launch up to two new Viva-branded airlines in 2018, a 
year after Viva Air Peru begins flights.
One of the two new operations is likely to be in Argentina. “I won’t discount another one [besides Argentina] for 
2018,” says William Shaw, chief executive of VivaColombia, which is majority owned by Irelandia.
Shaw is co-founder of VivaColombia and is helping to get Viva Air Peru off the ground in the first half of 2017. The 
Peruvian airline will operate two Airbus A320s transferred from VivaColombia.
Irelandia plans to launch a request for proposals for an aircraft order that will enable the Viva group of carriers to 
grow, Shaw said at the ALTA Airline Leaders Forum in Mexico City. While VivaColombia and sister airline 
VivaAerobus operate A320s, Shaw does not rule out the Boeing 737.
“If you look at Irelandia’s history, you will see other airlines operating other aircraft,” he says. Ryanair, in which the 
holding company still has a stake, uses 737s, Shaw points out.
VivaColombia itself will take delivery of another four A320s in the coming months, besides the two reserved for Viva 
Air Peru. Its 11th A320, leased from GECAS, will arrive in December.
The carrier plans to launch at least two new domestic routes in 2017, and will add a fifth international destination in 
Cancun in the second quarter, serving the Mexican resort from Medellin.
Passenger numbers at the airline will hit 3.6 million this year, and are expected to climb to just over 5 million in 
2017.
VivaColombia will see more low-cost competition in its back yard, as Copa Airlines’ Bogota-based low-cost affiliate 
Wingo begins flights. LATAM Airlines Group also plans to debut unbundled fares on its domestic network in 
Colombia in 2017.
Low-cost trailblazer Irelandia eyes Latin American growth Airline backer sees Argentina as potential market, as 
it plans order to fuel fleet expansion
VivaColombia is to receive four more A320s in the coming months

European ADRs Edge Higher as Oil Stocks Gain Traction
European ADRs Edge Higher as Oil Stocks Gain Traction
MT Newswires Live Briefs
November 21, 2016 Monday 10:38 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 203 words
Body
 American depository receipts of European stocks were 0.74% higher at 114.90 on the Bank of New York Mellon 
Europe ADR Index on Monday morning. 
Gainers in Continental Europe were led by energy companies Statoil (STO), Total (TOT) and Eni (E), 3.8%, 2.4% 
and 1.9% higher, respectively. Forward Pharma (FWP),  a Danish biopharmaceutical company, was up by 1.8%. 
In the UK, gold mining company Randgold Resources (GOLD) was 3.1% higher, followed by education company 
Pearson (PSO), up by 3.1% and oil and gas production company Royal Dutch Shell -B Shares and A Shares 
(RDS.B, RDS.A), both 2.5% higher.
Decliners in Continental Europe were led by Aixtron (AIXG), a German provider of deposition equipment to the 
semiconductor industry, 7.7% lower, followed by Materialise (MTLS), a Belgian provider of 3D printing software and 
services, down by 3.2% and Ascendis Pharma (ASND), a Danish clinical stage biopharmaceutical company, 1.2% 
lower. Telecom Italia - Savings (TI.A), a telecommunications company, was down by 1.2%. 
And, in the UK, Midatech Pharma (MTP), an early-stage biopharmaceutical company, was 6.1% lower followed by 
low-cost airline Ryanair (RYAAY), down by 0.9%.
