EasyJet chief confident of navigating Brexit storms Europe's second-biggest low-cost carrier focuses on 
expansion, despite profit warning
EasyJet chief confident of navigating Brexit storms; Europe's second-
biggest low-cost carrier focuses on expansion, despite profit warning
Financial Times (London, England)
November 17, 2016 Thursday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 21
Length: 1099 words
Byline: Robert Wright, Transport Correspondent
Body
When easyJet announced its financial results a year ago, jihadist violence appeared to be the biggest cloud on an 
otherwise bright horizon for Europe's second-biggest low-cost airline.
The group had just flown thousands of passengers home early from Sharm el-Sheikh in Egypt, after a bomb 
brought down a Russian aircraft, while four days earlier 130 people had been killed in Paris.
The £686m pre-tax profit for 2015 nevertheless marked easyJet's fifth successive record year.
Since then the skies have darkened. EasyJet, led by Dame Carolyn McCall, has been buffeted by further acts of 
violence in some destinations, disruption from air traffic strikes, and the economic and political uncertainty triggered 
by the Brexit vote.
The airline issued a profit warning four days after the EU referendum, partly because it expected the uncertainty 
would deter people from travelling. On Tuesday it revealed that pre-tax profits dropped 28 per cent , to £495m, in 
the year to September 2016 . Its share price has fallen 40 per cent in the past year.
The threat that has generated much of the attention surrounding the airline is that it loses its membership of the 
single European aviation market - and with it the right to fly many of its routes - once the UK leaves the EU. Created 
EasyJet chief confident of navigating Brexit storms Europe's second-biggest low-cost carrier focuses on 
expansion, despite profit warning
in the 1990s, the single market allows EU airlines to operate services on any route within the bloc and has been 
crucial to easyJet's expansion.
Michael O'Leary, chief executive of rival Ryanair, has been quick to highlight the potential risks to easyJet's 
business if Brexit removes the right of UK-registered airlines to fly wherever they want within the union.
Dame Carolyn is not overly worried.
"We believe the government will end up achieving agreement between the UK and Europe," she says.
"We are the single largest aviation market in Europe and therefore it's in everybody's interests to have an 
agreement."
Even if the UK is shut out of some markets, she says the problem will be solved by setting up an EU-based 
subsidiary that will apply for an independent air operator certificate. EasyJet has such an arrangement in 
Switzerland.
The airline will register aircraft that fly entirely within the EU with the new company, whose location it will decide 
some time next year.
"By doing this, we secure our own flying rights and we're in control of our own destiny," says Dame Carolyn.
John Strickland, an independent aviation consultant, says it is too early to foresee the process's outcome. 
"[EasyJet] has to be very proactive on all fronts because of the very large element of uncertainty it contains," he 
says.
Dame Carolyn dismisses suggestions that the past year has revealed strategic weaknesses in the easyJet 
business. She brushes aside the idea that the lower costs of Ryanair give the Irish airline a critical advantage in 
such tough conditions. EasyJet still earned almost £500m in tough conditions, she points out.
"I think our easyJet team have done a really, really good job keeping our customers loyal, growing our ancillary 
revenues, doing everything we can on cost and revenue to ensure we deliver."
Dame Carolyn is focusing on maximising returns. Her strategy depends partly on exploiting the airline's strong 
position at big airports such as Amsterdam Schiphol and Paris Charles de Gaulle, where there is no capacity for 
new competitors such as Ryanair to come in.
"It's so difficult to replicate," she says of the company's network. "Ninety-eight per cent of what we do touches a 
primary airport where we're number one or number two."
She outlines plans for a 9 per cent capacity expansion in the year to September 2017, a step up from the 6.6 per 
cent in the last financial year.
She says this will narrow the airline's cost disadvantage by bringing in bigger, more efficient aircraft. Excluding fuel, 
easyJet's average cost to operate a seat on a flight - £38.31 (EUR44.44) - is 59 per cent higher than Ryanair's 
EUR28.
"It's a very clear strategy," Dame Carolyn says. "We've done a huge amount of analysis on how we make our 
money and where we make our money, even in a tough environment."
Many industry observers back easyJet's strategy, given how many of Europe's higher-cost legacy airlines have 
slipped into loss and face uncertain futures. Analysts at HSBC and Cantor Fitzgerald class the company's shares a 
buy, while Dublin's Davy Research has an "outperform" rating.
Mr Strickland predicts that both easyJet and Ryanair will emerge from the difficulties stronger.
EasyJet chief confident of navigating Brexit storms Europe's second-biggest low-cost carrier focuses on 
expansion, despite profit warning
"If you look at the total market share of the two together, it still leaves everything to play for, given the weakness of 
competitors that might yet fall by the wayside," he says.
Over the coming year, 20 per cent of easyJet's new capacity will come from replacing ageing A319 aircraft - which 
have only 156 seats - with 186-seat A320s.
The shift to bigger aircraft will help to close a key gap with Ryanair, which operates 189-seat Boeing 737s .
It is the kind of decision that Dame Carolyn insists is critical if the company is to emerge from the current storms.
"When you have short-term headwinds, people can make real mistakes," she says. "You have to be brave enough 
to look to the long term to make your company sustainably successful."
Capacity challenge
Rivals adopt differing fleet strategies
One apparent similarity between easyJet and Ryanair - which both have plans to expand capacity - belies the 
contrasting strategies of the two low-cost airlines.
Under its agreement with Boeing, Ryanair has little discretion over when it receives aircraft, according to Michael 
O'Leary , chief executive. It can choose only where to deploy the 40 or so 737s it receives annually from Boeing's 
Washington state plant.
The arrangement fits with Ryanair's "load factor active, yield passive" strategy - it cuts fares to ensure that each 
flight operates as close as possible to full.
EasyJet, by contrast, deliberately sought latitude from Airbus to delay or accelerate deliveries according to market 
conditions.
The airline also leases some of its fleet and terminates or extends the leases according to demand. The approach 
fits with easyJet's greater focus on ensuring new capacity is profitable.
Dame Carolyn McCall , easyJet's chief, insists the arrangement is a valuable safeguard.
While intending to expand capacity by 9 per cent in 2017 - a higher rate than the 6.6 per cent in the last financial 
year - easyJet is keeping its plans for the following three years under "regular and close review".
Dame Carolyn says: "If we see the numbers shifting or we see something that won't sustain that growth, we will be 
able to take that down". Robert Wright
Load-Date: November 16, 2016
End of Document
EasyJet risks the wrath of Sir Stelios as profits dip and capex soars
EasyJet risks the wrath of Sir Stelios as profits dip and capex soars
Financial Times (London, England)
November 16, 2016 Wednesday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: LOMBARD; Pg. 20
Length: 320 words
Byline: Jonathan Guthrie
Body
EasyJet plans to grow fast at the airport serving Venice, city of dreams and lovers. Also at Luton, town of industrial 
estates and Lorraine Chase, where the low-cost airline is headquartered. How will this play with Sir Stelios Haji-
Ioannou, shareholder of frosty communiqués and no-confidence votes? Badly, one fears.
EasyJet endured a stinker of a year. Terrorism closed some popular resorts in Muslim countries. Cheap fuel 
emboldened rivals to expand capacity. Weak sterling, in which easyJet reports, raised costs. Profits before tax 
crashed 28 per cent to £495m.
Yet the group, helmed by shrewd ex-Guardian boss Dame Carolyn McCall, plans to raise gross capex from £650m 
next year to more than £1bn in both 2018 and 2019. She wants to increase the fleet of Airbuses from 257 to more 
than 300. She believes the business, in which founder Sir Stelios controls 34 per cent of shares, will need more 
seats as legacy European airlines atrophy.
EasyJet has net cash of £213m and would shade into net debt only in 2018, the peak year for investment. The 
dividend payout is set at 50 per cent of post-tax profits.
Numis forecasts profits before tax of some £400m in 2017, equating to dividends 13.5p lower at 40.3p. The radars 
of stock market sky scanners are crowded with dangers. Perils include weakening UK confidence, political 
disruption to airline access agreements and further terrorism.
EasyJet risks the wrath of Sir Stelios as profits dip and capex soars
Dame Carolyn is doing a good job in tough circumstances. Shares trading at only a modest discount to Ryanair, 
whose business model is stronger, suggest many investors recognise that. There is countercyclical sense in her 
growth plan. The question is whether Sir Stelios and another 17 per cent of shareholders can still stomach it 
following such bad results.
The run-up to next February's annual meeting may otherwise resemble an altercation outside a Luton pub rather 
than a gondola ride along the Grand Canal.
jonathan.guthrie@ft.com 
Load-Date: November 15, 2016
End of Document
EasyJet profits drop on Brexit and terror fears Airlines
EasyJet profits drop on Brexit and terror fears; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
November 16, 2016 Wednesday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 20
Length: 455 words
Byline: Robert Wright, Transport Correspondent
Highlight: Budget carrier posts 28% fall as uncertainty reigns in year of shocks for sector
Body
EasyJet, the UK's biggest budget airline by sales, reported a 28 per cent decline in pre-tax profits for the past year 
as it grappled with economic uncertainty, terrorism, air traffic disruption and excess capacity.
Chief executive Dame Carolyn McCall called the performance "resilient" in a year of shocks for the sector.
The £495m pre-tax profit in the year to September 30 was down from £686m a year earlier but at the top end of the 
company's revised forecast range.
EasyJet was forced in June to issue a profit warning in the wake of the UK's vote to leave the EU. In October, it 
further trimmed pre-tax profit expectations, saying it anticipated a range of £490m to £495m.
Revenue declined 0.4 per cent to £4.67bn.
EasyJet's figures follow the third-quarter results from Ryanair, Europe's biggest budget airline by revenues, which 
recorded post-tax profits up 7 per cent to EUR1.17bn. EasyJet is the only significant airline to record its results in 
sterling and has consequently faced far bigger problems as a result of the fall in the value of the pound after the EU 
poll.
EasyJet profits drop on Brexit and terror fears Airlines
"EasyJet achieved a resilient performance in 2016, in the face of significant challenges including a series of 
external events and foreign exchange headwinds," Dame Carolyn said.
The company increased capacity on its flights by 6.5 per cent compared with the previous year, while the number of 
passengers carried rose 6.6 per cent, to 73.1m. Average load factors - the proportion of seats occupied on each 
flight - increased 0.1 percentage points to 91.6 per cent.
Dame Carolyn said that passengers had benefited from a third successive year of falling fares - revenue per seat 
declined 6.4 per cent to £58.46.
The company said it expected to increase capacity in the year to September 2017 by 9 per cent.
It also expected this year to spend £5m of the total £10m cost of acquiring an air operator's certificate in another EU 
country, to ensure the airline could continue operations between EU countries once the UK leaves the bloc. The 
airline already has an AOC in the UK and Switzerland.
"Looking ahead, the easyJet model remains strong, as does the demand environment and we continue to see 
opportunities in the medium term to grow revenue, profit and shareholder returns," Dame Carolyn said.
She added that almost half of the airline's growth next year would be in the UK, while there would also be 
"significant growth" in Switzerland, France and Italy.
The approach contrasts with that of Ryanair, Europe's biggest budget airline, which has reduced its planned growth 
in the UK and is concentrating on Germany in the wake of the Brexit vote.
Earnings per share declined 22 per cent to 108.7p, while the proposed dividend dropped 2.5 per cent to 53.8p.
See Lombard
Load-Date: November 15, 2016
End of Document
O'Leary forecasts airline shake-up on 'hard Brexit' fears Ryanair chief predicts major changes in carrier 
structures if UK is forced to leave European open skie....
O'Leary forecasts airline shake-up on 'hard Brexit' fears; Ryanair chief 
predicts major changes in carrier structures if UK is forced to leave 
European open skies system in future
Flight International
November 15, 2016
Copyright 2016 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: AIR TRANSPORT
Length: 328 words
Body
Ryanair may be forced to create a new subsidiary to operate UK domestic flights if a “hard Brexit” comes to pass, 
chief executive Michael O’Leary says.
Speaking at a media briefing in London on 7 November, O’Leary suggested that under the “worst” outcome, the UK 
would be forced to leave the European open skies system as it exits the EU, which would prevent Ryanair as a 
European carrier from continuing to operate routes from London to Belfast, Edinburgh and Glasgow.
The Irish carrier would then need to establish a separate UK company, of which Ryanair would be able to own a 
maximum of 49.9%, O’Leary says.
He questions whether the UK would be able to reintroduce bilateral agreements. “It’s almost impossible to restore 
bilaterals because they’re based on flag carriers and most countries don’t have flag carriers anymore,” he says.
O’Leary speculates that in a hard Brexit scenario EasyJet’s exposure to the UK market would be “unsustainable” 
and require the airline to gain a European air operator’s certificate. He also sees a possibility that IAG – which owns 
Aer Lingus, BA, Iberia and Vueling – could be broken up under European ownership rules.
“BA/IAG gets broken up because you can’t have a British airline in the same ownership as three European airlines, 
because you have ownership restrictions as well as the AOCs,” he says.
“So I think either British Airways gets sold out by IAG and becomes a majority UK-owned airline or, alternatively, 
Iberia, Aer Lingus and Vueling get sold out of British Airways and IAG.”
If the UK remains part of the open skies area, however, O’Leary foresees “no change” in the ownership structures 
of Ryanair or UK carriers.
O'Leary forecasts airline shake-up on 'hard Brexit' fears Ryanair chief predicts major changes in carrier 
structures if UK is forced to leave European open skie....
Airlines have, he discloses, been invited to a “round table” discussion organised by the government department 
charged with negotiating the UK’s exit from the EU to discuss the impact this will have on their sector.
Outspoken CEO supported vote to remain ahead of EU referendum

Load-Date: November 18, 2016

Irish carrier has 'no desire' to push new 737's range to the Max
Irish carrier has 'no desire' to push new 737's range to the Max
Flight International
November 15, 2016
Copyright 2016 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: AIR TRANSPORT
Length: 149 words
Body
Michael O’Leary, the chief executive of Ryanair, has made the case against operating Boeing 737 Max 
narrowbodies on transatlantic routes.
O’Leary says he has “no desire” to use Ryanair’s on-order Max jets for US services, arguing: “You can only get to 
the East Coast and that’s not a soundly-based transatlantic area. You have to be able to get to both East Coast and 
West Coast.”
O’Leary declines to comment on Norwegian’s plans to deploy the Max across the Atlantic from June 2017, 
however.
Flight Fleets Analyzer shows Ryanair has ordered 100 737 Max 8s, of the Max 200 variant, and has options for 
another 100. Deliveries are to begin in 2019.
O’Leary says Ryanair paid a “small premium” to secure deliveries in that timeframe, but adds: “They have 4% more 
seats and 16% lower fuel costs on a per-passenger basis. We are happy to pay Boeing a premium for that.”

ViaSat Acquires Ireland -based Arconics - Quick Facts
ViaSat Acquires Ireland-based Arconics - Quick Facts
RTT News (United States)
November 14, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 RTT News All Rights Reserved
Length: 310 words
Body
(RTTNews) - Internet services provider ViaSat Inc. (VSAT) said it has acquired Arconics, an Ireland-based provider 
of software solutions to the aviation industry. Financial terms of the deal were not disclosed.
Arconics, registered as Aerodocs Limited in Ireland, offers enterprise software and mobile applications for aircraft 
operators.
ViaSat noted that through the acquisition, it will gain connected aircraft software, wireless in-flight entertainment, 
mobile applications and airline document management expertise. The company will also gain applications that will 
make entertaining passengers as well as opening new service and revenue opportunities for airlines possible.
The Arconics connected aircraft software platform enables the Arconics App Suite, which spans wireless In-flight 
Entertainment or IFE, Electronic Flight Bag or EFB, Airline Document Management and Cabin Management 
solutions, to communicate and share data with the aircraft.
Using available connectivity, it will also enable to connect with ground systems across mobile or avionics platforms.
Airline customers include Qatar Airways, Cathay Pacific, Ryanair, Aer Lingus, Philippine Airlines, Tigerair Australia, 
SpiceJet and others.
In connection with the acquisition, ViaSat will establish a presence in Dublin, Ireland, and will continue to build its 
operations in Sydney, Australia. More than 30 Arconics team members with both technical and business expertise 
will join ViaSat, including Arconics Chief Executive Officer Niall O'Sullivan.
The transaction is not expected to materially affect ViaSat adjusted pro forma earnings for fiscal year 2017. 
However, ViaSat has not completed its valuation analysis and, accordingly, has not determined the impact to its 
reported earnings.
For comments and feedback: contact editorial@rttnews.com

Ryanair Holdings Must Repay Illegal Austrian Airport Aid, European Commission Says
Ryanair Holdings Must Repay Illegal Austrian Airport Aid, European 
Commission Says
MT Newswires Live Briefs
November 11, 2016 Friday 12:28 PM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 202 words
Body
 Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY) and German airline Tuifly must repay aid that they received illegally from the operator 
of the Klagenfurt airport in Austria, the European Commission said Friday.
The regulator said that "certain airport services and marketing agreements concluded between the airport operator 
and airlines Ryanair, HLX and Tuifly gave the latter an undue advantage, which cannot be justified under EU state 
aid rules," and that this must now be repaid.
"As no profit-driven airport manager would have concluded such loss-making agreements, they amount to state aid 
to the airlines," the Commission said. "Moreover, the agreements simply reduce the operating costs of the airlines, 
without contributing to common transport objectives. These agreements therefore distort competition in the single 
market in breach of EU state aid rules."
The Commission said the amounts of incompatible state aid are estimated at around EUR2 million ($2.2 million) for 
Ryanair and EUR1.1 million for Tuifly and they now have to pay these amounts back to Austria. In addition, HLX, 
which was merged with Hapagfly in 2007 into the new brand Tuifly, has to repay EUR9.6 million.
Price: 82.71, Change: +0.27, Percent Change: +0.33
Load-Date: November 12, 2016
End of Document
EU orders Ryanair to repay illegal Austrian airport aid
EU orders Ryanair to repay illegal Austrian airport aid
Business World (Digest)
November 11, 2016 Friday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 202 words
Byline: Sim Pinder
Body
EU state aid regulators have ordered Irish budget airline Ryanair and German travel company TUI's unit TUIfly to 
repay millions of euros in illegal aid given by an Austrian airport.
"Certain airport services and marketing agreements concluded between the airport operator and airlines Ryanair, 
HLX and TUIfly gave the latter an undue advantage, which cannot be justified under EU state aid rules," the 
European Commission said on Friday.
HLX merged with Hapagfly in 2007 into the new brand TUIfly.
"The amounts of incompatible state aid are estimated at around 2 million euros for Ryanair, 1.1 million euros for 
TUIfly and 9.6 million euros for HLX," the EU competition enforcer said. The companies will have to repay the 
money to Austria.
Ryanair said it would fight the EU ruling. TUIfly had no immediate comment.
The case concerns Klagenfurt airport in the south of Austria.
"We note the Klagenfurt decision, where we stopped flying in 2013. We disagree with the findings and have 
instructed our lawyers to appeal," a Ryanair spokesman said.
The Commission also found that aid granted to the airport by its public owners between 2000 and 2011 was in line 
with EU state aid rules. (Reuters)
 Source: www.businessworld.ie

Europe ADR Index on Tuesday morning.

biopharmaceutical company, 2.3% lower.

Ryanair : web spinning
Ryanair: web spinning
Financial Times (London, England)
November 8, 2016 Tuesday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: LEX COLUMN; Pg. 14
Length: 327 words
Body
Spiders are the original networkers. Their carefully wrought weavings feed them from area traffic. So it goes with 
internet businesses, which ensnare both the casual browser and those hunting for a specific deal. Once, Ryanair 
might not have made the most of its online potential, but that time has past. Its website claims the highest traffic of 
any airline. Now this site is itself becoming a money-spinner.
Yesterday's interim report illustrated this. Ancillary revenues from its online ticket site, everything from reserved 
seat charges to hotel deals, have picked up to 22 per cent of sales. Growth here is so strong that the airline has 
revised its target to 30 per cent (from a fifth) by 2020. Ryanair's chief executive Michael O'Leary wants to "disrupt" 
travel sites such as Priceline's Booking.com and TripAdvisor via his own Ryanair Rooms. He asserts Ryanair can 
win business from overcharged suppliers, passing savings to flyers via cheaper seats.
Whether these extra slugs of revenue will keep Ryanair's margins strong is another matter. Operating margins, 
estimated at 23 per cent in the full year to March, are at a decade high.
European capacity has expanded steadily, in no small part owing to Ryanair's new fleet nearly doubling its capacity 
by 2024. Partly as a result, per-passenger revenues have already dropped 8 per cent. Fares are expected to 
decline a tenth for the full year.
Mr O'Leary's organisation, though, has enough bend in its fibre to withstand any future storms. Ryanair's low unit 
costs have already compressed enough to accommodate the most recent deflation. Should operating profitability 
Ryanair : web spinning
return to the average of the past decade, around 15 per cent, Ryanair's taxed free cash flow would very likely 
remain positive.
Ryanair's latest prey are the intermediaries in the online travel industry. Mr O'Leary wants a sticky network, catching 
and holding its customers for the right reasons. This new business will help achieve his aim.
Load-Date: November 7, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair hikes forecast but still has Brexit blues
Ryanair hikes forecast but still has Brexit blues
City A.M.
November 8, 2016 Tuesday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 4
Length: 264 words
Byline: CAITLÍN MORRISON; REBECCA SMITH
Body
BUDGET airline Ryanair reported an increase in profits during the first half of 2016, despite what boss Michael 
O'Leary described as "difficult market conditions" post-Brexit. Revenue rose two per cent in the three months to 30 
September, to (EURO)4.13bn (£3.68bn) from (EURO)4.04bn.
Profit after tax was up seven per cent, from (EURO)1.09bn this time last year to (EURO)1.17bn, and earnings per 
share rose 15 per cent to (EURO)0.92 from (EURO)0.80.
Investors had been braced for the weaker sterling to impact full-year profits and the airline warned last month that 
would be the case.
It has announced plans to return (EURO)550m to shareholders via a share buyback and hiked its long-term growth 
forecast by 10 per cent. Ryanair expects to carry 200m passengers per year by 2024. But it warned that weakened 
air fares and Brexit uncertainty will be "the dominant features" of the second half of the year.
The airline's chief executive told the BBC that while business was "booming", the environment was "bearish" after 
the vote to leave the EU in June.
O'Leary was particularly unimpressed with the government's handling of the proceedings, saying it had "no idea" as 
to how it will actually deliver Brexit.
He said Prime Minister Theresa May was "faffing around in India", when Brussels was the place she should be 
focusing on to get trade deals done. The Prime Minister is in India for her first bilateral trip outside of the EU, and 
vowed to "reboot" the relationship between the two nations.
Ryanair hikes forecast but still has Brexit blues
May plans to sign a raft of commercial deals while out there, expected to generate 1,370 jobs.

Ryanair lifts growth forecast as profits rise Airlines
Ryanair lifts growth forecast as profits rise; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
November 8, 2016 Tuesday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 20
Length: 450 words
Byline: Robert Wright, Transport Correspondent
Highlight: Carrier to cut fares amid 12% increase in estimates of passenger numbers
Body
Ryanair, Europe's biggest budget airline, increased its long-term growth forecast by more than 10 per cent as it said 
continued pressure on fares and falling costs would enable it to win more of the continent's air travel market.
The company made the projection yesterday after announcing better than expected half-year results that Michael 
O'Leary , chief executive, described as "creditable" despite a European air travel market facing uncertainties , 
including the UK's vote to leave the EU. Post-tax profits rose 7 per cent to EUR1.17bn on revenues up 2 per cent to 
EUR4.13bn.
The company raised its forecast for full-year passenger numbers to 119m - a 12 per cent increase on the year to 
March. That led it to forecast that it would carry 200m passengers annually by 2024, up from its previous forecast of 
180m.
Mr O'Leary said that the company's significant order book - it is due to receive about 40 new aircraft annually over 
the next eight years - meant it was bound to continue growing.
"We don't have discretion over the capacity," Mr O'Leary said. "We have discretion over how we allocate the 
capacity."
Ryanair lifts growth forecast as profits rise Airlines
Ryanair would continue to drive down ticket prices through its strategy of cutting fares to ensure its aircraft fly as full 
as possible. "The question for us is whether we can continue to drive down costs," he said.
Shares in Ryanair closed up 5 per cent in Dublin yesterday at EUR13.40.
The results follow a profit warning on October 18, when the company trimmed its forecast for profits for the year to 
March 2017 by around 5 per cent, to a range of EUR1.3bn-EUR1.35bn. The warning blamed the 18 per cent 
decline in sterling against the euro following June's Brexit vote. Ryanair, which is based in Dublin, expects to 
generate around 26 per cent of this year's revenue in sterling.
The company reiterated that, because of the uncertainty surrounding Brexit, it expected reduced economic growth 
in the UK and Europe more widely, and planned to shift some planned growth next year away from the UK towards 
mainland Europe.
Mr O'Leary, who campaigned for the UK to remain within the EU, said that it was difficult to forecast the long-term 
outcome of the Brexit process because ministers had no clear strategy. However, that meant that, for the time 
being, little had changed beyond the fall in sterling.
"It's a shambles and long may it continue to be a shambles," he said.
Average fares in the first half fell 10 per cent to EUR50, while passenger numbers grew 12 per cent to 65m.
Ryanair also announced a EUR550m programme of share buybacks over the three months to February. Mr O'Leary 
said that, thanks to recent declines in the share price, buybacks made more sense than dividend payments.
See Lex

No Headline In Original
No Headline In Original
Flight International
November 8, 2016
Copyright 2016 Reed Business Information Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: FEATURES
Length: 648 words
Body
Most airline pilots approach their annual recurrent training simulator time with apprehension. They perceive the 
exercise to be more about testing than training or learning, and with most airlines there is a lot of truth in that 
perception.
Some airlines provide more recurrent training than regulations require because flight operations data monitoring 
(FDM) – a requirement in Europe – flags up what crews need to practice. But still most train only to the legal 
minimums, partly for cost reasons, and partly because the compulsory exercises are defined – albeit based on 
aviation as it was in the 1970s.
gdsgfgsfsggfs
Additional training may be costly, but incidents, particularly related to shortcomings flagged up by FDM, could be 
even more expensive. At Ryanair, head of training Capt Andy O’Shea has come up with a solution: helping pilots to 
train themselves. At no cost, Ryanair pilots can book a fully capable flight simulation training device (FSTD) for the 
Boeing 737-800, and practice the skills they know they need to improve, with just a colleague in the other seat: no 
instructor and no “Big Brother” oversight.
Ryanair’s plan, already launched, is to bring on stream nine additional advanced fixed-base FSTDs beyond those 
needed to cope with growth. Three are already up and running, and early trials show it is popular with crews who 
have tried it – 96% say they would book the device again.
O’Shea has long wanted to give pilots the opportunity to develop their skills in their own time, but the carrier’s 
investment in sophisticated equipment has to be justified. So he needed a scheme to discourage misuse that might 
result in what he calls a “negative training” experience. That is, how can Ryanair give pilots the freedom to learn but 
discourage them from barrel-rolling a 737-800 for fun, all while convincing them that Big Brother isn’t watching?
A compromise is suggested in the programme’s name: Ryanair Controlled Training. The pilots who voluntarily book 
the simulator time will be alone and unwatched in the device. It has a normal, fully capable instructor operating 
station, but that does not have to be manned. When pilots book the session, they can choose from a menu of 
No Headline In Original
“lesson plans” entailing an origin, a destination and flight plan, and they upload it to the simulator when they start 
the session.
Pilots start by loading the simulator with the payload and weather data they need to derive performance figures for 
the “flight and “take off”. They don’t know what else will happen en-route: but things will.
If the crew has trouble with a scenario, they can freeze the simulator and discuss it, or try again. Sessions are 
recorded but O’Shea says: “We have no desire or intention to review each session for video or FDM events. Our 
hope is that crews come to the FTD, practice their skills, improve their knowledge and leave feeling good about 
themselves.”
fdsfdsfdsdfssfd
So if exceeding FDM limits will not trigger the curiosity of the Ryanair training department, what would? One event 
is straying outside the 737’s flight envelope; that freezes the simulator, which then has to be re-set. Why that occurs 
would matter. For example, upset prevention training (UPT) is programmed into some lesson plans, but recovery 
from extreme attitudes is not.
Usage so far shows bookings by captains at 19% of the total, first officers 37%, and cadets 44%. O’Shea says the 
new system provides a whole array of motivations for voluntary pilot bookings, including: maintaining handling or 
raw data flying skills, UPT, left-hand seat practice for prospective captains, right-hand seat practice for prospective 
instructors, and improving recurrent simulator training core competencies.
McCaren/LNP/REX/Shutterstock
sector
Quote – text. The style for quotes. Put a hard return at end of each line for the rule”
XxxxxUs atquisse parum fugitatur, et audis mod expero to bla venisci anim

Ryanair shares surge on plans to carry 200 million by 2024
Ryanair shares surge on plans to carry 200 million by 2024
Associated Press Financial Wire
November 7, 2016 Monday 12:58 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 Associated Press All Rights Reserved
Section: BUSINESS NEWS
Length: 383 words
Byline: By SHAWN POGATCHNIK, Associated Press
Dateline: DUBLIN 
Body
DUBLIN (AP) - Ryanair shares rose 5 percent on Monday after Europe's top budget airline said it expects to carry 
more than 200 million passengers annually by 2024, 11 percent higher than previously forecast.
The Dublin-based carrier offered the stronger long-term outlook as part of its half-year results for the tourism-driven 
April-September period, when the airline carries the bulk of its customers.
Ryanair shook off last month's profits warning pegged to the summer slide in the value of the British pound 
following the United Kingdom referendum to leave the European Union. Ireland is in the euro currency zone but 
Ryanair does 26 percent of its business in Britain, where customers pay for products priced in sterling.
The airline said it carried 65 million passengers in the first half of the fiscal year, a 12 percent gain versus April-
September 2015. Sales increased 2 percent to 4.1 billion euros ($4.6 billion) while net profit rose 7 percent to nearly 
1.19 billion euros ($1.32 billion).
Ryanair expects to carry a company-record 119 million passengers in this fiscal year as the airline pursues a 
strategy of relentless expansion across the continent, most prominently Germany.
Chief Executive Michael O'Leary says Ryanair plans this winter to expand services in Berlin and Frankfurt and open 
six new bases in the German cities of Hamburg and Nuremburg as well as Bucharest, Romania; Prague, Czech 
Republic; Vilnius, Lithuania, and Bournemouth on England's south coast.
O'Leary said he stood by the airline's negatively revised profits forecast issued in mid-October anticipating net 
profits of 1.3 billion euros to 1.35 billion euros when full-year fiscal 2017 earnings are published in May. He said 
profits would be constrained by the airline's policy of filling aircraft by offering steeply discounted fares when 
necessary.
Fares fell 10 percent in the April-September period to an average price of 50 euros ($55.35) per one-way ticket, an 
approach that allowed Ryanair to set a new load factor record of 95 percent of seats sold.
Ryanair shares surge on plans to carry 200 million by 2024
Ryanair shares surged on the Irish Stock Exchange to a 4 1/2-month high of 13.54 euros, nearly reaching a level 
last seen hours before the U.K. vote June 23 to leave the EU. The shares were at 13.42 euros ($14.85) in midday 
trading, up 5.1 percent on the day.
Load-Date: November 8, 2016
End of Document
European Stocks Rise Led by Banks, Miners After FBI Clears Clinton on E-Mails
European Stocks Rise Led by Banks, Miners After FBI Clears Clinton on E-
Mails
MT Newswires Live Briefs
November 7, 2016 Monday 5:26 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 392 words
Body
 European stocks were higher on Monday morning amid speculation that Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton might 
be getting closer to winning the US presidential race after the FBI cleared her of any wrongdoing in connection with 
her use of a private e-mail server for work when she was Secretary of State. 
The FBI said on Sunday it concluded a probe into newly discovered e-mails and found no reason to change its July 
conclusion that it found no evidence of criminal conduct and it won't prosecute her, according to news reports. 
Stock were up even as a report by Destatis, Germany's statistics office showed that new orders in manufacturing 
decreased 0.6% in September from August with both domestic and export orders falling. 
Oil prices were also supportive of equity markets after Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) 
Secretary General Mohammed Barkindo said Russia is "on board" with an OPEC agreement to limit crude oil 
production to stabilize the market, Bloomberg reported. OPEC has yet to agree on the details of the plan and is 
scheduled to meet on November 30 to do so.
Brent, the international crude benchmark, rose 1.3% to $46.18 per barrel and the US West Texas Intermediate 
gained 1.7% to $44.81 a barrel at the time of writing.
In equities, mining companies advanced, with BHP Billion (BHP) rising 4% and Antofagasta (ANTO.L) up 3.9% in 
London.  High street bank HSBC (HSBC) gained 4% with the rest of the European financial services sector even 
after it said third-quarter reported profit before tax tumbled 86% after booking a loss on the sale of its Brazilian 
business. Natixis (KN.PA) rose 3.7% in Paris and Deutsche Bank advanced 3.3% in Frankfurt. BNP Paribas 
(BNP.PA)  added 3.5%,  Sociate Generale (GLE.PA)  gained 2.3% in Paris. 
European Stocks Rise Led by Banks, Miners After FBI Clears Clinton on E-Mails
Irish low-cost airline Ryanair (RYA.L) gained 5.3% in London after the budget carrier raised its long-term passenger 
forecast. Symrise (SY1.DE), a German supplier of fragrances, flavorings and cosmetic active ingredients, rose 
26%, making it the best performer on the benchmark STOXX 600. 
The pan-European STOXX 600 index rose 1.2%, its biggest jump in more than a month, after falling for 10 out of its 
last 11 sessions. The euro-region blue-chip STOXX 50 index rose 1.7% and the DAX in Frankfurt was up by 1.7%. 
The FTSE 100 in London rose 1.5% and the CAC 40 in Paris gained 1.8%.

Ryanair Approves $610 Million Share Buyback, Second Quarter Earnings, Revenue Rise
Ryanair Approves $610 Million Share Buyback, Second Quarter Earnings, 
Revenue Rise
MT Newswires Live Briefs
November 7, 2016 Monday 6:13 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 375 words
Body
 [The headline of this article has been corrected to state that the share buyback is worth $610 million from an earlier 
version which stated $610 billion.]
Irish low-cost airline Ryanair (RYA.LO) said that it had approved its eighth share buyback on Monday after posting 
gains in its second quarter earnings and revenue and ramping up its forecast for annual passenger volumes 
through to 2024.
The group, which operates 1,800 daily routes and connects 33 countries, generated total operating revenues from 
continuing operations of 2.44 billion euros ($2.70 billion) in the three months ended September 30, according to 
results published on Monday. This marked a 2% increase on the prior year period. Pre-tax profit rose by 6% to 1.02 
billion euros and diluted earnings per share rose 17% to 72.34 cents over the same time-frames.  
The company said that a 550 million euro share buyback had been approved by its board over the four-month 
period from November 2016 to February 2017. It said that it now expects to carry just over 119 million customers in 
the fiscal year 2017 and said that this stronger growth requires it to raise its "long-term traffic forecast by over 10% 
from 180 million to over 200 million customers per annum by March 2024." 
Going forward, it said that it  remains "cautious" in its outlook for fiscal year 2017 and reiterated its revised full year 
guidance for profit to rise to a range of 1.30 billion to 1.35 billion euros. 
The group said that uncertainty over the final outcome of the UK's departure negotiations with the European Union 
(EU) following the nation's referendum decision to exit the EU,  would continue to overhang its business for fiscal 
year 2018. 
The group generates approximately 26% of its revenues from the UK and said that it expects to see weaker Sterling 
and slower economic growth both in the UK and in Europe. As a result, it said that it had reduced its planned UK 
Ryanair Approves $610 Million Share Buyback, Second Quarter Earnings, Revenue Rise
growth in 2017 from 12% to approximately 5%, and switched this capacity to accelerate growth in markets such as 
Italy, where it said that the the government had cut taxes, Germany, where it said that incumbent carriers continue 
to restructure, and other markets such as Belgium, where it said that competitors are closing routes and bases.

Body
 American depository receipts of European stocks were 1.2% higher at 115.81 on the Bank of New York Mellon 
Europe ADR Index on Monday morning. 
Gainers in Continental Europe were led by Flamel Technologies (FLML), a French pharmaceutical company, 8.0% 
higher, followed by Natuzzi (NTZ),  an Italian furniture manufacturer, up by 4.4% and ArcelorMittal (MT), a 
Luxembourg steelmaker, up by 4.1%. 
In the UK, low-cost airline operator Ryanair (RYAAY) was 5.4% higher after approving its eighth share buyback, 
posting gains in its second quarter earnings and revenue and ramping up its forecast for annual passenger volumes 
through 2024. High street bank HSBC (HSBC) and Amarin (AMRN), a biopharmaceutical company, were both 4.3% 
higher. 
Decliners in Continental Europe were led by Edap (EDAP), a French medical devices developer, and Cellectis 
(CLLS), a French genome engineering company, both 2.2% lower, followed by Nabriva Therapeutics (NBRV), an 
Austria-based clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company, down by 2.1%. 
And, in the UK, gold mining major Randgold Resources (GOLD) was 1.9% lower, followed by National Grid (NGG),  
an electricity and gas utility company, 0.8% lower.

European shares led higher by banks
European shares led higher by banks
Business World (Digest)
November 07, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: EU; World
Length: 384 words
Byline: Business World
Body
European shares rallied on Monday, underpinned by stronger banking stocks, as news that Hillary Clinton would 
not face charges over her use of emails gave her bid for the White House fresh momentum just before the Nov. 8 
vote.
By 0922 GMT, the STOXX 600 was up 1.4%. Last week the pan-European index made its biggest weekly loss 
since February on growing uncertainty over the U.S. vote's outcome.
But Clinton got a fresh boost over Republican rival Donald Trump after the FBI said on Sunday it stood by its earlier 
finding that no criminal charges were warranted.
"With this result being seen as a positive for her chances of winning tomorrow's election, the market has opened 
with a risk-on tone," Rabobank analysts wrote in a note.
While no sector was trading in the red, banks led the gainers, helped by a more than 4% surge in HSBC . The 
emerging markets-focused bank had posted a sharp jump in its core capital, bolstering the outlook for near-term 
dividend payments.
"The key feature of the numbers is the reported CT1 (core tier 1 ratio) of 13.9% and leverage ratio of 5.4%, 
substantially ahead of expectations and management's target," said UBS, which rates the stock as "neutral."
Italy's Intesa, BNP Paribas and Deutsche Bank rose between 2.6% and 3.4%. Analysts had said banks would suffer 
in particular by any policy uncertainty created by a Trump presidency.
European shares led higher by banks
Ryanair, up 5.6%, was another gainer after a well-received earnings update. Europe's largest carrier by passengers 
cut its annual profit forecast due to a weaker pound, but said it expected to boost its market share in the coming 
months by selling more tickets at cheaper prices.
The top STOXX gainer was PostNL, gaining 5.8%, after the Dutch postal company rebuffed a raised takeover offer 
from Belgian rival Bpost, saying it wished to remain an independent group.
Among top losers were Zalando, which fell more than 2% following a two-notch downgraded to "sell" from UBS, and 
precious metals miners Fresnillo and Randgold , which were supported last week as investors sought safe haven 
assets due to concerns over the U.S. vote's outcome.
Analysts at Deutsche Bank said a Clinton victory could lift Europe's STOXX index by around 5%, while uncertainty 
linked to a Trump win could see it fall 5-10%. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
About us

End of Document
Ryanair lifts passenger growth forecast as price war hits rivals
Ryanair lifts passenger growth forecast as price war hits rivals
Business World (Digest)
November 07, 2016 Monday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: IRELAND
Length: 561 words
Byline: Robert McHugh
Body
Budget airline Ryanair raised its long-term passenger growth forecast by 10% on Monday to 200 million travelers a 
year by 2024, saying it planned to take advantage as intense fare competition forces higher-cost rivals to retrench.
It also announced it would return an additional 550 million euros to shareholders by February in a share buyback, a 
move that helped lift its share price by 6%.
Ryanair cut its profit forecast last month by 5% for the year to March due to sterling weakness and lower average 
fares, but it still expects to outperform most rivals by increasing profits by 7% in the year to the end of March.
With the lowest cost base in the industry and a strategy of filling planes irrespective of air fares, it says it is uniquely 
positioned to take advantage of current low fares to boost market share.
"We have EU incumbents retrenching, restructuring...creating more and more opportunities for Ryanair, particularly 
in primary airports," Chief Executive Michael O'Leary said in a video presentation.
"The second half of the year will be difficult in a weaker pricing environment, but we expect that with a huge cost 
advantage over every other carrier in Europe, Ryanair is well positioned to continue to grow strongly."
Ryanair said it plans to grow capacity by 13% this winter compared to an industry average increase of around 9% - 
the highest level of capacity growth in the industry in a decade.
Already Europe's largest carrier by passenger numbers, Ryanair said it hopes to lift its share of the European short-
haul market from 15% to over 20% by 2024. It will defer the retirement of around 40 planes to boost capacity to 585 
Boeing Co 737 airliners by 2024.
Ryanair lifts passenger growth forecast as price war hits rivals
Ryanair shares have outperformed many of their peers in recent months as the sector struggled to come to terms 
with Britain's vote to leave the European Union and a flood of capacity that has driven down prices.
Its share price of 13.42 euros at 0956 GMT was 2% below its level before Britain's vote to leave the European 
Union was announced, compared to a fall of around 20% in the European airline sector as a whole.
Profit after tax for the six months to the end of September was 1.17 billion euros, in line with analyst forecasts.
British Airways owner IAG stuck to its main long-term earnings and margin growth targets on Friday but scaled back 
its plans to expand capacity.
Budget rival easyJet warned in October that annual profit had fallen by more than a quarter and hinted that trading 
would remain tough.
While a sharp fall in fuel prices in the past two years has allowed airlines to cut prices, Ryanair managed to cut non-
fuel per-passenger costs by 5% compared to last year, in part by cutting the number of empty seats on flights.
O'Leary said Ryanair was also benefiting from cheaper financing and lower plane costs thanks to its size.
While Ryanair built its business by striking low-cost deals with small airports far from city centers, by the end of this 
year it will for the first time be flying mainly to primary airports.
Last week it announced plans to fly from Lufthansa's home hub of Frankfurt.
The Airports Council International Europe trade body on Monday described Ryanair's move into Frankfurt as a 
"turning point for European air travel" as low-cost carriers increasingly compete with legacy rivals at the continent's 
largest airports. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
Load-Date: November 15, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair H1 Profit Down, Revenues Rise; Says Cautious In FY17 Outlook
Ryanair H1 Profit Down, Revenues Rise; Says Cautious In FY17 Outlook
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
November 7, 2016 Monday 7:23 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 294 words
Body
       DUBLIN (dpa-AFX) - Irish no-frills airline Ryanair Holdings Plc (RYA.L, RYAAY) reported Monday that its first-
half profit after tax declined to 1.17 billion euros from last year's 1.41 billion euros. Earnings per share fell to 91.76 
euro cents from 102.66 euro cents a year ago.  The prior year results included an exceptional accounting gain of 
317.5 million euros on sale of Aer Lingus shareholding. 
Excluding the item, profit increased 7 percent, and earnings per share grew 15 percent.  Total operating revenues - 
continuing operations grew 2% to 4.13 billion euros from 4.04 billion euros last year.  The company noted that lower 
fares delivered 12% traffic growth to 64.8 million customers and a 2% jump in load factor to 95%.   Average fares 
fell 10% to 50 euros, however first-half unit costs also fell by 10%.  The results were achieved amid the difficult 
market conditions due to repeated ATC strikes, terror events, and the adverse economic impact of the Brexit vote in 
June which saw Sterling weaken materially over the peak summer period, the company said.  Looking ahead, the 
company said it remains cautious in outlook for fiscal 2017.   The company expects fares will continue to fall, and 
unit costs will fall by approximately 3% this year.  The company expects to carry just over 119 million customers in 
FY17 and this stronger growth requires it to raise long term traffic forecast by over 10% from 180m to over 200m 
customers p.a. by March 2024.  Further, the company said the uncertainty over Brexit, and the final outcome of the 
UK's departure negotiations with the European Union, will continue to overhang its business for fiscal 2018. The 
company expects to see weaker Sterling and slower economic growth in both the UK and Europe.      
Load-Date: November 7, 2016
End of Document
European Markets Rallied After FBI Cleared Hillary Clinton
European Markets Rallied After FBI Cleared Hillary Clinton
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
November 7, 2016 Monday 5:56 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 756 words
Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - The European markets ended the first session of the new trading week with a strong gain. 
Following the weak performance of the previous week, the markets jumped in early trade and settled into a 
sideways trend for the rest of the session. Banks stocks turned in a strong performance following a solid earnings 
report from HSBC. Airlines were also among the gainers after a strong report from Ryanair. 
 Investors cheered the news that the FBI has once again cleared U.S. Democratic presidential nominee Hillary 
Clinton of criminal charges related to her use of a private email server while Secretary of State.  'Based on our 
review, we have not changed our conclusions that we expressed in July with respect to Secretary Clinton,' FBI 
Director James Comey wrote in a letter sent to members of Congress on Sunday.  Late last month, Comey 
revealed that the FBI re-opened its probe of Clinton after learning of the existence of new emails on a device 
obtained in connection with an unrelated investigation.  U.S. officials familiar with the case said told the Washington 
Post the new emails were either personal or duplicative of those found earlier.  The pan-European Stoxx Europe 
600 index advanced 1.41 percent. The Euro Stoxx 50 index of eurozone bluechip stocks increased 1.85 percent, 
while the Stoxx Europe 50 index, which includes some major U.K. companies, added 1.45 percent.  The DAX of 
Germany climbed 1.93 percent and the CAC 40 of France rose 1.91 percent. The FTSE 100 of the U.K. gained 1.70 
percent and the SMI of Switzerland finished higher by 1.87 percent.  In Frankfurt, Deutsche Bank climbed 4.82 
percent and Commerzbank rose 5.01 percent.  Daimler advanced 2.28 percent and BMW added 2.09 percent.  In 
Paris, Renault rose 2.96 percent on news that the car maker plans to open a manufacturing plant in Pakistan by 
2018. Peugeot also added 2.97 percent.  BNP Paribas increased 3.73 percent and Societe Generale gained 3.49 
percent. Credit Agricole also finished higher by 2.23 percent.  In London, HSBC Holding climbed 4.62 percent after 
the lender reported a third-quarter pre-tax profit that beat analysts' estimates.  Mining giant Rio Tinto gained 3.57 
percent after an annual tender of diamonds from its Argyle mine in Western Australia achieved the highest average 
price per carat since the tender began in 1984.  Irish no-frills airline Ryanair Holdings jumped 4.97 percent after 
reporting a 7 percent increase in half yearly after tax profits, and lifting its long-term traffic growth forecast by 10 
percent.  PostNL rallied 3.80 percent in Amsterdam after the postal company rejected a raised takeover offer from 
Belgian rival Bpost.  Eurozone investor confidence strengthened to a 11-month high in November, survey data from 
Sentix showed Monday. The Sentix investor confidence index rose to 13.1 from 8.5 in October. The score was well 
European Markets Rallied After FBI Cleared Hillary Clinton
above the expected level of 8.9.  Eurozone retail sales annual growth slowed for a second straight month in 
September to mark its weakest pace in two years, preliminary data from Eurostat showed Monday. Retail sales 
grew a calendar adjusted 1.1 percent year-on-year following 1.2 percent increase in August, revised sharply from 
0.6 percent. Economists had forecast a gain of 1.2 percent.  German factory orders contracted unexpectedly in 
September, largely reflecting weak domestic demand and orders from euro area, figures from Destatis showed 
Monday. Factory orders fell 0.6 percent in September from August, when they grew by a revised 0.9 percent. This 
was the first fall in three months and the biggest since April. Orders were forecast to grow 0.2 percent.  Germany's 
construction sector expanded at the fastest pace in six months in October, driven by solid growth in housing and 
commercial activity, survey figures from IHS Markit showed Monday. The construction Purchasing Managers' Index, 
or PMI, rose to 52.9 in October from 52.4 in the previous month.  U.K. house prices increased at a slower pace in 
October, data published by the mortgage lender Halifax showed Monday.  In three months to October, house prices 
climbed 5.2 percent from previous year, following a 5.8 percent rise in three months to September. October's 5.2 
percent was the lowest yearly growth rate since July 2013.  The U.K. private sector growth picked up in the three 
months to October, the latest growth indicator from the Confederation of British Industry showed Sunday. The 
growth indicator rose to +8 percent from +3 percent in three months to September.

European Shares Rally As FBI Closes Clinton Email Probe
European Shares Rally As FBI Closes Clinton Email Probe
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
November 7, 2016 Monday 11:33 AM GMT

Body
       VIENNA (dpa-AFX) - European stocks are rallying on Monday, as the FBI's dramatic climbdown on an 
investigation into the alleged email scandal boosted Hillary Clinton's odds of winning the U.S. presidential election 
and HSBC posted a surprise jump in adjusted third-quarter pretax profit.  The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 
index is currently up 1.2 percent at 332.71 in late opening deals after losing 0.8 percent in the previous session.   
The German DAX is rallying 1.6 percent, France's CAC 40 index is moving up 1.8 percent and the U.K.'s FTSE 100 
is up 1.3 percent. 
  Banks are among the best performers, with HSBC Holding shares climbing 4.5 percent after the lender reported a 
third-quarter pre-tax profit that beat analysts' estimates.  Commerzbank, Deutsche Bank, Credit Agricole, BNP 
Paribas, Societe Generale Group, Unicredit and BBVA are up 2-4 percent.  PostNL shares are rallying 5.5 percent 
after the Dutch postal company rejected a raised takeover offer from Belgian rival Bpost.  Mining giant Rio Tinto is 
gaining 3 percent in London after an annual tender of diamonds from its Argyle mine in Western Australia achieved 
the highest average price per carat since the tender began in 1984.  Irish no-frills airline Ryanair Holdings is adding 
5 percent on reporting a 7 percent increase in half yearly after tax profits, and lifting its long-term traffic growth 
forecast by 10 percent.  Renault shares are up 2.5 percent in Paris on news that the French car maker plans to 
open a manufacturing plant in Pakistan by 2018.  In economic releases, figures from Destatis showed that German 
factory orders contracted unexpectedly in September largely due to a fall in domestic demand. Factory orders fell 
0.6 percent from August, when it grew by revised 0.9 percent.  Separately, survey figures from IHS Markit showed 
that activity in German construction sector expanded at the fastest pace in six months in October, driven by solid 
growth in housing and commercial activity.  The euro zone investor confidence index produced by the Frankfurt-
based Sentix group rose to an 11-month high of 13.1 in November from 8.5 in October.  The pound slipped back 
below $1.24 as the dollar strengthened and data published by mortgage lender Halifax showed that U.K. house 
prices increased at a slower pace in the three months to October.

Ryanair H1 Profit Down, Revenues Rise; Says Cautious In FY17 Outlook

(RTTNews) - Irish no-frills airline Ryanair Holdings Plc (RYA.L, RYAAY) reported Monday that its first-half profit 
after tax declined to 1.17 billion euros from last year's 1.41 billion euros. Earnings per share fell to 91.76 euro cents 
from 102.66 euro cents a year ago.

RTT News (United States)

Body
(RTTNews) - The European markets ended the first session of the new trading week with a strong gain. Following 
the weak performance of the previous week, the markets jumped in early trade and settled into a sideways trend for 
the rest of the session. Banks stocks turned in a strong performance following a solid earnings report from HSBC. 
Airlines were also among the gainers after a strong report from Ryanair.
Investors cheered the news that the FBI has once again cleared U.S. Democratic presidential nominee Hillary 
Clinton of criminal charges related to her use of a private email server while Secretary of State.
"Based on our review, we have not changed our conclusions that we expressed in July with respect to Secretary 
Clinton," FBI Director James Comey wrote in a letter sent to members of Congress on Sunday.
Late last month, Comey revealed that the FBI re-opened its probe of Clinton after learning of the existence of new 
emails on a device obtained in connection with an unrelated investigation.
U.S. officials familiar with the case said told the Washington Post the new emails were either personal or duplicative 
of those found earlier.
The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index advanced 1.41 percent. The Euro Stoxx 50 index of eurozone bluechip 
stocks increased 1.85 percent, while the Stoxx Europe 50 index, which includes some major U.K. companies, 
added 1.45 percent.
The DAX of Germany climbed 1.93 percent and the CAC 40 of France rose 1.91 percent. The FTSE 100 of the U.K. 
gained 1.70 percent and the SMI of Switzerland finished higher by 1.87 percent.
In Frankfurt, Deutsche Bank climbed 4.82 percent and Commerzbank rose 5.01 percent.
Daimler advanced 2.28 percent and BMW added 2.09 percent.
In Paris, Renault rose 2.96 percent on news that the car maker plans to open a manufacturing plant in Pakistan by 
2018. Peugeot also added 2.97 percent.
BNP Paribas increased 3.73 percent and Societe Generale gained 3.49 percent. Credit Agricole also finished 
higher by 2.23 percent.
European Markets Rallied After FBI Cleared Hillary Clinton
In London, HSBC Holding climbed 4.62 percent after the lender reported a third-quarter pre-tax profit that beat 
analysts' estimates.
Mining giant Rio Tinto gained 3.57 percent after an annual tender of diamonds from its Argyle mine in Western 
Australia achieved the highest average price per carat since the tender began in 1984.
Irish no-frills airline Ryanair Holdings jumped 4.97 percent after reporting a 7 percent increase in half yearly after 
tax profits, and lifting its long-term traffic growth forecast by 10 percent.
PostNL rallied 3.80 percent in Amsterdam after the postal company rejected a raised takeover offer from Belgian 
rival Bpost.
Eurozone investor confidence strengthened to a 11-month high in November, survey data from Sentix showed 
Monday. The Sentix investor confidence index rose to 13.1 from 8.5 in October. The score was well above the 
expected level of 8.9.
Eurozone retail sales annual growth slowed for a second straight month in September to mark its weakest pace in 
two years, preliminary data from Eurostat showed Monday. Retail sales grew a calendar adjusted 1.1 percent year-
on-year following 1.2 percent increase in August, revised sharply from 0.6 percent. Economists had forecast a gain 
of 1.2 percent.
German factory orders contracted unexpectedly in September, largely reflecting weak domestic demand and orders 
from euro area, figures from Destatis showed Monday. Factory orders fell 0.6 percent in September from August, 
when they grew by a revised 0.9 percent. This was the first fall in three months and the biggest since April. Orders 
were forecast to grow 0.2 percent.
Germany's construction sector expanded at the fastest pace in six months in October, driven by solid growth in 
housing and commercial activity, survey figures from IHS Markit showed Monday. The construction Purchasing 
Managers' Index, or PMI, rose to 52.9 in October from 52.4 in the previous month.
U.K. house prices increased at a slower pace in October, data published by the mortgage lender Halifax showed 
Monday.
In three months to October, house prices climbed 5.2 percent from previous year, following a 5.8 percent rise in 
three months to September. October's 5.2 percent was the lowest yearly growth rate since July 2013.
The U.K. private sector growth picked up in the three months to October, the latest growth indicator from the 
Confederation of British Industry showed Sunday. The growth indicator rose to +8 percent from +3 percent in three 
months to September.

a surprise jump in adjusted third-quarter pretax profit.
The pound slipped back below $1.24 as the dollar strengthened and data published by mortgage lender Halifax

The benchmark FTSE 100 is currently up 89 points or 1.34 percent at 6,782 in opening deals, on track to snap its

(RTTNews) - European stocks are rallying on Monday, as the FBI's dramatic climbdown on an investigation into the 
alleged email scandal boosted Hillary Clinton's odds of winning the U.S. presidential election and HSBC posted a 
surprise jump in adjusted third-quarter pretax profit.
The pan-European Stoxx Europe 600 index is currently up 1.2 percent at 332.71 in late opening deals after losing 
0.8 percent in the previous session.
The German DAX is rallying 1.6 percent, France's CAC 40 index is moving up 1.8 percent and the U.K.'s FTSE 100 
is up 1.3 percent.
Banks are among the best performers, with HSBC Holding shares climbing 4.5 percent after the lender reported a 
third-quarter pre-tax profit that beat analysts' estimates.

2-4 percent.

fastest pace in six months in October, driven by solid growth in housing and commercial activity.
European Shares Rally As FBI Closes Clinton Email Probe

Ryanair in for bumpy landing on sterling dip
Ryanair in for bumpy landing on sterling dip
City A.M.
November 7, 2016 Monday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 14
Length: 254 words
Byline: REBECCA SMITH
Body
LOW-COST carrier Ryanair has suffered some turbulence post-Brexit, predominantly fuelled by the plummeting 
sterling, and investors are braced for a bumpy landing in its upcoming results.
Full-year profits are expected to grow five per cent lower than previous estimates of seven per cent.
The revised guidance, provided last month, reflected that average air fares had dropped by 13-15 per cent, 
compared with the previously guided drop of 10 to 12 per cent.
Analysts at Davy emphasised that the earnings cut was driven by the sterling dip but its "business model and free 
cash flow generation still leaves Ryanair as the stand-out winner in the European airline industry".
The pound hit record lows in the wake of the EU referendum result and has struggled to recoup its losses since 
then.
Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary has said the airline will focus its expansion away from its central base in the UK, 
because of the vote to leave the EU.
The budget airline recently announced ambitious plans to expand with a new base at Frankfurt airport.
This made Ryanair the first of the low-fare airlines to open one at Germany's biggest airport.
But the chief executive of airport operator Fraport, Dr Stefan Schulte, said it was now "responding to the strong and 
growing demand in our region for this aviation segment".
Ryanair in for bumpy landing on sterling dip
Ryanair also announced a major recruitment drive last month saying it is gearing up to hire 2,000 cabin crew, 1,000 
pilots and 250 engineers.
The Irish airline also announced plans to add a further 50 planes to its fleet.

Ryanair reports 7-per-cent rise in half-year profit
Ryanair reports 7-per-cent rise in half-year profit
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
November 7, 2016 Monday 11:59 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 148 words
Body
       LONDON (dpa-AFX) - Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost airline, on Monday said its profit rose 7 per cent to 
1.17 billion euros (1.29 billion dollars) in the first six months of its financial year, despite a 10-per-cent fall in its 
average fare to 50 euros.  The airline said it also cut costs per seat by 10 per cent year-on-year and opened 73 new 
routes as it carried some 65 passengers from April to September, up 12 per cent.  Ryanair owner Michael O'Leary 
said the half-yearly results showed 'a creditable performance in difficult market conditions,' citing problems including 
strikes by air traffic control staff, the effect of terrorist attacks, and a plunge in the pound since Britain's Brexit vote 
in June.  Ryanair warned last month that it expects its annual net profit to fall by up to 125 million euros, mainly due 
to the fall in the British currency.   Copyright dpa
