British Airways owner reins in ambitions Airlines
British Airways owner reins in ambitions; Airlines
Financial Times (London, England)
November 5, 2016 Saturday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: UK COMPANIES; Pg. 16
Length: 453 words
Byline: Robert Wright, Transport Correspondent
Highlight: IAG trims targets for profits, capacity and capital expenditure
Body
Shares in International Airlines Group fell 4 per cent yesterday after the owner of British Airways cut its long-term 
core profit target, in the latest sign of the challenges facing Europe's airlines.
At its annual investor day, IAG also cut its targets for planned capital spending and growth in capacity.
Like other European carriers the group, which owns Spain's Iberia, BA, Ireland's Aer Lingus and Vueling, a Spanish 
budget airline, has been grappling with difficult market conditions created by excess capacity and a series of 
external shocks.
This summer airlines have faced economic uncertainty following the UK's vote to leave the EU, which came on top 
of the negative impact of terrorist attacks in mainland Europe and strikes by air traffic controllers.
Last month IAG blamed a "tough operating environment", including the fall in the value of sterling since the Brexit 
referendum, for a near 4 per cent drop in operating profit during its third quarter.
However, it is regarded by some analysts as being in a stronger position than Lufthansa and Air France-KLM 
because it has made deeper cost cuts to try to compete with budget airlines led by Ryanair and easyJet.
British Airways owner reins in ambitions Airlines
IAG said yesterday it was cutting its target for average annual earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, 
amortisation and rent for the period from 2016 to 2020 from EUR5.6bn to EUR5.3bn.
The group also reduced its target for annual capital expenditure from EUR2.5bn to EUR1.7bn.
Capacity, meanwhile, would grow at an annual rate of 3 per cent, down from a former range of 3 to 4 per cent.
The shares closed down 3.6 per cent to 434.7p in London.
Robin Byde, analyst at Cantor Fitzgerald, said the group's target trimming might indicate that the cycle for European 
airlines had turned.
"IAG is an increasingly complex airlines group," he said. "Diversity can be positive but evaluating the earnings 
drivers for the group as a whole is more difficult."
Mark Simpson at Goodbody said the reduced capital spending should bolster free cash flow and provide scope for 
share buybacks.
Alex Cruz, BA chief executive, outlined plans to make the best possible use of the UK flag carrier's powerful 
position at London's Heathrow airport, one of the world's most attractive hubs.
He confirmed that BA intended to introduce more flights to European tourist destinations from the airport in the 
summer months, to counteract a downturn in demand for business travel.
BA also plans to introduce Boeing 777 passenger jets on long-haul routes operating out of London Gatwick.
Mr Cruz portrayed the move as enabling BA to compete more effectively with Norwegian Air Shuttle, which is 
operating long-haul routes from Gatwick with modern, cost-efficient Boeing 787 Dreamliners.
Load-Date: November 4, 2016
End of Document
Air France - KLM bets on budget long-haul unit Interview: Jean-Marc Janaillac
Air France-KLM bets on budget long-haul unit; Interview: Jean-Marc 
Janaillac
Financial Times (London, England)
November 4, 2016 Friday
USA Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: COMPANIES; Pg. 17
Length: 961 words
Byline: Michael Stothard in Paris
Highlight: Move threatens to reignite tensions with group's powerful trade unions
Body
The new head of Air France-KLM yesterday revealed plans to create a low-cost, long-haul unit within Air France; a 
move that threatens to reignite tensions with the group's powerful trade unions.
Jean-Marc Janaillac told the FT that the Franco-Dutch group must adopt an "offensive mindset" to improve its 
competitiveness or it would "end up like Alitalia", the Italian flag carrier that ran up losses for years and now has 
Etihad Airways as its largest shareholder .
Mr Janaillac, who became group chief executive in July, signalled he was willing to confront Air France's unions, 
which have in the past made efficiency reforms difficult. "It will be a tough negotiation, but they have to understand 
that the status quo is no longer possible."
The most contentious cost-cutting measure in his new group strategy is the creation of a company inside Air France 
that will operate 10 per cent of long-haul routes, and whose pilots and cabin crew are expected to have less 
generous contracts compared with those at the French flag carrier's main business.
This would be a way to improve Air France's efficiency, which lags behind European budget airlines led by easyJet 
and Ryanair, but also fast-expanding Gulf carriers such as Emirates.
Air France - KLM bets on budget long-haul unit Interview: Jean-Marc Janaillac
Air France-KLM's shares rose more than 6 per cent yesterday to EUR5.77, but several unions with members at the 
airline expressed hostility to the plans.
Mr Janaillac is widely considered to have one of the toughest jobs in aviation. Attempts by the previous Air France-
KLM chief Alexandre de Juniac to expand the group's budget airline Transavia on short-haul routes prompted the 
longest strike in Air France's history in 2014 because unions regarded his plans as a strategy to lower wages.
Since then, industrial relations at Air France have been poor and Mr de Juniac was unable to fully implement his 
cost-cutting measures . A new low was reached last year when, after a tense employee meeting about 2,900 job 
cuts, the airline's human resources director had his shirt torn off by an angry mob.
Mr Janaillac confirmed he would persist with Transavia, and focus its operations on France and the Netherlands, "in 
order to fight against low-cost competition and the [high-speed] trains".
He said he hoped that, as a "new face", his talks with the unions would be better than those of his predecessor. He 
is replacing the head of Air France, Frédéric Gagey , with Franck Terner , who was boss of the group's engineering 
and maintenance unit.
Mr Janaillac said he intended to explain to the unions that to increase capacity by 2 to 3 per cent each year until 
2020, Air France must generate cash to "renew the fleet and buy new planes", and that in turn meant the airline had 
to "cut costs and become more competitive".
"My bet is that [Air France] staff are ready to make a deal this time to secure the long-term future of the company 
and start growing again," he said. "It is a bet though."
Air France's longstanding problems focus on its high operating costs compared with certain competitors and its 
large debt load.
But, as with other European airlines, Air France has been contending in recent months with economic and political 
uncertainty stemming from the UK's vote in June to leave the EU, the negative impact of terrorist attacks in 
mainland Europe including France and strikes by air traffic controllers.
Yesterday, Air France-KLM reported that its operating profit dropped 16 per cent to EUR737m in the July to 
September period compared with one year earlier, while revenue fell 5.1 per cent to EUR6.9bn. The group recorded 
net debt of EUR4.2bn at September 30.
Mr Janaillac said he was positively surprised by the strength of Air France's brand, service and its alliances with 
other airlines.
He was, however, disappointed to discover the "lack of trust" within the group, both between Air France and KLM, 
and between management and staff. He also saw the group's "financial situation", "competitiveness" and 
"organisation structure" were not good enough.
Mr Janaillac's plans to set up a low-cost, long-haul flying unit within Air France have some similarities with an 
initiative by Lufthansa.
Eurowings, Lufthansa's budget airline focused on short-haul routes, last year began flying to long-distance 
destinations including the Caribbean.
A more radical cost-cutting approach was taken by International Airlines Group at its subsidiary Iberia in 2012, 
when the Spanish flag carrier was running up losses. IAG set out plans to cut Iberia's workforce by 20 per cent , 
and capacity by 15 per cent, and it subsequently returned to profit.
British Airways, IAG's main subsidiary, also cut costs in 2011 at its long-haul operations by reducing the number of 
cabin crew on certain flights and paying new recruits less.
Air France - KLM bets on budget long-haul unit Interview: Jean-Marc Janaillac
All the established European airlines have come under pressure from a newer breed of long-haul carriers. These 
have been led by the Gulf airlines, but also carriers such as Malaysia's AirAsia X, which are seeking to replicate the 
low-cost, short-haul business model on long-haul routes.
Some analysts questioned whether Mr Janaillac's cost-cutting plans went far enough.
Damian Brewer, analyst at RBC Capital Markets, said the plans did not look sufficient to enable Air France-KLM to 
escape its "high debt balance sheet, high unit cost base". He added the proposal for the low-cost, long-haul flying 
unit within Air France risked "being seen by the union as a stalking horse for deeper changes later; ie to cease 
growing the legacy Air France and grow the new unit over time".
The SNPL pilots union said it was willing to start negotiations with Mr Janaillac on a positive footing.
But Emmanuel Mistrali, union president, said it would not countenance having different contracts for staff in Air 
France's low-cost, long-haul flying unit.
Load-Date: November 3, 2016
End of Document
EasyJet climbs after broker spotlights discount to rival London
EasyJet climbs after broker spotlights discount to rival; London
Financial Times (London, England)
November 3, 2016 Thursday
London Edition 1
Copyright 2016 The Financial Times Ltd. All Rights Reserved Please do not cut and paste FT articles and redistribute by email or post to the 
web.
Section: MARKETS & INVESTING; Pg. 27
Length: 437 words
Byline: Bryce Elder
Body
An upgrade from HSBC helped buoy easyJet , the FTSE 100's second-worst performing stock of 2016.
HSBC switched easyJet from "reduce" to "buy" with an £11.50 target price. While Ryanair and easyJet "remain the 
long-term strategic winners in the market with solid strategic positions and strong balance sheets", recent weak 
trading means easyJet shares sit at a 35 per cent discount to Ryanair based on mid-cycle earnings multiples, it told 
clients.
"If management does not fix this struggling business, we think someone else will," the broker added. "Its pan-
European network, portfolio of slots in constrained airports and well recognised brand position should make it an 
attractive opportunity for carriers looking to consolidate what is currently an unstable business."
EasyJet closed 2.9 per cent higher at 968p, which narrowed its loss for the year-to-date to 44 per cent.
A sterling rally and a sharp drop for oil meant the wider market struggled, with the FTSE 100 sliding 1 per cent, 
down 71.72 points at 6,845.42.
Standard Chartered slipped a further 4.3 per cent to 644.1p as forecast downgrades followed Tuesday's quarterly 
results, which damped hopes of a return to revenue growth and a restart of dividends.
EasyJet climbs after broker spotlights discount to rival London
Berenberg forecast StanChart's return on equity to remain below 5 per cent compared with the 2018 target of 8 per 
cent when management first set out its turnround plan .
Barclays faded 2.5 per cent to 182.1p on word of a cautious briefing from Tushar Morzaria , its finance director, to 
Deutsche Bank analysts.
Among issues discussed was the rising cost to service Barclays' coco bonds , about three-quarters of which are 
non-sterling denominated and are unhedged against sterling's recent devaluation.
Heroin substitute maker Indivior jumped 10.6 per cent to 350.4p after boosting full-year earnings guidance with 
better than expected quarterly results. Lower research costs combined with resilient demand for Suboxone film 
against generic and branded rivals, to eclipse news of a $220m exceptional provision for litigation costs.
Security outsourcer G4S rose 10.3 per cent to 242.8p on the back of an unscheduled trading update, which showed 
organic growth accelerating.
Aggreko hit a seven-year low, down 2 per cent to 765.5p. The generator hire specialist has begun contract renewal 
talks in Argentina, where analysts expect 35 per cent price cuts, and faces increased competition in emerging 
markets from Karpowership, a Turkish ship maker that is rapidly expanding its fleet of floating power stations.
Potash mine developer Sirius Minerals dropped 10.1 per cent to 33.3p after setting out a $900m fundraising .
Load-Date: November 2, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair sticks to its post-Brexit expansion plans
Ryanair sticks to its post-Brexit expansion plans
City A.M.
November 3, 2016 Thursday
Edition 1, National Edition
Copyright 2016 City A.M. All Rights Reserved
Section: NEWS; Pg. 9
Length: 301 words
Byline: REBECCA SMITH
Body
RYANAIR is branching out, but not in the UK. The no-frills airline is spreading its wings and opening a base at 
Frankfurt airport.
That makes it the first low-cost carrier to open a base at Germany's biggest airport as the rise of budget carriers 
continues.
Michael O'Leary, Ryanair's chief executive, has said the airline will focus expansion away from its central base in 
the UK, because of the Brexit vote.
Frankfurt had been the last of Europe's big hub airports to hang onto "legacy" airlines, but is bowing to the 
popularity of the low-cost names, with Ryanair the first through the doors. It will launch the new base from the end 
of March 2017.
The chief executive of airport operator Fraport, Stefan Schulte, said it was "responding to the strong and growing 
demand in our region for this aviation segment".
The Irish airline will have two Boeing 737s there; an investment of $200m (£162m) for the company, along with four 
new routes to Alicante, Faro, Malaga and Palma. There will be 28 weekly flights, with the expectation that Ryanair 
will deliver over 400,000 customers per year through Frankfurt airport.
Ryanair's chief commercial officer, David O'Brien, said: "Our two based aircraft represent an investment of $200m, 
which further underlines our commitment to growing traffic, tourism and jobs in the Hessen region.
Ryanair sticks to its post-Brexit expansion plans
We look forward to working closely with Fraport to deliver industry leading efficiencies and further growth at 
Germany's biggest airport."
The development also signals Ryanair stepping up its battle with Lufthansa; Frankfurt airport is the German airline's 
main base. It has been facing difficulties of late with strikes as it tries to lower costs and expand its own budget unit, 
Eurowings. Frankfurt is the third busiest airport in the EU, after Heathrow and Charles de Gaulle in Paris.
Graphic
 
Ryanair earlier said Brexit would mean its new routes would not be out of the UK
Load-Date: November 3, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair passenger numbers increase 13% in October
Ryanair passenger numbers increase 13% in October
Business World (Digest)
November 03, 2016 Thursday
Copyright 2016 Media World Ltd. All Rights Reserved
Section: GENERAL
Length: 128 words
Byline: Business World
Body
Ryanair have today released figures which show that traffic grew 13% to 10.9m customers in October. Load factor 
rose 1% point to 95% and rolling annual traffic to Oct grew 16% to 114.4m customers.
Ryanair will start flying from Frankfurt airport to tourist destinations in Spain and Portugal, the airline and airport 
operator Fraport said on Wednesday.
The once-daily flights to Palma de Mallorca, Alicante, Malaga and Faro will start from the end of March, they said, in 
a move flagged by Reuters on Tuesday.
The news will provide a further headache for Fraport's main customer Lufthansa, which has slowed growth at its 
main brand and has faced strikes while it tries to lower costs and expand its own budget unit Eurowings. (Reuters)
Source: www.businessworld.ie
About us
Load-Date: November 10, 2016
End of Document

Body
October traffic statistics as follows: Traffic grew 13% to 10.9m customers.Load factor rose 1% point to 95%Rolling 
annual traffic to Oct grew 16% to 114.4m customersRyanair'sKenny Jacobs said: "Ryanair's October traffic grew by 
13% to 10.9m customers, while our load factor jumped 1% point to 95%, on the back of lower fares and the 
continuing success of our "Always Getting Better" customer experience programme. Customers can look forward to 
even lower fares when they make advance bookings for summer 2017, so there's never been a better time to book 
a low fare flight on Ryanair and we urge all customers who wish to book their summer 2017 holidays to do so now 
on the Ryanair.com website or mobile app, where they can avail of the lowest fares in Europe."

Ryanair Reports October Traffic Increases 13%; Load Factor Rises to 95%
Ryanair Reports October Traffic Increases 13%; Load Factor Rises to 95%
MT Newswires Live Briefs
November 2, 2016 Wednesday 6:24 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 61 words
Body
 Ryanair (RYAAY), a low-fair passenger airline, reported increased that in October traffic, measured in revenue 
passenger miles, increased 13% to 10.9 million customers from 9.7 million in the same period last year. Rolling 
annual traffic to Oct. grew 16% to 114.4 million customers. The load factor was 95%, up 1% from last year. 
Price: 74.93, Change: , Percent Change: 
Load-Date: November 3, 2016
End of Document
European ADRs Fractionally Higher as Technology Stocks Advance
European ADRs Fractionally Higher as Technology Stocks Advance
MT Newswires Live Briefs
November 2, 2016 Wednesday 10:26 AM EST
Copyright 2016 MT Newswires All Rights Reserved
Length: 194 words
Body
 American depository receipts of European stocks were 0.03% higher at 116.65 on the Bank of New York Mellon 
Europe ADR Index on Wednesday morning. 
Gainers in Continental Europe were led by Criteo (CRTO), a French technology company, 9.8% higher,  Talend 
(TLND), a provider of open source integration solutions, up by 5.4% and Telefonaktiebolaget LM Ericsson (ERIC), a 
Sweden-based telecommunications operator, 3.5% higher. 
In the UK, Randgold Resources (GOLD), a gold-mining company, was 3.8% higher, followed by low-cost airline 
Ryanair (RYAAY), up by 2.4% and education company Pearson (PSO), 1.5% higher. 
Decliners in Continental Europe were led by voxeljet (VJET), a German three-dimensional printer manufacturer, 
3.3% lower, followed by Marine Harvest (MHG), a Norwegian seafood company, down by 2.6% and VimpelCom- 
Com (VIP), a Dutch provider of telecommunications services, down by 2.1%. 
And, in the UK, biopharmaceutical companies GW Pharmaceuticals (GWPH) and Amarin (AMRN), were down by 
1.8% and 1.6%, respectively, while oil and gas production company Royal Dutch Shell - A Shares (RDS.A), was 
1.6% lower. 
Price: 39.70, Change: +3.09, Percent Change: +8.44
Load-Date: November 3, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair to step up battle with Germany 's Lufthansa
Ryanair to step up battle with Germany's Lufthansa
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
November 2, 2016 Wednesday 2:40 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 150 words
Body
       By Andrew McCathie, dpa   BERLIN (dpa-AFX) - Europe's biggest low-cost airline Ryanair is to take on 
Lufthansa on its home turf by beginning to fly out of Frankfurt airport, the German national carrier's main hub.  
Frankfurt airport operator Fraport and Ryanair announced on Wednesday that the Irish airline will use Germany's 
biggest airport to fly from March 2017 to holiday destinations such as Spain's Mallorca, Alicante and Malaga, as 
well as Faro in Portugal.  Ryanair is currently planning to operate two aircraft out of Frankfurt with four departures 
each day generating about 400,000 passengers a year  But the budget airline is already planning an expansion of 
the number of destinations it flies to and from Frankfurt by the end of the year.  'We hope that we will be able to 
offer a significantly bigger flight plan from winter,' said Ryanair spokesman Kenny Jacobs.   Copyright dpa    
Load-Date: November 2, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair to step up battle with Germany 's Lufthansa
Ryanair to step up battle with Germany's Lufthansa
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
November 2, 2016 Wednesday 1:05 PM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved

Body
       By Andrew McCathie, dpa   BERLIN (dpa-AFX) - Europe's biggest low-cost airline Ryanair is take on Lufthansa 
on its home turf by beginning to fly out of Frankfurt airport, the German national carrier's main hub.  Frankfurt airport 
operator Fraport and Ryanair announced on Wednesday that the Irish airline will use Germany's biggest airport to 
fly from March 2017 to holiday destinations such as Spain's Mallorca, Alicante and Malaga, as well as Faro in 
Portugal.  Ryanair is currently planning to operate two aircraft out of Frankfurt with four departures each day 
generating about 400,000 passengers a year  But the budget airline is already planning an expansion of the 
number of destinations it flies to and from Frankfurt by the end of the year.  'We hope that we will be able to offer a 
significantly bigger flight plan from winter,' said Ryanair spokesman Kenny Jacobs.   Copyright dpa

Ryanair to step up battle with Germany 's Lufthansa
Ryanair to step up battle with Germany's Lufthansa
dpa-AFX International ProFeed
November 2, 2016 Wednesday 11:36 AM GMT
Copyright 2016 dpa-AFX Wirtschaftsnachrichten GmbH All Rights Reserved
Length: 176 words
Body
       BERLIN (dpa-AFX) - Irish low-cost airline Ryanair is take on Lufthansa on its home turf by beginning to fly out 
of Frankfurt airport, the German national carrier's main hub.  Frankfurt airport operator Fraport and Ryanair are 
expected to announced at a press conference on Wednesday that the budget airline will use Germany's biggest 
airport to at least initially fly to Spanish holiday destinations such as Mallorca.   The Frankfurt-Mallorca route is 
already served by Lufthansa along with German airlines Air Berlin, Condor, SunExpress and Tuifly during the peak 
summer holiday season.   Up until now Ryanair, like other low-cost airlines, has tended to avoid the Frankfurt hub 
because of the higher airport fees as well as the longer turnaround times for the aircraft on the ground at the airport.   
But, according to the daily Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, Ryanair will receive a new customer discount from 
Fraport, and the budget airline will announce a 35-minute turnaround time between landing and departure at 
Frankfurt.   Copyright dpa    
Load-Date: November 2, 2016
End of Document
